{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2014}} {{Infobox politician | name = David McReynolds | image = NLN David McReynolds.jpg | caption = McReynolds at the 2009 Left Forum in [[New York City]] | party = Independent | otherparty = [[Socialist Party USA|Socialist Party]] (1951–2015)
[[Prohibition Party]] (before 1951)Mulkerin, Joseph. [http://thevillager.com/2015/08/27/a-socialist-presidential-candidate-no-not-that-one-looks-back/ "A socialist presidential candidate — no, not that one — looks back"]. ''[[The Villager (Manhattan)|The Villager]]'', 27 August 2015. Retrieved 28 August 2015.
[[Green Party (United States)|Green]] (affiliated non-member) |birth_name=David Ernest McReynoldsJames T. Havel. [https://books.google.ca/books?id=BwgWAQAAIAAJ&q=%22David+Ernest+McReynolds%22&dq=%22David+Ernest+McReynolds%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwitqY3vg_bcAhXp7IMKHWxQCJ4Q6AEIFDAA ''The Elections, 1789-1992''], Macmillan Library Reference USA, (1996) | birth_date = {{Birth date|1929|10|25}} | birth_place = [[Los Angeles, California]] | alma_mater = [[University of California Los Angeles]] | death_date = {{death date and age|2018|8|17|1929|10|25}} | death_place = [[New York, New York]] | religion = | occupation = Activist, politician, writer }} '''David Ernest McReynolds''' (October 25, 1929 – August 17, 2018) was an American politician and [[social activist]] who was a prominent [[democratic socialism|democratic socialist]] and [[pacifist]] [[activist]]. He described himself as "a peace movement bureaucrat" during his 40-year career with the [[War Resisters League]].David McReynolds, "Thinking About Retirement", ''Nonviolent Activist'', March–April 1999, p. 7.[https://www.amazon.com/Saving-Remnant-Radical-Barbara-McReynolds/dp/1595583238 Martin Duberman, ''A Saving Remnant: The Radical Lives of Barbara Deming and David McReynolds,'' New York: The New Press (2011)]{{rp|221}} He was a resident of New York City.{{cite web|url=http://www.ourcampaigns.com/CandidateDetail.html?CandidateID=7993|title=Our Campaigns - Candidate - David McReynolds|website=www.ourcampaigns.com|accessdate=October 4, 2017}} McReynolds was twice a candidate for [[President of the United States]], running atop the ticket of the [[Socialist Party USA]] in 1980 and 2000. {{American socialism |expanded=People}} ==Early life== McReynolds was born in Los Angeles, to Elizabeth Grace (Tallon), a nurse, and Lt. Col. Charles McReynolds, an Air Force intelligence officer.https://www.ourcampaigns.com/CandidateDetail.html?CandidateID=7993 In 1951 he joined the [[Socialist Party of America]] (SPA) and in 1953 he graduated from [[UCLA]] with a degree in [[political science]]. Between 1957 and 1960, he worked for the [[editorial board]] of the left-wing magazine ''[[Liberation (magazine)|Liberation]]''. He was [[openly gay]] and wrote his first article about living as a gay man in 1969.Leaders from the 1960s: A Biographical Sourcebook of American Activism. Edited By David De Leon Published by Greenwood Publishing Group, 1994 {{ISBN|0-313-27414-2}} pp.215–219 ==War Resisters League== McReynolds was staunchly [[anti-war]] and a [[Conscription#Draft resisters|draft resister]], and in 1960 joined the staff of the [[War Resisters League]] (WRL), where he remained until his retirement in 1999. In 1965 he lectured on 'The Old Left and the New Left' at the newly founded [[Free University of New York]].{{Citation| last = [[Joseph Berke|Berke]]| first = Joseph | title = The Free University of New York| journal = Peace News| volume =| issue =|date=October 29, 1965| pages = 6–7| url =}} as reproduced in {{Citation |last=Jakobsen |first=Jakob |title=Anti-University of Londin–Antihistory Tabloid |publisher=MayDay Rooms |location=London |year=2012 |pages=6–7 |url=http://maydayrooms.org/room-3-research/ |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121012141942/http://maydayrooms.org/room-3-research/ |archivedate=October 12, 2012 |df=mdy }} On November 6, 1965, he was one of five men who publicly [[Draft-card burning|burned their draft cards]] at an [[Opposition to the Vietnam War#The draft|anti-war demonstration]] at Union Square in New York. This was one of the first public draft-card burnings after U.S. law was changed on August 30, 1965 to make such actions a felony, punishable by up to five years' imprisonment. He was close friends with [[Bayard Rustin]]John D'Emilio. READING THE SILENCES IN A GAY LIFE The Case of Bayard Rustin pp. 59–68 in The Seductions of Biography. Edited: Mary Rhiel, David Suchoff, David Bruce Suchoff. Routledge, 1996 {{ISBN|0-415-91089-7}}
"Rustin's only defender was Dave McReynolds, a younger gay staffer at the War Resisters League, whom Rustin had mentored over the years" and other prominent peace activists, as well as literary figures such as [[Quentin Crisp]].Dave McReynolds. [http://www.crisperanto.org/memories/mcreynolds.html NOTES ON KNOWING QUENTIN]. and [http://www.crisperanto.org/memories/mcreynolds1.html QUENTIN CRISP: THE RADICAL], Quentin Crisp Archives (2005) In 1968, he signed the "[[Writers and Editors War Tax Protest]]" pledge, vowing to refuse tax payments in protest against the Vietnam War."Writers and Editors War Tax Protest" January 30, 1968 ''New York Post'' McReynolds was particularly active internationally, both in [[War Resisters' International]] of which he was chairperson for the term 1986–88, and in the International Confederation for Disarmament and Peace which eventually merged into the [[International Peace Bureau]]. ==Socialist Party USA== The SPA was renamed the [[Social Democrats USA]] by a majority vote at the 1972 convention. [[Michael Harrington]] resigned and then formed the [[Democratic Socialist Organizing Committee]] (now the [[Democratic Socialists of America]], DSA) with the purpose of "realignment" strengthening the role of labor unions and other progressive organizations in the [[United States Democratic Party|Democratic Party]] to pull it to the left. The smallest and the most left wing of the SPA, known as the [[Debs Caucus]], including McReynolds, formed the [[Socialist Party USA]] (SPUSA). McReynolds was long a member of both DSA and SPUSA. McReynolds' primary theoretical contribution to socialism came from his blending of a [[pacifist]] world-view with a commitment to re-distributive [[socialist economics]]. Politically, he was a staunch [[anti-authoritarian]] and collaborated with a diverse set of political formations on the democratic left. His widely read pamphlet, ''The Philosophy of Nonviolence'', provides a unique window into the mind of a lifelong activist wrestling with the contradictions and pitfalls which plagued the political left in the 20th century. He concludes that "...there is no living, vital philosophy which does not have 'holes' in it." Consequently, he mapped out a [[Pluralism (philosophy)|pluralistic]] approach which is, on the one hand, socialist, yet is entirely engaged with thought systems as seemingly contradictory as [[Hindu philosophy]]. He concluded that a brand of pacifist-socialism is best suited for future socialist experiments since it offers the greatest opportunity to prefigure the kinds of democratic relations necessary to create a functional and free society.{{Clarify|date=September 2010}} In his political career, McReynolds ran for [[United States Congress|Congress]] from [[Lower Manhattan]] twice and for [[President of the United States|President]] twice. In 1958 he ran as a write-in SPA candidate and then in 1968 as a [[Peace and Freedom Party]] candidate for Congress in the 19th district pulling in 4.7% of the vote (3,969 votes).{{cite web|url=http://clerk.house.gov/member_info/electionInfo/1968election.pdf |title=Statistics of the Presidential and Congressional Election of November 5, 1968 |publisher= |date= |accessdate=2011-09-27}} In 1980, he ran for President of the United States as the SPUSA candidate, with [[Diane Drufenbrock]] as vice presidential candidate, receiving 6,994 votes (0.01%).{{cite web|url=http://uselectionatlas.org/RESULTS/national.php?year=1980&off=0 |title=1980 Presidential General Election Results |publisher= |date= |accessdate=2011-09-27}}Kari Lydersen. David vs. Goliath. In These Times. Vol. 24, No. 10 (2000).
On his 1980 presidential run: "He was among the first openly gay political candidates for any office, having come out in WIN magazine in 1969, and though he doesn't see himself as a "gay and lesbian candidate," he has continued to work for gay rights." Upon the request of fellow Socialists, he ran again for President as the SPUSA candidate in 2000, with [[Mary Cal Hollis]] as his running mate, receiving 5,602 votes. In both 1980 and 2000, McReynolds received the endorsement and ballot line of the [[Liberty Union Party]] in Vermont.{{cite web|url=http://www.thegreenpapers.com/G00/VT.html#Pre |title=Vermont November 2000 General Election |publisher=Thegreenpapers.com |date= |accessdate=2011-09-27}} After the 2000 election, the ''Palm Beach Post'' speculated that 2,908 voters, "mostly in elderly Jewish districts", had mistakenly voted for both Al Gore, running for President on the Democratic ticket, and for McReynolds on a "confusing [[butterfly ballot]]", thereby resulting in voided votes, helping to cost Gore the state's crucial electoral votes.{{cite web |url=http://www.palmbeachpost.com/politics/content/news/election2000/election2000_overvote_gore.html |title=Joel Engelhardt and Scott McCabe, "Over-votes cost Gore the election in Florida," ''Palm Beach Post,'' undated website |publisher=Palmbeachpost.com |date= |accessdate=2011-09-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110616195335/http://www.palmbeachpost.com/politics/content/news/election2000/election2000_overvote_gore.html |archivedate=June 16, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} {{cite web|url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/421793208 |title=Kevin Phillips, "The GOP's control of Congress and the White House can last only so long," ''Los Angeles Times,'' April 15, 2001, page M-1 |accessdate=2011-09-27}} {{dead link|date=June 2017}} In January 2015, the [[Socialist Party USA]]'s National Committee voted to [[censure]] McReynolds over alleged racist comments made on social media regarding the [[Charlie Hebdo shooting]] and [[shooting of Michael Brown]].{{cite web|last=Reinholz|first=Mary|title=Rift Among Socialists Over Former Presidential Hopeful’s ‘Potentially Racist’ Comments About Michael Brown|url=http://bedfordandbowery.com/2015/05/rift-among-socialists-over-former-presidential-hopefuls-potentially-racist-comments-about-michael-brown/|publisher=Bedford + Bowery|date=May 1, 2015|accessdate=February 16, 2016}} He resigned from the SPUSA shortly thereafter. ==2004 Senate campaign== {{Main|United States Senate election in New York, 2004}} On July 10, 2004, McReynolds announced his candidacy running on the [[Green Party (United States)|Green Party]] ticket for one of the New York seats in the [[United States Senate elections, 2004|Senate]], running an anti-war campaign against Democratic incumbent [[Chuck Schumer]], where he pulled in 36,942 votes for 0.5% of total.{{cite web|url=http://www.elections.ny.gov/NYSBOE/elections/2006/general/2006_ussen.pdf |title=NYS Board of Elections US Senate Election Returns Nov. 7, 2006 |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2011-09-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120822221220/http://www.elections.ny.gov/NYSBOE/elections/2006/general/2006_ussen.pdf |archivedate=August 22, 2012 |df=mdy }} ==Later life== McReynolds was active politically until just before his death, attending meetings; speaking in classrooms; being interviewed for films and research; and participating in peace/justice/antiwar/antinuclear actions. His last arrest was at the U.S. Mission to the U.N. in 2015 at an action calling for immediate nuclear disarmament, starting with the U.S. He was an avid photographer throughout his adult life and spent time during the last three years of his life sorting his collection of more than 50,000 photos. A photo website is linked under Works, below. In 2015, McReynolds endorsed U.S. Senator [[Bernie Sanders]] for [[President of the United States]], praising him as a "serious candidate" and for not personally attacking his Democratic rival [[Hillary Clinton]].{{cite web|url=http://www.peoplesworld.org/article/why-i-support-bernie-sanders/|title=Why I support Bernie Sanders|publisher=Peoples World|date=July 7, 2015}} McReynolds died on August 17, 2018, aged 88, following a fall he sustained at his New York City home.{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/ny-news-david-mcreynolds-dead-88-story.html|title=David McReynolds, longtime peace activist and agitator, dead at 88|publisher=New York Daily News|date=August 17, 2018}} ==Footnotes== {{Reflist|2}} == Works == * ''We Have Been Invaded by the 21st Century.'' {{more footnotes|date=March 2013}} {{Infobox person |name=David Seymour |image=David Seymour, taken by Elliott Erwitt.jpg |caption=David Seymour (Chim), 1954, by [[Elliott Erwitt]]. |birth_name=Dawid Szymin |birth_date=November 20, 1911 |birth_place=[[Warsaw, Poland]] |death_place=[[Egypt]] |death_date={{death date and given age|1956|11|10|44}} |occupation=Photographer, photo journalist |other_names=Chim }} '''David Seymour''' (born '''Dawid Szymin''';[http://www.thejc.com/lifestyle/lifestyle-features/104539/chim-photographys-forgotten-hero Chim: Photography's forgotten hero] November 20, 1911 – November 10, 1956), or '''Chim''' (pronounced ''shim'', an abbreviation of the surname "Szymin"), was a Polish [[Photography|photographer]] and [[photojournalism|photojournalist]]. Chim was known for his images from the [[Spanish Civil War]], for co-founding [[Magnum Photos]] with [[Henri Cartier-Bresson]], [[Robert Capa]] and [[George Rodger]],[https://pro.magnumphotos.com/C.aspx?VP3=CMS3&VF=MAX_2&FRM=Frame:MAX_3#/CMS3&VF=MAX_2&FRM=Frame:MAX_5: History of Magnum] and for his project "Children of War" with [[UNICEF]] that captured the plight of children in the aftermath of [[World War II]].[https://www.unicef.org/emergencies/index_69785.html: UNICEF's first international photographer] He became president of Magnum after Capa's death in 1954 and held this post until his own death in 1956 by Egyptian machinegun fire in the aftermath of the [[Suez crisis]].[https://www.magnumphotos.com/theory-and-practice/david-seymour-life-worth-living/: David Seymour: A Life Worth Living] ==Early life== Chim was born to Polish Jewish parents in [[Warsaw]] in 1911. David had a sister, Eileen, who was three years older. Their parents were Regina and Benjamin Szymin, a respected publisher of Yiddish and Hebrew books.{{cite web |url=http://museum.icp.org/museum/collections/special/chim/chim2.html|title=Chim |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130315180604/http://museum.icp.org/museum/collections/special/chim/chim2.html |archivedate=2013-03-15 |df= }} In 1914 Chim and his parents emigrated to Odessa just as [[World War I]] had begun. In 1919 they returned to Warsaw. Chim studied graphic arts in [[Leipzig]] and then traveled to [[Paris]] to study at the [[Sorbonne]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nga.gov/feature/chim/bio.shtm|title=Biography|work=Chim: David Seymour's Humanist Photography|publisher=[[National Gallery of Art]]|accessdate=2013-03-27}} ==Career== [[File:David Seymour, A Disturbed Child in a Warsaw Orphanage, 1948.jpg|thumbnail|right|A Disturbed Child in a Warsaw Orphanage, 1948, by Chim. Identified as Teresa Adwentowska, per Tel Aviv University exhibit]] It was while Chim was studying at the [[Sorbonne]] in [[Paris]] that he became interested in photography. He began working as a freelance journalist in 1933. His first "credited" published photograph appeared in 1934 in the magazine ''[[Regards]].'' Between 1936 and 1938 Chim covered the [[Spanish Civil War]] (alongside colleague [[Robert Capa]]) and other international political events. In February 1935 Chim was sent to Spain by ''Regards'' to report on crucial issues there. Twenty five of his stories on Spain ended up being published in ''Regards.'' In 1939 he covered the Loyalist Spanish war refugees on the S.S. Sinaia to Mexico and then later in the year he arrived in the United States. Chim was in New York City when [[World War II]] broke out in Europe when Nazi Germany invaded Poland, Chim's birthplace. In 1940 he enlisted in the United States Army, serving in Europe as a photo interpreter during the war. In 1942 he became a naturalized citizen of the United States, the same year that his parents were killed by the Nazis.http://www.jewage.org/wiki/he/Article:David_Seymour_-_Biography Chim photographed for ''[[Life (magazine)|Life]]'', along with ''[[Look (American magazine)|Look]],'' ''[[Paris-Match]]'' and ''Regards.'' In 1948 he received a commission through [[UNICEF]] and traveled to Austria, Hungary, Italy, Poland and Germany to document the plight of World War II refugee children. Inge Bondi, Chim scholar, said:
Chim's heart had always gone out to children, and they reacted to him with complete acceptance. They seemed oblivious of him, but he noticed every little movement, every little pain, every little pleasure. There is no artifice, no bravura of lighting expertise in Chim's photographs of the children. They speak simply from his pictures, as if alive. This intellectual, so adept at analyzing the most complex political situations, so comfortable photographing heads of state, produced his greatest photographs to help children in need.{{cite book|last=Bondi|first=Inge|title=CHIM: The Photographs of David Seymour|publisher=Bulfinch Press/Little, Brown and Company}}
Between 1949 and 1955 Chim travelled extensively throughout Europe and Israel, fulfilling assignments for major publications in Europe and the United States. [[Edward Steichen]] included his imagery, including his simple but eloquent picture of the worn hands of an older worker clutching a dip-pen to practice the letter 'a', in [[MoMA]]'s 1955 world-touring [[The Family of Man]], seen by 9 million visitors.{{Citation | author1=Steichen, Edward | author2=Steichen, Edward, 1879-1973, (organizer.) | author3=Sandburg, Carl, 1878-1967, (writer of foreword.) | author4=Norman, Dorothy, 1905-1997, (writer of added text.) | author5=Lionni, Leo, 1910-1999, (book designer.) | author6=Mason, Jerry, (editor.) | author7=Stoller, Ezra, (photographer.) | author8=Museum of Modern Art (New York, N.Y.) | title=The family of man : the photographic exhibition | publication-date=1955 | publisher=Published for the Museum of Modern Art by Simon and Schuster in collaboration with the Maco Magazine Corporation | url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/work/10809600 }} ==Magnum Photos== In 1947, Chim co-founded the [[Magnum Photos]] photography cooperative, together with [[Robert Capa]] and [[Henri Cartier-Bresson]], whom he had befriended in Paris in the 1930s. As Inge Bondi, Chim scholar, stated:
Photojournalism was about to enter a golden decade. Television was not yet available to broadcast world events, and editors and the public were eager for news, from which they had been cut off during the fascist years and war years.
After Capa's death in 1954, Chim became president of Magnum Photos. He held that post until his death on November 10, 1956. ==Death== On November 10, 1956, Chim was killed while driving to photograph an exchange of wounded soldiers at El Quantara (along with French photographer Jean Roy) by Egyptian machinegun fire four days after the armistice of the [[Suez Crisis|1956 Suez War]], ten days before his 45th birthday. Chim's work remains available by way of Magnum Photos and his estate is managed by nephew [[Ben Shneiderman]] and niece Helen Sarid. [[File:Pablo Picasso In Front Of Guernica in Paris, 1937.jpg|thumbnail|right|Pablo Picasso in Front of ''[[Guernica (painting)|Guernica]]'', 1937, by Chim.]] ==Photographic portraits == Chim's reputation for his photos of [[war orphan]]s was magnified by his later work in photographing famous people of his time. These included: * [[Sophia Loren]], at home, Naples, Italy (1955) * [[Bernard Berenson]], at 90, visiting [[Borghese Gallery]], Rome, Italy (1955) * [[Pablo Picasso]], in front of detail of [[Guernica (painting)|Guernica]], France (1937) * [[Henri Barbusse]], along with leading left-wing intellectuals in his office at the literary journal "Monde", Paris France (1935) * [[Arturo Toscanini]], at his home, Milan (1954) * [[Ingrid Bergman]], 35 portraits of Ingrid Bergman, Rome, Italy (1952–1956) * [[Roberto Rossellini]], and family (1956) * [[Audrey Hepburn]], 14 portraits (1956) * [[Richard Avedon]], Paris, France (1956) ==Exhibitions== *''CHIM: The Photos of David Seymour'', 1996, [[International Center of Photography]], New York City. *''"Close Enough"'', 1999, [[The Art Gallery at the University of Maryland]], College Park. *''Reflections from the Heart'', September 11 – December 10, 2006, Albin O. Kuhn Library Gallery; March – June 2006, The [[Corcoran Gallery of Art]];{{cite web|url=http://www.corcoran.org/exhibitions/past/reflections-from-the-heart-photographs-by-david-seymour |title=Reflections from the Heart: Photographs by David Seymour |publisher=[[Corcoran Gallery of Art]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130409112323/http://www.corcoran.org/exhibitions/past/reflections-from-the-heart-photographs-by-david-seymour |archivedate=2013-04-09 |df= }} January 20, 2007 – Sunday, April 22, 2007, [[George Eastman House]]. *''Photographs by David Seymour (Selections from George Eastman House),'' May 11 September 9, 2007, International Center of Photography, New York City. *''Chim: The Photography of David Seymour (1911–1956)'', September 29, 2007 – February 24, 2008, the [[De Young (museum)|de Young]], San Francisco. *''The Mexican Suitcase,'' September 24, 2010 – January 9, 2011, International Center of Photography, New York City. *''Chim/Gamboa Exhibition: The Mexican Connection'', December 9, 2010 – March 6, 2011, El Centro de la Imagen, Mexico City. *''CHIM Retrospective'', October 29 to February 27, 2011, the Jewish Museum, Brussels. *''CHIM Rediscovered / CHIM retrouvé,'' December 22, 2012 – January 27, 2013, CLAIR Galerie, St. Paul de Vence, Nice, France. *''CHIM (David Seymour),'' February 7 – March 30, Galerie Walter Keller, Zürich. *''Photographs by David "Chim" Seymour and Roman Vishniac,'' February 1–23, 2013, Howard Greenberg Gallery, New York City. *''We Went Back: Photographs from Europe 1933–1956 by Chim'', January 18 – May 5, 2013, International Center of Photography, New York City. *''David Seymour (CHIM): A Celebration of Chim,'' September 7 – late October, 2013, Leica Gallery, Washington, DC. *''David Seymour (CHIM), October 19th 2018 - March 10th 2019 Jewish Historical Museum Amsterdam. ==Public collections== Chim's work is held in the following public collections: * [[Magnum Photos]], New York City * [[International Center of Photography]], New York City * [[George Eastman House]], Rochester, NY * [[National Gallery of Art]], Washington, DC * [[Corcoran Gallery of Art]], Washington, DC * The [[De Young (museum)|de Young]], San Francisco, CA * [[Victoria and Albert Museum]], London * [[Harry Ransom Center]], Austin, TX ==Bibliography== *''Krieg in Spanien (War in Spain),'' by S.L. Shneiderman, Photos by Chim, Warsaw, Poland: Yiddish Universal Library, 1938. *''Children of Europe.'' Photographs by David Seymour, 1949. *''The Vatican.'' Photographs by David Seymour, 1950. *''Little Ones.'' Photographs by David Seymour, 1957. *"Chim (David Seymour), 1911–1956." Paris: Michel Brient, 1966. *''David Seymour ("Chim")'' Paragraphic Editor: Anna Farova - Associate Editors: Cornell Capa & Sam Holmes, New York City: Grossman Publishers, 1966. *''The Concerned Photographer.'' Photographs by David Seymour, 1968. *''Israel/The Reality - People, Places, Events in Memorable Photographs,'' Edited by Cornell Capa, Micha Bar-am, Karl Katz & Arnold Saks, New York City: The World Publishing Company in association with the Jewish Museum, 1969. *''David Seymour Chim, 1911–1956.'' Photographs by David Seymour, 1974. *''David Seymour--"Chim."'' ICP Library of Photographers Editors: Cornell Capa and Bhupendra Karia, New York City: Grossman Publishers, 1974. *''Front Populaire,'' photographs by Robert Capa and David Seymour-Chim, Paris, France: Chene-Magnum, 1976. *''Les Grandes Photos de la Guerre d'Espagne." Photographs by Robert Capa, David Seymour-Chim,' 1980. *''In Our Time. The World as Seen by Magnum Photographers.'' Text by William Manchester. Norton, New York City, 1989. *''Chim. The Photographs of David Seymour.'' Photographs by Chim (David Seymour). Bulfinch, Boston, 1996. *''Chim: The Photographs of David Seymour.'' Bondi, Inge. Boston, 1996. *''Magnum. Fifty Years at the Front Line.'' Text by Russell Miller. New York City, 1998. *''Close Enough. Photographs by Chim (David Seymour).'' College Park, 1999. *''David Seymour, Chim.'' Valencia, 2003. *''David Seymour (Chim).'' Beck, Tom. London and New York City, 2005. *''Chim: Children of War.'' Naggar, Carole. Umbrage Editions, 2013. *''David Seymour: Vies de Chim.'' Naggar, Carole. Contrejour, 2014. ==Filmography== *''[[The Mexican Suitcase (film)|The Mexican Suitcase]].'' Dir. Trisha Ziff. 212 Berlin, 2011. Film.http://www.themexicansuitcase.com/ *''Chim's Children of Europe.'' 2013. 7-minute video.https://vimeo.com/57370037 ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.magnumphotos.com/C.aspx?VP=XSpecific_MAG.PhotographerDetail_VPage&l1=0&pid=2K7O3R139PNF&nm=David%20Seymour: The Photographs of David Seymour] *[https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=5295557 NPR Story: Reflections from the Heart] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BSftmzlk4pY UMD Professor Ben Shneiderman on David "Chim" Seymour] *[http://blogs.loc.gov/loc/2014/11/david-seymour-chim-photographer-of-the-spanish-civil-war/ Library of Congress blog] and [https://www.loc.gov/today/cyberlc/feature_wdesc.php?rec=6614 Video] *[https://www.loc.gov/rr/print/coll/david-seymour-photograph-collection.html?loclr=blogpic Library of Congress website for David Seymour Collection] *[http://www.davidseymour.com/ Chim Home Page] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Seymour, David}} [[Category:1911 births]] [[Category:1956 deaths]] [[Category:American army personnel of World War II]] [[Category:Deaths by firearm in Egypt]] [[Category:Magnum photographers]] [[Category:Polish emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:American photojournalists]] [[Category:American people of Polish-Jewish descent]] [[Category:Journalists killed while covering military conflicts]] [[Category:Polish photojournalists]] [[Category:United States Army soldiers]]

revision.comment: removed [[Category:Accidental deaths from falls]]; added [[Category:Deaths from falls]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
'''Ahmad Sarbani Mohamed''' was a [[Malaysians|Malaysian]] customs officer from [[Port Klang]]. On 6 April 2011, he was found dead in an open air badminton court on the first floor of the [[Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission]] (MACC) building in [[Kuala Lumpur]].<ref name="found">{{cite news |title=Body of senior Customs officer found in badminton court |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/4/7/nation/8434162&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=17 April 2011 |accessdate=20 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110812064250/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2011%2F4%2F7%2Fnation%2F8434162&sec=nation |archivedate=12 August 2011 |df= }}</ref> His death coincided with the MACC's investigation into allegations of corruption in the [[Royal Malaysian Customs]].<ref name="found"/> The MACC insists that Ahmad Sarbani was not murdered, nor did he commit suicide, but rather fell to his death trying to escape from the building.<ref name="rulesout"/> In September 2011, the coroner's court ruled the death an accident.<ref name="ruling"/>
Ahmad Sarbani's death came nearly two years after the death of [[Teoh Beng Hock]] in the custody of the MACC.<ref name="fewwords">{{cite news |title=Few words, tears as Ahmad Sarbani laid to rest |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/few-words-tears-as-ahmad-sarbani-laid-to-rest |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=7 April 2011 |last=Chong |first=Debra |accessdate=20 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110410114140/http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/few-words-tears-as-ahmad-sarbani-laid-to-rest |archivedate=10 April 2011 |df= }}</ref><ref name="fmt1"/> A royal commission of inquiry ruled Teoh's death as suicide resulting from abusive behaviour by MACC officers,<ref>{{cite news |title=RCI rules Beng Hock committed suicide |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/rci-rules-beng-hock-committed-suicide/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=21 July 2011 |last=Chong |first=Debra |accessdate=21 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723232724/http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/rci-rules-beng-hock-committed-suicide |archivedate=23 July 2011 |df= }}</ref> a verdict which was rejected by the victim's family.<ref>{{cite news|title=Teoh family rejects RCI verdict |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/teoh-family-rejects-rci-verdict/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=21 July 2011 |last=Yow |first=Hong Chieh |accessdate=21 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121015002847/http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/teoh-family-rejects-rci-verdict/ |archivedate=15 October 2012 |df= }}</ref>
==Biography== Ahmad Sarbani bin Mohamed was the Selangor Customs assistant director.<ref name="evidence">{{cite news |title=New evidence in Ahmad Sarbani’s death |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/4/13/nation/8472810&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=13 April 2011 |author=M. Shaminee |accessdate=20 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110809082759/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2011%2F4%2F13%2Fnation%2F8472810&sec=nation |archivedate=9 August 2011 |df= }}</ref> He was attached to the [[Port Klang]] Customs office.<ref name="never"/> At the time of his death, Ahmad Sarbani was 56 years old.<ref name="fewwords"/> He is survived by his parents, his wife, and five children.<ref name="fewwords"/>
==Events leading to death== On 29 March 2011, the MACC announced that it had uncovered a syndicate involved in [[tax evasion]], [[money laundering]] and illegal money outflows worth RM108 billion.<ref name="ongoing">{{cite news |title=Investigations on Customs officers ongoing |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/05/26/investigations-on-customs-officers-ongoing/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=26 May 2011 |author=S. Rutra |accessdate=20 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110805042059/http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/05/26/investigations-on-customs-officers-ongoing/ |archivedate=5 August 2011 |df= }}</ref><ref name="3b">{{cite news |title=Customs, MACC meets Tuesday over Ops 3B, Sarbani’s death |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/customs-macc-meets-tuesday-over-ops-3b-sarbanis-death/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=11 April 2011 |author=G. Manimaran |accessdate=20 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110414133730/http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/customs-macc-meets-tuesday-over-ops-3b-sarbanis-death |archivedate=14 April 2011 |df= }}</ref> That figure was later revised to RM2.2 billion.<ref name="probe">{{cite news |title=Probe papers on Sarbani’s death handed to MACC complaints panel |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/6/4/nation/8838453&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=4 June 2011 |accessdate=20 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121019012749/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2011%2F6%2F4%2Fnation%2F8838453&sec=nation |archivedate=19 October 2012 |df= }}</ref> A special task force comprising the MACC, the Inland Revenue Board, the Customs Department and [[Bank Negara Malaysia]] raided over 100 premises, including 25 [[Royal Malaysian Customs]] offices, in what was known as "Operation 3B."<ref name="3b"/>
Ahmad Sarbani was among 62 customs officers who were detained relation to the investigation.<ref name="fmt1">{{cite news |title=Customs officer falls to his death at MACC office |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/04/06/customs-officer-falls-to-his-death-at-macc-office/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=6 April 2011 |accessdate=20 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110628120554/http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/04/06/customs-officer-falls-to-his-death-at-macc-office/ |archivedate=28 June 2011 |df= }}</ref> He was first detained on 1 April 2011.<ref name="probe"/> He was then picked up again by the MACC for questioning on 4 April.<ref name="failed">{{cite news |title=MACC duo failed to ensure Ahmad Sarbani’s safety |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/4/8/nation/8440308&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=8 April 2011 |accessdate=20 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110511202145/http://www.thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2011%2F4%2F8%2Fnation%2F8440308&sec=nation |archivedate=11 May 2011 |df= }}</ref> During this round of questioning, he confessed to accepting between RM50 and RM100 a month from Schenker Logistics officer Wan Zainal Abidin Wan Zaki and between RM30 and RM200 a month from a Top Mark Freight & Shipping officer called Ah Seng.<ref name="beaten">{{cite news |title=Customs officer: I was beaten and forced to confess |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/customs-officer-i-was-beaten-and-forced-to-confess/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=14 July 2011 |last=Chi |first=Melissa |accessdate=20 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717164525/http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/customs-officer-i-was-beaten-and-forced-to-confess |archivedate=17 July 2011 |df= }}</ref> After giving his statement, Sarbani was released on bail.<ref name="failed"/>
He returned to the MACC building on Jalan Cochrane, [[Kuala Lumpur]] at 8:26am on 6 April, apparently to change a statement he had previously given.<ref name="found"/><ref name="probe"/> The MACC maintains he had gone on his own accord without prior appointment.<ref name="found"/> According to MACC accounts, Ahmad Sarbani was brought into a room on the third floor by an officer and disappeared a few minutes after 10:15am.<ref name="found"/><ref name="fmt1"/> He was then found dead in the open air badminton court on the first floor at 10:20am.<ref name="found"/>
Police classified the case as sudden death.<ref name="found"/> <ref name="fall">{{cite news |title=Cops: Sarbani died because of fall |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/4/22/nation/8534706&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=22 April 2011 |last=Chiew |first=Steven |accessdate=20 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121019012809/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2011%2F4%2F22%2Fnation%2F8534706&sec=nation |archivedate=19 October 2012 |df= }}</ref>
==Aftermath== In a press conference after the news emerged, MACC director of investigations Mustafar Ali said Ahmad Sarbani went to the MACC building without prior appointment.<ref name="found"/> Two MACC investigating officers who met Ahmad Sarbani were suspended on 8 April.<ref name="failed"/> The MACC also announced that all business with accused persons, suspects, witnesses and complainants would be conducted only on the ground floor with heightened supervision.<ref>{{cite news |title=MACC to use ground floor for business with public |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/04/08/macc-to-use-ground-floor-for-business-with-public/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=8 April 2011 |accessdate=20 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110820154140/http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/04/08/macc-to-use-ground-floor-for-business-with-public/ |archivedate=20 August 2011 |df= }}</ref>
None of the Customs officers initially held under the tax evasion and money laundering allegations has been charged.<ref name="ongoing"/>
Ahmad Sarbani's family lawyers denied allegations that he was involved in money laundering and rejected suggestions that he committed suicide.<ref name="evidence"/>
===Inquest=== On 2 June 2011, Attorney-General [[Abdul Gani Patail]] agreed to hold an inquest into Ahmad Sarbani's death.<ref name="probe"/> The inquest was held from 4 to 15 July 2011 at the magistrate's court in Kuala Lumpur<ref>{{cite news |title=Ahmad Sarbaini’s death: Inquest from July 4-15 |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/6/14/nation/20110614102429&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=14 June 2011 |author=M. Mageswari |accessdate=20 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121019012826/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2011%2F6%2F14%2Fnation%2F20110614102429&sec=nation |archivedate=19 October 2012 |df= }}</ref> and continued on 2 August.<ref name="rulesout"/><ref>{{cite news|title=Sarbaini inquest verdict out on Sept 26 |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/sarbaini-inquest-verdict-out-on-sept-26/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=4 August 2011 |first=Melissa |last=Chi |accessdate=4 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121015082248/http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/sarbaini-inquest-verdict-out-on-sept-26/ |archivedate=15 October 2012 |df= }}</ref>
;Family Sarbani's wife, Maziah, told the court that her husband was "very calm, patient and rational" and would "never" have committed suicide.<ref name="never">{{cite news |title=Ahmad Sarbani would not commit suicide, wife tells inquest |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/7/4/nation/20110704141101&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=4 July 2011 |last=Goh |first=Lisa |accessdate=20 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110710060927/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2011%2F7%2F4%2Fnation%2F20110704141101&sec=nation |archivedate=10 July 2011 |df= }}</ref>
;Schenker Logistics Schenker Logistics senior executive Wan Zainal Abidin Wan Zaki denied that Sarbani ever took bribes from his company. Zainal Abidin said Sarbani called him at 8:55pm on 4 April to tell him that his name was mentioned by Sarbani when questioned by the MACC. He also told the court he felt Sarbani was being pressured. Zainal Abidin last spoke to Sarbani at 9:55pm on 5 April to ask how he was.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ahmad Sarbani didn’t take money from company, inquest told |url=https://www.mysinchew.com/node/60201 |work=[[Sin Chew Daily]] |date=8 July 2011 |author=Bernama |authorlink=Bernama |accessdate=20 July 2011 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110830144117/http://www.mysinchew.com/node/60201 |archivedate=30 August 2011 |df= }}</ref>
;Customs officers Customs officer Abdul Rahim Abdul Kadir, who among those arrested in the MACC crackdown on tax evasion and money laundering, told the court that he was beaten and forced to confess to accepting bribes by the MACC.<ref name="beaten"/> He said he lodged a police report on the incident then retracted it out of fear.<ref>{{cite news |title=MACC ‘victim’ retracted police report out of fear |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/macc-victim-retracted-police-report-out-of-fear/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=14 July 2011 |last=Chi |first=Melissa |accessdate=20 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717235212/http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/macc-victim-retracted-police-report-out-of-fear |archivedate=17 July 2011 |df= }}</ref> Another Customs officer, Mohd Khairul Hisyam Mohd Gazali, said Sarbani told him on 2 April that he was pressured by the MACC to confess that he had accepted bribes but refused to give in.<ref name="beaten"/>
Three of Sarbani's colleagues testified that Sarbani was calm and patient man with "high integrity."<ref>{{cite news |title=Sarbaini seorang tenang, tidak mudah melatah, kata rakan |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/bahasa/article/sarbaini-seorang-tenang-tidak-mudah-melatah-kata-rakan/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=14 July 2011 |accessdate=20 July 2011 |language=Malay |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718103330/http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/bahasa/article/sarbaini-seorang-tenang-tidak-mudah-melatah-kata-rakan |archivedate=18 July 2011 |df= }}</ref>
;MACC Investigating officer Abdul Ghani Ali testified that he was under orders from KL MACC investigation unit head Mohd Fauzi Husin not to allow Sarbani to change his statement on 6 April.<ref name="graft">{{cite news |title=Sarbaini not allowed to change graft confession, says MACC man |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/sarbaini-not-allowed-to-change-graft-confession-says-macc-man/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=12 July 2011 |last=Boo |first=Su-Lyn |accessdate=20 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110715145714/http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/sarbaini-not-allowed-to-change-graft-confession-says-macc-man |archivedate=15 July 2011 |df= }}</ref> He said he ordered Sarbani to wait in the MACC office before Sarbani was found dead.<ref name="graft"/> Ghani also said: "Throughout my career, I think no one has confessed like this before. I’ve never met a suspect who confessed."<ref name="graft"/>
Assistant superintendent Mohd Rosly Mohd Saup testified that Sarbani denied accepting bribes from a Top Mark officer on 2 April.<ref name="graft"/>
Assistant superintendent Sheikh Niza Khairy Sheikh Mohamad said Sarbani confessed to him on 4 April to receiving "goodwill payments" and that Sarbani went to the MACC office two days later to change his statement.<ref name="graft"/>
;Forensics DSP Sharul Othman Mansor from the [[Bukit Aman]] Forensic Division said Sarbani fell 10 m to his death.<ref name="confided">{{cite news |title=Sarbaini confided in wife about claims, inquest told |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/7/5/nation/9030502&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=5 July 2011 |last=Goh |first=Lisa |accessdate=20 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708053145/http://www.thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2011%2F7%2F5%2Fnation%2F9030502&sec=nation |archivedate=8 July 2011 |df= }}</ref>
Forensic investigator DSP Sharul Othman Mansor told the court that Sarbani's death was neither suicide nor murder. He instead claimed that Sarbani tried to jump over the roof of the badminton court, but missed and fell to his death. Sharul added that there were no signs of a struggle and that an optical illusion made the roof appear near to the corner of the window.<ref name="rulesout">{{cite news |title=Investigator rules out suicide, homicide in Sarbaini death |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/investigator-rules-out-suicide-homicide-in-sarbaini-death/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=15 July 2011 |last=Chi |first=Melissa |accessdate=20 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718090816/http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/investigator-rules-out-suicide-homicide-in-sarbaini-death |archivedate=18 July 2011 |df= }}</ref>
Forensic pathologist Faridah Mohd Noor, who performed the autopsy, said the death was "accidental" based on "the injuries and circumstantial evidence."<ref>{{cite news|title=Forensic pathologist tells court Sarbaini fell accidentally to his death |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/forensic-pathologist-tells-court-sarbaini-fell-accidentally-to-his-death/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=2 August 2011 |first=Melissa |last=Chi |accessdate=3 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121015082058/http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/forensic-pathologist-tells-court-sarbaini-fell-accidentally-to-his-death/ |archivedate=15 October 2012 |df= }}</ref>
====Verdict==== On 26 September 2011, the coroner's court ruled Sarbani's death an accident. Coroner Aizatul Akmal Maharani said the fear of being arrested must have preyed heavily on Ahmad Sarbani’s mind so as to make him consider the window exit.<ref name="ruling">{{cite news |title=Sarbaini’s death ruled a misadventure |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/sarbainis-death-ruled-an-accident/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=26 September 2011 |first=Debra |last=Chong |accessdate=5 October 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110929132206/http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/sarbainis-death-ruled-an-accident |archivedate=29 September 2011 |df= }}</ref> Aizatul also remarked that the MACC officer tasked to look after Sarbani on 6 April had been "negligent."<ref name="ruling"/>
===''Malaysia Today'' allegations=== Prominent blogger [[Raja Petra Kamaruddin]] alleged on his ''[[Malaysia Today]]'' blog that Sarbani fell accidentally from the third-floor pantry window of the MACC building after being forced onto the ledge by a senior MACC officer.<ref name="expose">{{cite news |title=RPK Sarbaini expose prompts new police report |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/rpk-sarbaini-expose-prompts-new-police-report/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=20 July 2011 |last1=Yow |first1=Hong Chieh |author2=Syed Mu'az Syed Putra |accessdate=20 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722003428/http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/rpk-sarbaini-expose-prompts-new-police-report |archivedate=22 July 2011 |df= }}</ref> He claimed the MACC then went through great lengths, including "concoct[ing] the most plausible story" and wiping CCTV footage, to cover up the incident.<ref name="expose"/> Raja Petra also posted what appeared to be Sarbani's cautioned statement denying that he had ever received "additional profit" as a Customs officer.<ref>{{cite news |title=RPK claims proof Sarbaini did not take bribes |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/rpk-claims-proof-sarbaini-did-not-take-bribes/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=21 July 2011 |author=Shazwan Mustafa Kamal |accessdate=21 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110728090124/http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/rpk-claims-proof-sarbaini-did-not-take-bribes/ |archivedate=28 July 2011 |df= }}</ref>
Sarbani's family lawyer Awtar Singh said Raja Petra's allegations were "plausible [''ada asasnya'']."<ref>{{cite news |title=Kes Sarbaini: Peguam mahu buat laporan polis, dakwa tulisan Raja Petra ada asas |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/bahasa/article/kes-sarbaini-peguam-mahu-buat-laporan-polis-dakwa-tulisan-raja-petra-ada-asas/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=20 July 2011 |author=Syed Mu'az Syed Putra |accessdate=20 July 2011 |language=Malay |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722000341/http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/bahasa/article/kes-sarbaini-peguam-mahu-buat-laporan-polis-dakwa-tulisan-raja-petra-ada-asas/ |archivedate=22 July 2011 |df= }}</ref>
The MACC's lawyer called the allegations "nonsense."<ref>{{cite news |title=Shafee: Raja Petra’s Sarbaini claims nonsense |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/shafee-raja-petras-sarbaini-claims-nonsense/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=21 July 2011 |author=Syed Mu'az Syed Putra |accessdate=21 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722143559/http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/shafee-raja-petras-sarbaini-claims-nonsense/ |archivedate=22 July 2011 |df= }}</ref>

{{multiple issues| {{original research|date=June 2017}} {{refimprove|date=June 2017}} }}
'''Diploidization''' is the process of converting a polyploid genome back into a diploid one. [[Polyploid]]y is a product of whole genome duplication (WGD) and is followed by diploidization as a result of genome shock.<ref>Conant, G.C., J. A. Birchler, and J. C. Pires Dosage, duplication, and diploidization: clarifying the interplay of multiple models for duplicate gene evolution over time. Current Opinion in Plant Biology 2014, 19: 91–98</ref><ref>Feldman, Moshe and Avraham A. Levy Genome evolution in allopolyploid wheat—a revolutionary reprogramming followed by gradual changes. J. Genet. Genomics 2009, 36: 511–518</ref><ref> Hufton, A. L. and G. Panopoulou Polyploidy and genome restructuring: a variety of outcomes Current Opinion in Genetics & Development 2009, 19: 600–606</ref><ref>Wolfe, Kenneth H. Yesterday’s Polyploids and the Mystery of Diploidization Nat Rev Genet. 2001 May;2(5): 333-41.</ref> The plant kingdom has undergone multiple events of polyploidization followed by diploidization in both ancient and recent lineages.<ref>Conant, G.C., J. A. Birchler, and J. C. Pires Dosage, duplication, and diploidization: clarifying the interplay of multiple models for duplicate gene evolution over time. Current Opinion in Plant Biology 2014, 19: 91–98</ref> It has also been hypothesized that vertebrate genomes have gone through two rounds of [[paleopolyploidy]].<ref>Wolfe, Kenneth H. Yesterday's Polyploids and the Mystery of Diploidization Nat Rev Genet. 2001 May;2(5): 333–341.</ref> The mechanisms of diploidization are poorly understood but patterns of chromosomal loss and evolution of novel genes are observed in the process.
== Elimination of duplicated genes ==
Upon the formation of new polyploids, large sections of DNA are rapidly lost from one genome.<ref>Conant, G.C., J. A. Birchler, and J. C. Pires Dosage, duplication, and diploidization: clarifying the interplay of multiple models for duplicate gene evolution over time. Current Opinion in Plant Biology 2014, 19: 91–98</ref><ref> Feldman, Moshe and Avraham A. Levy Genome evolution in allopolyploid wheat—a revolutionary reprogramming followed by gradual changes. J. Genet. Genomics 2009, 36: 511–518</ref><ref> Hufton, A. L. and G. Panopoulou Polyploidy and genome restructuring: a variety of outcomes Current Opinion in Genetics & Development 2009, 19: 600–606</ref> The loss of DNA effectively achieves two purposes. First, the eliminated copy restores the normal gene dosage in the diploid organism.<ref>Conant, G.C., J. A. Birchler, and J. C. Pires Dosage, duplication, and diploidization: clarifying the interplay of multiple models for duplicate gene evolution over time. Current Opinion in Plant Biology 2014, 19: 91–98</ref> Second, the changes in chromosomal genetic structure increase the divergence of the homoeologous chromosomes (similar chromosomes from inter-species hybrid) and promotes [[homologous chromosome]] pairing.<ref>Feldman, Moshe and Avraham A. Levy Genome evolution in allopolyploid wheat—a revolutionary reprogramming followed by gradual changes. J. Genet. Genomics 2009, 36: 511–518</ref> Both are important in terms of adjusting to the induced genome shock.
== Evolution of genes to ensure correct chromosome pairing ==
There have been rare events in which genes that ensure proper chromosome pairing have evolved shortly after polyploidization. One such gene, Ph1, exists in hexaploid wheat.<ref>Martinez-Perez, E,, P. Shaw and G. Moore The Ph1 locus is needed to ensure specific somatic and meiotic centromere association Nature 411: 204-207</ref> These genes keep the two sets of genomes separately by either spatially separating them or giving them a unique chromatin identity to facilitate recognition from its homologous pair. This prevents the need of rapid gene loss to speed up homeologous chromosome diversification.
== Drive for diploidization == ; Coordinate inter-genomic gene expression : Duplicated genes often result in increased dosage of gene products. Doubled dosages are sometimes lethal to the organism thus the two genome copies must coordinate in a structured fashion to maintain normal nuclear activity.<ref>Conant, G.C., J. A. Birchler, and J. C. Pires Dosage, duplication, and diploidization: clarifying the interplay of multiple models for duplicate gene evolution over time. Current Opinion in Plant Biology 2014, 19: 91–98</ref> Many mechanisms of diploidization promote this coordination. ; Maintain intra-genomic chromosome pairing at meiosis : Chromosome pairing during meiosis is a significant challenge for polyploids. Homoeologous chromosomes with similar genetic content may pair with each other resulting in trivalent or tetravalent interactions.<ref>Hufton, A. L. and G. Panopoulou Polyploidy and genome restructuring: a variety of outcomes Current Opinion in Genetics & Development 2009, 19: 600–606</ref> The resolution of these structures results in chromosome breakage, rearrangement, and gamete infertility. Diploidization is often required to restore the cell’s ability to stably go through meiosis.<ref>Feldman, Moshe and Avraham A. Levy Genome evolution in allopolyploid wheat—a revolutionary reprogramming followed by gradual changes. J. Genet. Genomics 2009, 36: 511–518</ref> ; Reduce costs of maintaining large, duplicated genomes : Large genomes are costly to synthesize during replication and hard to maintain.<ref>Feldman, Moshe and Avraham A. Levy Genome evolution in allopolyploid wheat—a revolutionary reprogramming followed by gradual changes. J. Genet. Genomics 2009, 36: 511–518</ref> The loss of duplicated genes during diploidization effectively reduces the overall size of the genome.
== Revolutionary vs. evolutionary changes == Once a polyploid is made, either synthetically or naturally, the genome goes through a period of "genome shock". Genome shock can be defined as a stage in which the genome experiences massive reorganization and structural changes to deal with the external stress (X-ray damage, chromosome duplication, etc.) imposed upon the genome.<ref>McClintock, Barbara The significance of responses of the genome to challenge Science 1984, 226: 792–801</ref> Such changes are termed '''revolutionary changes''' and occur early in the process of diploidization.<ref>Feldman, Moshe and Avraham A. Levy Genome evolution in allopolyploid wheat—a revolutionary reprogramming followed by gradual changes. J. Genet. Genomics 2009, 36: 511–518</ref> Revolutionary changes ensure that the organism has a stable genome that can be passed to its progeny.
At the end of this process, certain duplicated genes may be preserved thus allowing evolution to shape them into novel functions. This is commonly termed as neofunctionalization. The mechanism of retaining duplicated genes is poorly understood. It has been hypothesized that dosage balance may play a key role in shaping the evolutionary fates of duplicated genes.<ref> Conant, G.C., J. A. Birchler, and J. C. Pires Dosage, duplication, and diploidization: clarifying the interplay of multiple models for duplicate gene evolution over time. Current Opinion in Plant Biology 2014, 19: 91–98</ref> Evolutionary changes refer to the long process of converting duplicated genes into diverse, functional gene derivatives.<ref>Feldman, Moshe and Avraham A. Levy Genome evolution in allopolyploid wheat—a revolutionary reprogramming followed by gradual changes. J. Genet. Genomics 2009, 36: 511–518</ref>
== Mechanisms == There are many ways in which a polyploid organism can convert back to a diploid status. This is usually achieved by elimination of duplicated genes. The main goals of diploidization are: (1) To ensure proper gene dosage; and (2) to maintain stable cellular division processes. It should be noted that this process does not need to occur rapidly for all chromosomes in one or few steps. In recent polyploid events, segments of the genome may still remain in a tetraploid status. In other words, diploidization is a long ongoing process that is shaped by both intrinsic and evolutionary drives.<ref>Wolfe, Kenneth H. Yesterday’s Polyploids and the Mystery of Diploidization Nat Rev Genet. 2001 May;2(5): 333–341.</ref>
=== Abnormal chromosome pairing === Normally, homologous chromosomes pair up in bivalents during meiosis and separate into different daughter cells. However, when multiple copies of similar chromosomes are present in the nucleus, homeologous chromosomes can also pair with homologous chromosomes resulting in the formation of trivalents or multivalents.<ref>Hufton, A. L. and G. Panopoulou Polyploidy and genome restructuring: a variety of outcomes Current Opinion in Genetics & Development 2009, 19: 600–606</ref> The formation of multivalents results in unequal division of the chromosomes and lead to daughter cells lacking one or few chromosomes.
=== Illegitimate recombination === When homeologous chromosomes pair up though bivalents or multivalents, illegitimate genetic crossovers may occur.<ref>Hufton, A. L. and G. Panopoulou Polyploidy and genome restructuring: a variety of outcomes Current Opinion in Genetics & Development 2009, 19: 600–606</ref> Since the chromosomes may differ in genetic structure and content, segments of the chromosome may be shuffled around resulting in massive gene loss. Additionally, [[illegitimate recombination]]s may also result in dicentric chromosomes lead to chromosome breakage during anaphase.<ref>Hufton, A. L. and G. Panopoulou Polyploidy and genome restructuring: a variety of outcomes Current Opinion in Genetics & Development 2009, 19: 600–606</ref> This further contributes to gene loss on duplicated chromosomes.
=== Relaxed selective pressure on duplicated genes === The duplicated copies of a gene are commonly non-essential to the plant’s ability to maintain normal growth and development. Therefore, one copy is generally free to mutate/be lost from the genome.<ref>Feldman, Moshe and Avraham A. Levy Genome evolution in allopolyploid wheat—a revolutionary reprogramming followed by gradual changes. J. Genet. Genomics 2009, 36: 511–518</ref><ref>Wolfe, Kenneth H. Yesterday’s Polyploids and the Mystery of Diploidization Nat Rev Genet. 2001 May;2(5): 333-41.</ref> This contributes to gene loss through the massive chromosome reorganization events during genome shock.
=== Neofunctionalization === As mentioned earlier, duplicated genes are under relaxed selective pressure. Thus it may also be subject to [[neofunctionalization]], the process in which a duplicated gene obtains a novel function.
== See also == * [[Polyploid]]y * [[Paleopolyploidy]] * [[Neofunctionalization]]
== References == {{reflist}}
