revision.text:
{{short description|American particle physicist who won the Nobel Prize in Physics }} {{other people|Henry Kendall}} {{Infobox scientist |name=Henry Way Kendall |image= Henry Kendall by Tom Frost.jpg |caption= Henry Kendall climbing in [[Yosemite Valley]]. Photo by [[Tom Frost]]. |birth_date = {{Birth date|1926|12|9|mf=y}} |birth_place = [[Boston, Massachusetts]] |death_date = {{Death date and age|1999|2|15|1926|12|9|mf=yes}} |death_place= [[Wakulla Springs State Park]], [[Florida]] |alma_mater = [[Amherst College]]
[[MIT]] |nationality = [[United States]] |field=[[Physics]] |prizes=[[Nobel Prize in Physics]] (1990) |work_institution = [[MIT]]
[[Stanford University]] |doctoral_advisor = [[Martin Deutsch]] |spouse= |children= |website= |footnotes= }} '''Henry Way Kendall''' (December 9, 1926 – February 15, 1999){{cite web |author=Kendall, Henry W |url=http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/physics/laureates/1990/kendall-autobio.html |title=Autobiography |publisher=Nobelprize.org |accessdate=2011-01-08}} was an American particle physicist who won the [[Nobel Prize in Physics]] in 1990 jointly with [[Jerome Isaac Friedman]] and [[Richard E. Taylor]] "for their pioneering investigations concerning deep inelastic scattering of [[electron]]s on [[proton]]s and bound [[neutron]]s, which have been of essential importance for the development of the [[quark model]] in particle physics."{{cite web |url=http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/physics/laureates/1990/ |title=Nobel prize citation |publisher=Nobelprize.org |accessdate=2011-01-08}} ==Biography== Kendall was born in [[Boston]] to Evelyn Way and [[Henry P. Kendall]], an industrialist. Kendall grew up in [[Sharon, Massachusetts]] and attended [[Deerfield Academy]].{{cite web |url=http://web.mit.edu/newsoffice/1999/kendall.html |title=MIT Nobelist Henry Kendall dies at 72 while scuba diving in Florida lake |author=Sales, Robert J |date=1999-02-16 |publisher=MIT News Office |accessdate=2011-01-08}} He enrolled in the [[United States Merchant Marine Academy|U. S. Merchant Marine Academy]] in 1945, and served on a troop transport on the North Atlantic in the winter of 1945 - 1946. In 1946, he enrolled at [[Amherst College]] where he majored in mathematics, graduating in 1950. While at Amherst, he operated a [[Underwater diving|diving]] and [[marine salvage]] company during two summers. He co-authored two books, one on shallow water diving and the other on [[underwater photography]]. He did graduate research at the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]], involving an experimental study of [[positronium]], and he obtained his PhD in 1955. He then spent the next two years as a postdoctoral fellow at [[Brookhaven National Laboratory]]. He then spent five years in [[Robert Hofstadter]]'s research group at [[Stanford University]] in the late 50's and early 60's, where he worked with [[Jerome Isaac Friedman|Jerome Friedman]] and [[Richard E. Taylor|Richard Taylor]], studying the structure of [[proton]]s and [[neutron]]s, using the university's 300 feet long [[Linear particle accelerator|linear electron accelerator]]. He developed a close working relationship with [[Wolfgang K. H. Panofsky]] at Stanford. He then returned to the [[MIT Physics Department]], where he remained for the rest of his life. In the late 60's and early '70s, Kendall worked in collaboration with researchers at the [[Stanford Linear Accelerator Center]] (SLAC) including Friedman and Taylor. These experiments involved scattering high-energy beams of [[electron]]s from [[proton]]s and [[deuteron]]s and heavier [[atomic nucleus|nuclei]]. At lower energies, it had already been found that the electrons would only be scattered through low angles, consistent with the idea that the [[nucleon]]s had no internal structure. However, the SLAC-MIT experiments showed that higher energy electrons could be scattered through much higher angles, with the loss of some energy. These deep inelastic scattering results provided the first experimental evidence that the protons and neutrons were made up of point-like particles, later identified to be the [[Up quark|up]] and [[Down quark|down]] [[quark]]s that had previously been proposed on theoretical grounds.{{cite news |author1=Dye, Lee |author2=Maugh II, Thomas H |date=1990-10-18 |title=Four U.S.-Based Scientists Share Nobel Prizes |publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]] |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1990-10-18/news/mn-3365_1_nobel-prize |accessdate=2011-01-08}} The experiments also provided the first evidence for the existence of [[gluon]]s. Kendall was not only a very accomplished physicist, but also a very skilled mountaineer and photographer. He did extensive rock climbing in [[Yosemite Valley]], followed by expeditions to the [[Andes]], [[Himalaya]] and [[Antarctica]], photographing his experiences with large format cameras. He was elected a Fellow of the [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] in 1982.{{cite web|title=Book of Members, 1780-2010: Chapter K|url=http://www.amacad.org/publications/BookofMembers/ChapterK.pdf|publisher=American Academy of Arts and Sciences|accessdate=14 April 2011}} On April 7, 2012, the [[American Alpine Club]] inducted Kendall into its Hall of Mountaineering Excellence at an award ceremony in [[Golden, Colorado]].{{cite news |last=Osius |first=Alison |title=Beautiful minds: Blum, Reichardt, Kendall, Molenaar in Mountaineering Hall of Fame |newspaper=Rock and Ice |location= |pages= |language= |publisher= |date=April 11, 2012 |url=http://www.rockandice.com/news/1889-beautiful-minds-blum-reichardt-kendall-molenaar-inducted-into-mountaineering-hall-of-fame |accessdate=April 11, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120412192703/http://www.rockandice.com/news/1889-beautiful-minds-blum-reichardt-kendall-molenaar-inducted-into-mountaineering-hall-of-fame |archivedate=April 12, 2012 |df= }} ==Service activities== Kendall was one of the founding members of the [[Union of Concerned Scientists]] (UCS) in 1969. He served as Chairman of the UCS from 1974 until his death in 1999.{{cite news |author=Oliver, Myrna |date=1999-02-17 |title=Henry Kendall; Nobel Prize-Winning Nuclear Scientist |publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]] |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1999/feb/17/news/mn-8938 |accessdate=2011-01-08}} His public policy interests included avoiding [[Nuclear warfare|nuclear war]], the [[Strategic Defense Initiative]], the [[B-2 Spirit|B2 bomber]], [[Nuclear safety|nuclear reactor safety]] and [[global warming]]. He was also a member of the [[JASON Defense Advisory Group]].{{cite news|author1=Berkeley Scientists |author2=Engineers for Social |author3=Political Action |year=1972 |url=http://ist-socrates.berkeley.edu/~schwrtz/SftP/Jason.html |title=The Story of Jason - The Elite Group Of Academic Scientists Who, As Technical Consultants To The Pentagon, Have Developed The Latest Weapon Against Peoples' Liberation Struggles: "Automated Warfare". |accessdate=2011-01-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110607181553/http://ist-socrates.berkeley.edu/~schwrtz/SftP/Jason.html |archivedate=2011-06-07 |df= }} ==Death== Kendall died while diving the cave at the [[Edward Ball Wakulla Springs State Park]], Florida as a part of the Wakulla 2 Project.{{cite journal |author=Kakuk, Brian J |title=The Wakulla 2 Project: Cutting Edge Diving Technology for Science and Exploration. |journal=In: Hamilton RW, Pence DF, Kesling DE, eds. Assessment and Feasibility of Technical Diving Operations for Scientific Exploration. |publisher=[[American Academy of Underwater Sciences]] |year=1999 |url=http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/9002 |accessdate=2011-01-08}} He by-passed two pre-dive [[checklist]]s for his [[Cis-Lunar]] MK-5P Mixed Gas [[rebreather]] and entered the spring basin without his [[Buddy diving|dive buddy]] from the [[National Geographic Society]].{{cite news |author=Associated Press |date=1999-02-18 |title=Safety Lapse Suspected in Scientist's Diving Death |publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]] |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1999/feb/18/news/mn-9174 |accessdate=2011-01-08}} Kendall missed turning on the [[oxygen]] supply to his rebreather and [[Unconsciousness|lost consciousness]] and drowned. The [[autopsy]] revealed a physiological issue that led to his disregarding the protocols. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Henry Kendall}} {{Wikiquote}} *[http://www.aip.org/history/ohilist/4704.html Oral History interview transcript with Henry Way Kendall 25 and 26 November 1986, American Institute of Physics, Niels Bohr Library and Archives] *[http://www.nasonline.org/publications/biographical-memoirs/memoir-pdfs/kendall-henry.pdf National Academy of Sciences Biographical Memoir] {{Nobel Prize in Physics Laureates 1976–2000}} {{1990 Nobel Prize winners}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kendall, Henry Way}} [[Category:1926 births]] [[Category:1999 deaths]] [[Category:American Nobel laureates]] [[Category:American mountain climbers]] [[Category:American rock climbers]] [[Category:American underwater divers]] [[Category:Amherst College alumni]] [[Category:Deerfield Academy alumni]] [[Category:Experimental physicists]] [[Category:Massachusetts Institute of Technology alumni]] [[Category:Nobel laureates in Physics]] [[Category:Underwater diving deaths]] [[Category:Underwater photographers]] [[Category:United States Merchant Marine Academy alumni]] [[Category:Fellows of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] [[Category:Winners of the Panofsky Prize]] [[Category:Members of JASON]]

{{Orphan|date=April 2018}} {{infobox artefact |name = Heslington Brain |image = [[File:Heslington Brain.jpg|250px]] |image_caption = Mass "A" of the Heslington Brain |material = [[Human brain]] |size = (Mass "A") {{convert|70|mm|in}} ×
{{convert|60|mm|in}} ×
{{convert|30|mm|in}} |created = 673–482 BC |discovered = By [[York Archaeological Trust]] in August 2008 |place = [[Heslington]], [[Yorkshire]] |location = }} The '''Heslington Brain''' is a 2,600-year-old [[human brain]] found inside a skull buried in a pit in [[Heslington]], [[Yorkshire]], in [[England]], in 2008. It is the oldest preserved brain ever found in [[Eurasia]], and is believed to be the best-preserved ancient brain in the world. The skull was discovered during an archaeological dig commissioned by the [[University of York]] on the site of its new campus on the outskirts of the city of [[York]]. The area was found to have been the site of well-developed permanent habitation between 2,000–3,000 years before the present day. A number of possibly ritualistic objects were found to have been deposited in several pits, including the skull, which had belonged to a man probably in his 30s. He had been hanged before being decapitated with a knife and his skull appears to have been buried immediately. The rest of the body was missing. Although it is not known why he was killed, it is possible that it may have been a human sacrifice or ritual murder. The brain was found while the skull was being cleaned. It had survived despite the rest of the tissue on the skull having disappeared long ago. After being extracted at [[York Hospital]], the brain was subjected to a range of medical and forensic examinations which found that it was remarkably intact, though it had shrunk to only about 20% of its original size. It showed few signs of decay, though most of its original material had been replaced by an as yet unidentified organic compound, due to chemical changes during burial. According to the archaeologists and scientists who have examined it, the brain has a "resilient, tofu-like texture". It is not clear why the Heslington brain survived, although the presence of a wet, anoxic environment underground seems to have been an essential factor, and research is still ongoing to shed light on how the local soil conditions may have contributed to its preservation. ==Discovery== The site where the brain was discovered is about {{convert|3|km|mi}} south-east of York city centre on the eastern edge of Heslington village. It is situated partly on the ridge of an ancient glacial [[moraine]] and partly in the basin of the [[Vale of York]].{{cite web|url=http://www.yorkarchaeology.co.uk/about/yat-2008-web.pdf |title=37th Annual Report 2008–2009 |publisher=York Archaeological Trust |year=2009 |accessdate=21 August 2012 }}{{dead link|date=April 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Until the construction of the [[University of York#Heslington East campus|Heslington East campus]] of the University of York in 2009, the site was used as agricultural land. {{Location map | England | width = 180 | lat_deg = 53.948617 | lon_deg = -1.032524 | label = Heslington | position = left | caption = Heslington, England }} Survey and excavation work, commissioned by the university, was carried out on the site from 2003. It culminated in a full-scale excavation carried out in 2007–08 by [[York Archaeological Trust]] in an area of just over {{convert|8|ha|acre}}. The archaeologists found that the landscape had been inhabited and farmed for thousands of years. The remains of prehistoric fields, buildings and trackways were discovered, dating from the [[Bronze Age Britain|Bronze Age]] through to the middle of the [[Iron Age Britain|Iron Age]],{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1016/j.jas.2011.02.030| title = Exceptional preservation of a prehistoric human brain from Heslington, Yorkshire, UK | journal = Journal of Archaeological Science | volume = 38 | year = 2011 | last1 = o’Connor | first1 = S. | last2 = Ali | first2 = E. | last3 = Al-Sabah | first3 = S. | last4 = Anwar | first4 = D. | last5 = Bergström | first5 = E. | last6 = Brown | first6 = K. A. | last7 = Buckberry | first7 = J. | last8 = Buckley | first8 = S. | last9 = Collins | first9 = M. | last10 = Denton | first10 = J. | last11 = Dorling | first11 = K. M. | last12 = Dowle | first12 = A. | last13 = Duffey | first13 = P. | last14 = Edwards | first14 = H. G. M. | last15 = Faria | first15 = E. C. | last16 = Gardner | first16 = P. | last17 = Gledhill | first17 = A. | last18 = Heaton | first18 = K. | last19 = Heron | first19 = C. | last20 = Janaway | first20 = R. | last21 = Keely | first21 = B. J. | last22 = King | first22 = D. | last23 = Masinton | first23 = A. | last24 = Penkman | first24 = K. | last25 = Petzold | first25 = A. | last26 = Pickering | first26 = M. D. | last27 = Rumsby | first27 = M. | last28 = Schutkowski | first28 = H. | last29 = Shackleton | first29 = K. A. | last30 = Thomas | first30 = J. | issue = 7 | pages = 1641 }}{{cite news|url=http://www.nouse.co.uk/2008/12/13/%E2%80%98oldest-human-brain%E2%80%99-unearthed-at-heslington-east/|title=‘Oldest human brain’ unearthed at Heslington East|work=Nouse|date=13 December 2008|accessdate=20 August 2012}} with traces of earlier activity as far back as the [[Mesolithic]] and [[Neolithic]] periods. During the Iron Age, the area appears to have been the site of a permanent settlement. The excavators found a number of circular features, which they interpreted as the remains of [[Roundhouse (dwelling)|roundhouses]]. The inhabitants seem to have relocated during the Roman period to a site further up the ridge, leaving the area of the Iron Age settlement to revert to fields. Around a dozen pits were found on the site and possibly ritualistic objects were found in a number of them. Some pits had been pierced with a single stake, while a number of pits included "burned" cobbles of a local type of stone. The headless body of a [[red deer]] had been deposited in a drainage channel and a red deer antler was found in an Iron Age ditch. In one waterlogged pit, a human skull – with the jawbone and the first two vertebrae still attached – was discovered in August 2008, lying face-down at the bottom of the pit. The find was seen as unusual but its true importance was not discovered until after it had been transported, within a block of soil, to the Finds Laboratory of the York Archaeological Trust. As Finds officer Rachel Cubitt was cleaning it, she noticed that something was loose inside the skull. She peered through its base and saw that it contained a "yellow substance". She said later that it "jogged my memory of a university lecture on the rare survival of ancient brain tissue ... we gave the skull special conservation treatment as a result and sought expert medical opinion." The skull and its contents were put into cold storage and were examined using a variety of medical and autopsy techniques. ==Analysis== [[File:Archaeology at Heslington East.jpg|right|280px|thumb|The excavation at Heslington East, May 2008.]] The skull was found to be that of a man aged between 26–45 years old at the time of death, likely in his mid-30s. Radiocarbon dating found that the man had died some time between the 7th century BCE and 5th century BCE (673–482 BCE). He belonged to the [[mtDNA haplogroup|Mitochondrial DNA haplogroup]] [[haplogroup J (mtDNA)|J1d]], which had not previously been seen in Britain, in either living or dead individuals. J1d has been identified previously in only a few people from [[Tuscany]] and the [[Middle East]]; it may have been more widely present in Britain in the past, and lost through [[genetic drift]]. He had died from traumatic [[spondylolisthesis]] – a complete fracture of his spine that is usually associated with death by [[hanging]]. Shortly after death his head and upper vertebrae had been severed from his body, almost surgically, using a thin-bladed knife. Although there is evidence from other sites of "[[Human trophy collecting|trophy head]]s" in Iron Age societies, it appears that the head was immediately deposited in the pit and buried in fine-grained wet sediment. The reason for the killing is unclear. The archaeological context suggests that the man may have been killed for a ritual or [[human sacrifice|sacrificial]] purposes.{{cite news|url=http://www.yorkpress.co.uk/features/features/8487242.Was_death_of_Iron_Age_man_a_ritual_killing_/|title=Was death of Iron Age man at Heslington East a ritual killing?|last=Lewis|first=Simon|work=The Press|location=York|date=1 November 2010|accessdate=20 August 2012}} [[X-ray computed tomography|CT scanning]] was carried out at [[York Hospital]], where the skull was opened and the contents were removed and forensically examined. The interior of the skull was found to contain several large fragments of brain mixed with sediment. The brain had shrunk to about 20% of its original size, but many anatomical features were still readily identifiable. It was remarkably well-preserved and had few signs of decay other than the presence of a few bacterial spores. One of the fragments clearly showed the neural folds of a cerebral lobe. Discovery of such a well-preserved brain is all the more remarkable, considering the fragility of all human brains following death. Even when placed in a chilled environment in a mortuary, brains quickly dissolve into liquid.{{cite news|url=http://www.medicaldaily.com/news/20120817/11577/brain-archeology-well-preserved-heslington-england.htm |title=2,600-Year-Old Brain Found in England, in Remarkably Fresh Condition |last=Brice |first=Makini |work=Medical Daily |date=17 August 2012 |accessdate=20 August 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120820030038/http://www.medicaldaily.com/news/20120817/11577/brain-archeology-well-preserved-heslington-england.htm |archivedate=20 August 2012 |df= }} The high fat content of the brain means that it is usually the first major organ to deteriorate.{{cite news|url=http://www.livescience.com/13410-prehistoric-brain-skull-preservation-decapitated-iron-age.html|title=2,500-Year-Old Preserved Human Brain Discovered|last=Parry|first=Wynne|publisher=LiveScience|date=25 March 2011|accessdate=20 August 2012}} The brains of the crew of the [[American Civil War]] submarine ''[[HL Hunley (submarine)|H. L. Hunley]]'' were recovered along with their skeletonised bodies in 2000, and brains were found in the wreck of the English warship ''[[Mary Rose]]'', but archaeologists found that they "liquefied within a matter of minutes" unless preserved immediately in [[formalin]]. Brains found in terrestrial environments have tended to be better preserved, as the surviving material tends to have a higher proportion of hydrophobic (water-repellent) matter than in a fresh brain. There appear to be a number of routes by which brains have been preserved, though a common factor appears to be the existence of a wet, anoxic environment. The presence of such an environment is thought to have been responsible for a similar but less complete preservation of brain matter discovered in the 1990s during the construction of a new magistrates' court in [[Kingston upon Hull|Hull]]. The preservation of the brain has been attributed to several factors. First, the waterlogged, [[wiktionary:anoxic|anoxic]] soil in which the head was buried, even though only the brain, and not the rest of the tissue, survived burial. Only scanty traces of other tissue remain on the rest of the skull. Second, the brain had undergone unusual chemical changes as a result of being severed and the conditions under which it was buried. In contrast to other brains found, no [[adipocere]] – a fatty compound formed through the process of decay – was detected in the Heslington brain, probably because the head was severed from the body before the brain had started to decay. There had also been a major decrease in the amount of [[protein]]s and [[lipid]]s and their replacement by fatty acids and other substances produced as degradation products. Much of the original substance of the brain has been replaced by a high molecular weight, long-chain, hydrocarbon material that is as yet unidentified. According to the archaeologists who have examined it, the brain is "odourless", with a "smooth surface" and a "resilient, [[tofu]]-like texture." Thirdly, the human body tends to decay from the inside out, consumed by a post-mortem swarm of bacteria from the gut which spread around the body via blood from the [[alimentary tract]]. In this particular case, the head was severed from the alimentary tract and drained of blood, so the intestinal bacteria did not have an opportunity to contaminate it. The precise mechanism by which the Heslington brain was preserved is unclear, however; in a bid to shed light on this question, researchers buried a number of pigs' heads in and around the campus to see what happened to them{{update-inline|date=November 2018}}.{{cite news|url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2011/04/110406-oldest-brain-britain-archaeology-science-world/|title=Ancient "Pickled" Brain Mystery Explained?|publisher=National Geographic News|last=Owen|first=James|date=6 April 2011|accessdate=20 August 2012}} ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.academia.dk/BiologiskAntropologi/Tafonomi/PDF/Brains/Britains_Oldest_Brain.pdf Exceptional preservation of a prehistoric human brain from Heslington, Yorkshire, UK]. O'Connor et al. ''Journal of Archaeological Science'' '''38''' (7): 1641 * [https://www.escholar.manchester.ac.uk/api/datastream?publicationPid=uk-ac-man-scw:106845&datastreamId=FULL-TEXT.PDF Analysis of the Bronze Age Heslington Brain by FTIR Imaging and Hierarchical Cluster Analysis]. Correia Faria E., Dorling K.M., O’Connor S. and Gardner P. In: SPEC2010 "Shedding Light on Disease: Optical Diagnosis for the new Millenium" ; 26 Jun 2010-01 Jul 2010; University of Manchester. 2010. [[Category:2008 archaeological discoveries]] [[Category:Archaeology of England]] [[Category:Human remains (archaeological)]] [[Category:Iron Age Britain]] [[Category:Individual human heads, skulls and brains]] [[Category:Bog bodies]]

revision.comment: Robot - Moving category Palliative medicine to [[:Category:Palliative care]] per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2017 November 15]].
revision.text:
'''Interventionism''', when discussing the practice of [[medicine]], is generally a derogatory term used by critics of a [[medical model]] in which patients are viewed as passive recipients receiving external treatments provided by the physician that have the effect of prolonging life, or at least of providing a subjective sense of doing everything possible.
Interventionism is commonly encouraged by [[terminally ill]] patients and their family members when they are emotionally unprepared to acknowledge that the patient is going to die.<ref name=Gawande>{{vcite journal | url = http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2010/08/02/100802fa_fact_gawande?currentPage=all | title = Letting Go: What should medicine do when it can’t save your life? | author = Gawande, Atul | journal = The New Yorker | date = 2 August 2010 }}</ref> Most healthcare providers are uncomfortable telling people that further cure-oriented or life-extending treatment is [[futile medical care]], and patients and families are frequently angry with the provider or feel rejected by the provider when they are given accurate, but negative, information about the patient's prospects.<ref name=Gawande /> In nearly all cases, "something" can be done for the patient, and families often reward and encourage a provider who proposes a string of useless and often directly harmful treatments; as a result, it is easier for providers to substitute worthless and expensive activity than to honestly admit that nothing will extend the patient's life.<ref name=Gawande />
Interventionism is related to [[optimism bias]]. This is the belief that the patient will beat the odds, no matter how unlikely this might be. Optimism bias encourages patients to undertake treatments that have only tiny chances of success, in the erroneous and irrational belief that they will be part of the tiny minority that is successful, rather than part of the vast majority who are not.
With terminally ill patients, the attitude of interventionism prevents providers and patients from taking full advantage of [[palliative care]] options. The primary focus for palliative care is improving the patient's immediate, daily life through better management of medications, practical assistance, planning for possible complications, and other services.<ref name=Gawande /> Patients who use palliative care services usually live longer, have fewer disruptive medical crises, incur fewer medical expenses, and have significantly higher quality of life.
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Interventionism (Medicine)}} <!-- Categories --> [[Category:Medical aspects of death]] [[Category:Palliative care]] [[Category:Medical treatments]]

{{otheruses|Latifi (disambiguation)}} '''Latifî''' (1491–1582), or '''Kastamonulu Latifî Çelebi''', was an [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] poet and bibliographer. Born in [[Kastamonu]], in northern [[Anatolia]], he became famous for his ''[[tezkire]]'' ''Tezkiretü'ş-Şuara'' (Memoirs of the Poets), the second Ottoman collection of bibliographical data on poets and poetry in overall. Latifî was born Abdüllatif Hatibzâde[http://www.kastamonur.com/test/kastamonulu-bir-tezkireci-ve-divan-airi-latifi-mehmet-tuerkan/ Mehmet Turkan, KASTAMONU’LU BİR TEZKİRECİ VE DİVAN ŞAİRİ (in Turkish)] into a notable family in Kastamonu and was educated there. He worked as accountant and [[katib]] (secretary) in various [[vakif]]s (pious foundation), including [[Belgrade]], [[Constantinople]], [[Rhodes]], and [[Egypt]].{{citation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UU8iCY0OZmcC&pg=PA261&dq=Sehi+Bey&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CDgQ6AEwAmoVChMImO73mZjQyAIVCmk-Ch1ZFQ8X#v=onepage&q=Sehi%20Bey&f=false|title=The A to Z of the Ottoman Empire| pages=161-162|author=Selcuk Aksin Somel|location=London|publisher=Scarecrow Press|year=2010|isbn=9780810875791}}
His major work was ''Tezkiretü'ş-Şuara'' (Memoirs of the Poets), which was the second ''tezkire'' in chronological order after that of [[Sehi Bey]]. It is also the one with most extent copies, 91 in total.{{citation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7xMDvp2ypVcC&pg=PA17&dq=tezkire&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CDEQ6AEwA2oVChMI-MvgrqzIyAIViBs-Ch15Rg9Z#v=onepage&q=tezkire&f=false|author=Ralf Elger, Yavuz Köse|page=17| title=Many ways of speaking about the self : Middle Eastern ego-documents in Arabic, Persian, and Turkish (14th-20th century)|publisher=Harrassowitz| location=Wiesbaden |year=2010|isbn=9783447062503 }} The ''tezkire'' was organized in three sections with an introduction. It narrated the life and work of around 300 poets of the period from the reign of [[Murad II]] (reigned between 1421-1451) until 1543, and was finished and presented it to Sultan [[Suleiman the Magnificent]] in 1546.{{citation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MSxkAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA7&dq=Sehi+Bey&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CEcQ6AEwBWoVChMImO73mZjQyAIVCmk-Ch1ZFQ8X#v=onepage&q=Sehi%20Bey&f=false| title=A History of Ottoman Poetry|author=Elias John Wilkinson Gibb|volume=3|page=7|oclc=2110073| editor=Edward Browne|location=London| year=1904| publisher=Luzac & Co}} The Sultan was so pleased that he appointed Latifi as secretary at the "[[Abu Ayyub al-Ansari|Ayyub al-Ansari]]" complex endowment. According to [[Aşık Çelebi]]'s work ''Senses of Poets'' (Meşairü'ş-Şuara), the poet wrote it mostly during the era of Suleiman, but presented it to [[Murad III]] in 1574 after making minor changes to the introduction.{{citation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ot2HQMwah_gC&pg=PA77&dq=latifi+%C3%87elebi&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CDoQ6AEwBWoVChMIosaAwv_ZyAIVxFs-Ch0zswey#v=onepage&q=latifi%20%C3%87elebi&f=false|pages=77,79|author=Pinar Emiralioglu| title=Geographical Knowledge and Imperial Culture in the Early Modern Ottoman Empire|publisher=Ashgate|year=2004|series= Transculturalisms, 1400-1700|isbn=9781472415332 |oclc=853113732}}
Another important work of him was ''Evsaf-ı İstanbul'' (Qualities of Istanbul) written in 1525. It gives a historical overview on the city of Istanbul, intertwined with geographical data, and information on the city's neighborhoods, architecture, and social life. Latifi spent the last years of his life in Istanbul. He died by drowning when the ship he was traveling to [[Yemen]] sank in the [[Red Sea]]. == See also == *[[Ahdi of Baghdad]] *[[Diwan (poetry)|Diwan poetry]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Turkish literature |state=collapsed}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Latifi}} [[Category:Divan poets of the Ottoman Empire]] [[Category:People from Kastamonu]] [[Category:1491 births]] [[Category:1582 deaths]] [[Category:15th-century people of the Ottoman Empire]] [[Category:16th-century poets of the Ottoman Empire]] [[Category:Deaths due to shipwreck]] [[Category:Civil servants of the Ottoman Empire]] [[Category:Turkish-language poets]]

page.title: List of Mayflower passengers who died in the winter of 1620–21

revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/170.211.79.92|170.211.79.92]] ([[User talk:170.211.79.92|talk]]) to last revision by Smasongarrison. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:List of ''Mayflower'' passengers who died in the winter of 1620–21}} Forty-five of the 102 '''''Mayflower''''' '''passengers died in the winter of 1620–21''', and the ''Mayflower'' colonists suffered greatly during their first winter in the New World from lack of shelter, scurvy, and general conditions on board ship.<ref name="rothbard1975">{{cite book |last=Rothbard |first=Murray Rothbard |title=Conceived in Liberty |year=1975 |volume=1 |chapter="The Founding of Plymouth Colony" |publisher=Arlington House Publishers }}</ref> They were buried on [[Cole's Hill]].<ref>''[http://www.pilgrimhall.org/1stthnks.htm 1998, Pilgrim Hall Museum, accessed August 29, 2006''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081216143248/http://www.pilgrimhall.org/1stthnks.htm |date=December 16, 2008 }}''/</ref>
People marked * below were probably buried in unmarked graves in the Coles Hill Burial Ground in Plymouth, Massachusetts. In 1921, some of the remains of persons buried on that hill were collected into the sarcophagus that is the Pilgrim Memorial Tomb on Cole's Hill in Plymouth. Many of the people listed here are named on the Tomb.<ref>http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=cr&CRid=2272036</ref>
==Men== *John Allerton* *Richard Britteridge*, December 21 *[[William Butten]]/Button, November 6/16 on board ''Mayflower''. Buried either at sea or later possibly ashore. Memorial in [[Provincetown, Massachusetts|Provincetown]]. (a young man)<ref>Charles Edward Banks. ''The English Ancestry and Homes of the Pilgrim Fathers" (Grafton Press N.Y. 1929) p. 42</ref> *Robert Carter*, after February 21 *[[James Chilton]]*, 8/18 on board ''[[Mayflower]]'' in Cape Cod Harbor. Most likely buried ashore. Memorial in Provincetown. Signor of the [[Mayflower Compact]]. *Richard Clarke* *[[John Crackstone|John Crackstone Sr.]]* *Thomas English* hired to master a shallop but died in the winter. *[[Moses Fletcher]]* *[[Edward Fuller (Mayflower)|Edward Fuller]]* *[[John Goodman (Pilgrim)|John Goodman]]*, there are conflicting reports regarding Goodman's death, with records of his name appearing in 1623 *William Holbeck* *John Langmore* *Edmund Margesson* *[[Christopher Martin (Mayflower passenger)|Christopher Martin]]*, January 8 * [[William Mullins]]*' February 21 *[[Degory Priest]]*, January 1 *John Rigsdale* *[[Thomas Rogers (Mayflower passenger)|Thomas Rogers]]* *Elias Story* *Edward Thompson, December 4/14 on board ''Mayflower'' in Cape Cod Harbor. Most likely buried ashore. Memorial in Provincetown. *[[Edward Tilley]]* *[[John Tilley (Mayflower passenger)|John Tilley]]* *[[Thomas Tinker]]* *[[John Turner (Mayflower passenger)|John Turner]]* *[[William White (Mayflower passenger)|William White]]*, February 21, 1621. *Roger Wilder* *[[Thomas Williams (Mayflower)|Thomas Williams]]*
==Women== *[[Isaac Allerton|Mary (Norris) Allerton]]*, of Newbury, England, wife of Isaac Allerton, died February 25, 1621, reportedly in childbirth, baby was stillborn. Remains later interred in Pilgrim Memorial Tomb, Cole's Hill, Plymouth, Massachusetts<ref name= "Mintz">Mintz, S. (2003). Childbirth in Early America,</ref><ref>Ruth Wilder Sherman, CG, [[FASG]], and Robert Moody Sherman, CG, [[FASG]], ''Mayflower'' Families Through Five Generations, Family of Isaac Allerton, Vol. 13 3rd edition (Pub. by General Society of Mayflower Descendants 2006) p. 5.</ref> *Dorothy (May) Bradford, December 7/17 drowned while on board ''Mayflower'' in Cape Cod Harbor. Her body was never recovered, Memorial in Provincetown. *Margaret Chilton* (first name was unknown)(Mrs. James Chilton) *Sarah Eaton* *Mrs. Edward Fuller* *Mary (Prower) Martin*, January 11 *Alice Mullins*, February 22–28 *Alice Rigsdale* *Agnes (Cooper) Tilley* *Joan (Hurst) Tilley* *Mrs. Thomas Tinker* *Elizabeth (Barker) Winslow*, March 24. Remains later interred in Pilgrim Memorial Tomb, Cole's Hill, Plymouth, Massachusetts.<ref>New England Historical Genealogical Society http://www.americanancestors.org/pilgrim-families-edward-winslow/</ref> *Rose Standish* January 29 - grave unknown
==Children== [[File:St James Memorial Plaque.JPG|thumb|right|file size: 136 KB, MIME type: image/jpeg|''Mayflower'' plaque in St. James Church in Shipton, Shropshire commemorating the More children baptism. courtesy of Phil Revell]]
*[[More children|Elinor (Ellen) More]], age 8 died in Plymouth January 1621. She died of the disease pneumonia. Name is on the Pilgrim Memorial Tomb, Cole's Hill, Plymouth, Massachusetts. *[[More children|Jasper More]], age 7, died on board the ''Mayflower'' on December 6, 1620. Buried ashore in the Provincetown area. *[[More children|Mary More]], age 4 died in the winter of 1620. Location of her remains unknown. Name is represented on the Pilgrim Memorial Tomb, Plymouth, Massachusetts. *Joseph Mullins*, age 14, February 22–28 *Solomon Prower*, age ca. 14-17, December 24 *the son of Thomas Tinker* *both sons of John Turner*
==Statistics by month==
===Winter=== According to Bradford's Register,<ref name="Bradford">The Plymouth Colony Archive Project MAYFLOWER PASSENGER DEATHS, 1620-1621 [http://etext.virginia.edu/users/deetz/Plymouth/Maydeaths.html], 2000, Patricia Scott Deetz and James Deetz, accessed August 29, 2006</ref> a contemporary source
*November, 1 *December, 6 *January, 8, 11 *February, 17 *March, 13
===Spring=== *April uncertain, between 1 and 5<ref name="Will">The death dates of Alice Mullins* and her son Joseph* are not clear, perhaps after April 5 when the ''Mayflower'' left with her husband William's will naming them as heirs but with no attachment concerning their deaths.</ref> (including Governor [[John Carver (Mayflower passenger)|John Carver]], not in above list) *May or June, at least 1 (Mrs. Katherine (White) Carver*, not in above list)
Four deaths occurred in months unknown before the first Thanksgiving bringing the total deaths to 51.
==See also==
*[[List of Mayflower passengers who died at sea November/December 1620]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==Notes== *List of deaths and dates as shown in ''Chronological History of New England'' by [[Thomas Prince]] in 1737, from the register of deaths compiled by [[William Bradford (1590-1657)|William Bradford]], which was lost during the [[American Revolutionary War|Revolutionary War]]. Can be seen at [http://etext.virginia.edu/users/deetz/Plymouth/Maydeaths.html ''Mayflower'' passenger deaths, 1620-1621]
==Further reading== * Glenn Alan Cheney. ''Thanksgiving: The Pilgrims' First Year in America,'' (New London: New London Librarium, 2007) {{ISBN|978-0-9798039-0-1}} * Nathaniel Philbrick, Nathaniel. ''Mayflower: A Story of Courage, Community, and War,'' (New York: Viking, 2006) {{ISBN|0-670-03760-5}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110718054648/http://www.mayflowerhistory.com/History/women.php Women on the ''Mayflower''], MayflowerHistory.com, accessed August 29, 2006.
{{Mayflower passengers and related topics}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Mayflower Passengers Who Died In The Winter Of 1620-1621}} [[Category:Mayflower passengers|*Died in the winter of 1620-1621]] [[Category:Death in the United States-related lists]]
[[hu:Mayflower]]

page.title: List of NFL players with chronic traumatic encephalopathy

revision.comment: not sure what that is supposed to mean
revision.text:
A large number of former [[American football]] ([[NFL]]) players have been diagnosed with or have had [[chronic traumatic encephalopathy]], or CTE. A definitive diagnosis so far can be made only [[post-mortem]]. However, an increasing number of former players are reporting symptoms of CTE.
==Former players with CTE confirmed post-mortem == A definitive test currently can be made only by examining the brain tissue of a deceased victim.
As the families of many deceased players wish to keep their medical information private, the following list is incomplete. A brain injury study conducted at the [[Boston University School of Medicine]] showed that 33 of 34 players tested post-mortem showed clear signs of CTE,<ref name="34players"/> and additional players have so far been confirmed with CTE separately. A new list released in November 2016 mentions CTE in 90 of 94 brains of former and deceased NFL players.<ref>{{cite |url=http://www.bu.edu/cte/our-research/case-studies/ |title=Case Studies |work=Boston University CTE Center |accessdate=2016-11-04}}</ref> In July 2017, a new study showed that 110 of 111 brains examined showed signs of CTE.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/07/25/health/cte-nfl-players-brains-study/index.html|title=CTE found in 99% of studied brains from deceased NFL players|last=CNN|first=Daniella Emanuel|website=CNN|access-date=2017-07-27}}</ref>
{{div col|colwidth=13em}} *[[Jovan Belcher]]<ref>{{cite web|title=OTL: Belcher's brain had CTE signs|url=http://espn.go.com/espn/otl/story/_/id/11612386/jovan-belcher-brain-showed-signs-cte-doctor-says-report|website=ESPN.com}}</ref> *[[Forrest Blue]]<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.law360.com/articles/457498/nfl-riddell-face-brain-injury-suit-after-ex-player-s-death|title= NFL, Riddell Face Brain Injury Suit After Ex-Player's Death |date= July 16, 2013 |accessdate= November 22, 2013}}</ref> *[[Bill Bryant (American football)|Bill Bryant]]<ref name="110of111" /> *[[Lew Carpenter]]<ref name=Carpenter>{{cite web|title=CTE found in Lew Carpenter's brain|url=http://espn.go.com/nfl/story/_/id/7332016/evidence-cte-found-lew-carpenter-brain|publisher=ESPN via Associated Press|accessdate=8 September 2012}}</ref> *[[Ronnie Caveness]]<ref>{{cite web |title=110 N.F.L. Brains | publisher=''New York Times'' |date=July 25, 2017 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2017/07/25/sports/football/nfl-cte.html |accessdate=25 July 2017}}</ref> *[[Dwight Clark]]<ref>{{cite news|last=Mano|first=Daniel|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/2017/03/19/49ers-legend-dwight-clark-announces-als-diagnosis/|title=49ers legend Dwight Clark announces ALS diagnosis|newspaper=[[The Mercury News]]|date=March 19, 2017|accessdate=March 19, 2017}}</ref> *[[Daniel Colchico]]<ref name="110of111" /> *[[Lou Creekmur]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bu.edu/cste/case-studies/lou-creekmur/ |title=Lou Creekmur|website=bu.edu|accessdate=27 July 2017}}</ref> *[[Art DeCarlo]]<ref name="110of111" /> *[[Shane Dronett]]<ref name=smith>{{citation|last=Smith|first=Stephanie|title=Ex-Falcons lineman had brain disease linked to concussions|url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/HEALTH/04/01/brain.concussion.dronett/index.html?hpt=Sbin|date=April 1, 2011|publisher=CNN}}</ref> *[[Dave Duerson]]<ref name="Deardorff">{{cite news |url=http://www.latimes.com/health/cbsports-study-duerson-had-brain-damage-at-time-of-suicide-20110502,0,1748318.story |title= Study: Duerson had brain damage at time of suicide |author= Deardorff, Julie |newspaper= Los Angeles Times |date= May 2, 2011 |accessdate= May 2, 2011}}</ref><ref name=rolecall/> *[[Pete Duranko]]<ref name="110of111" /> *[[Ray Easterling]]<ref name=rolecall/><ref>[http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-400_162-57481576/autopsy-former-falcons-safety-ray-easterling-had-brain-disease-associated-with-concussions/ "Autopsy: Former Falcons safety Ray Easterling had brain disease associated with concussions"], CBS/AP, July 27, 2012.</ref><ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2012/07/27/sports/football/ray-easterling-autopsy-found-signs-of-brain-disease-cte.html "Ray Easterling autopsy found signs of brain disease CTE"], ''New York Times'', July 27, 2012.</ref> *[[Frank Gifford]]<ref name=rolecall/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/11/25/health/frank-gifford-cte-concussion-chronic-traumatic-encephalopathy/index.html |title=Family: Frank Gifford suffered from brain disease CTE|authors=Eliott C. McLaughlin & Catherine E. Shoichet|publisher=CNN|accessdate=27 July 2017}}</ref> *[[Cookie Gilchrist]]<ref name=rolecall/><ref name=Gilchrist>{{cite web|last=Gola|first=Hank|title=Ex-cop pens Cookie Gilchrist bio|url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/2011-11-16/news/30407756_1_cookie-gilchrist-bad-luck-social-media-website|publisher=New York Daily News|accessdate=8 September 2012}}</ref> *[[John Grimsley]]<ref>[http://www.bu.edu/cste/case-studies/john-grimsley/ Case Study: John Grimsley], Center for the Study of Traumatic Encephalopathy. Accessed August 17, 2010.</ref> *[[Chris Henry (wide receiver)|Chris Henry]]<ref name=rolecall/><ref>{{cite news |author=Schwarz, Alan |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2010/06/29/sports/football/29henry.html |title=Former Bengal Henry Found to Have Had Brain Damage |newspaper= [[The New York Times]] |date= June 28, 2010 |accessdate= October 19, 2010 |authorlink= Alan Schwarz}}</ref> *[[Aaron Hernandez]]<ref>{{cite news |author=Belson, Ken |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/21/sports/aaron-hernandez-cte-brain.html?mcubz=0|title=Aaron Hernandez Found to Have Severe C.T.E. |newspaper= [[The New York Times]] |date= September 21, 2017 |accessdate= September 21, 2017 }}</ref> *[[Jim Hudson]]<ref name="110of111" /> *[[Gerry Huth]]<ref name="110of111" /> *[[Tom Keating (American football)|Tom Keating]]<ref name="110of111" /> *[[Terry Long (American football)|Terry Long]]<ref name = 34players>{{cite news |url=http://abcnews.go.com/Health/cte-degenerative-brain-disease-found-34-pro-football/story?id=17869457 |newspaper= ABC News |title=CTE, a Degenerative Brain Disease, Found in 34 Pro Football Players |date= December 3, 2012 |accessdate= November 21, 2013}}</ref> *[[Rob Lytle]]<ref name="Frei">{{cite |url=http://www.denverpost.com/2015/12/20/autopsy-ex-texas-longhorns-tackle-greg-ploetz-had-stage-4-cte/ |author= Frei, Terry |title=Autopsy: Ex-Texas Longhorns tackle Greg Ploetz had Stage 4 CTE |date= 2015-12-20 |accessdate= 2016-11-05}}</ref> *[[John Mackey (American football)|John Mackey]]<ref name=rolecall/><ref name="Suarez">{{cite news ==Deceased players suspected of having had CTE== Included in the list are players diagnosed with [[amyotrophic lateral sclerosis]] (ALS) who were never tested ''post-mortem'' for CTE but whose history appears consistent with CTE. A typical diagnosis of ALS has primarily been based on the symptoms and signs the physician observes in the patient and a series of tests to rule out other diseases<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1002/ana.410180302 | volume=18 | issue=3 | title=Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis: Part 1. Clinical features, pathology, and ethical issues in management | year=1985 | journal=Annals of Neurology | pages=271–280 | author=Tandan Rup}}</ref> and therefore, prior to the discovery of CTE as a phenomenon in ex-American football players, many CTE cases were diagnosed as ALS. The testing of CTE in deceased ex-NFL players began only after the disease was first diagnosed, in 2002, in the brain tissue of [[Mike Webster]].<ref>[http://www.post-gazette.com/stories/news/health/late-steeler-great-websters-case-launched-the-cte-brain-debate-687509/ Late Steelers great Webster's case launched the CTE brain debate] ''[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]'' 2013-05-14</ref> After then, testing became common practice only gradually. A [[cohort study|cohort mortality study]] run by the [[National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health]] (NIOSH) examined 3,349 NFL players who played at least five full seasons from 1959 to 1988.<ref name=Lehman>{{cite journal |last1= Lehman|first1= EJ|last2= Hein|first2= MJ|last3 = Baron|first3 = SL|last4 = Gersic|first4 = CM|year= 2012|title= Neurodegenerative causes of death among retired National Football League players|journal= Neurology|publisher=American Academy of Neurology |doi=10.1212/WNL.0b013e31826daf50|url=http://www.neurology.org/content/early/2012/09/05/WNL.0b013e31826daf50.full.pdf+html |accessdate=18 December 2012 |pmid=22955124 |volume=79 |issue=19 |pages=1970–4 |pmc=4098841}}</ref><ref name = brain>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.cdc.gov/niosh-science-blog/2012/09/nfl-brain-injury/ |title=CDC - NIOSH Science Blog - Brain Injury in the NFL | publisher= NIOSH|accessdate=18 December 2012}}</ref> Findings showed that while NFL players lived longer than the average American male, the risk of death associated with [[neurodegeneration|neurodegenerative disorders]] was about three times higher among the NFL cohort.<ref name=Lehman/><ref name = brain/> The risk for death from [[Alzheimer's disease]] and [[Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis|ALS]] were about four times higher among the NFL cohort.<ref name = Lehman/>
Some on this list may have had dementia not related to ALS or CTE.

==Living former players diagnosed with CTE or ALS or reporting symptoms consistent with CTE or ALS== These players have publicly acknowledged either having been diagnosed with likely CTE or having experienced symptoms, such as dementia or unusual memory loss, consistent with CTE. In some cases, the player has received a diagnosis of ALS but symptoms are consistent with CTE. There are at least two dozen former players who were diagnosed as part of a UCLA study but have not come forward publicly.<ref name=34players /> There are also around 4,500 former players who joined a class action suit against the [[NFL]] alleging that it had covered up a growing body of medical evidence about the preponderance of head-trauma related CTE in ex-NFL players.<ref name=CTEConcussSuit>{{cite news |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/12/22/us/sport-nfl-concussion-lawsuits/ |title=Former NFL players sue league over head trauma |date=December 22, 2011| accessdate=November 21, 2013 |publisher=CNN}}</ref>
Some of these ex-players may have medical conditions other than CTE or ALS. For example, ex-players that have presented with symptoms late in life may have other forms of age-related dementia. Some of the former players on this list are came forward only in the context of the class action lawsuit versus the NFL. At present, there is no definitive CTE test available for living persons. Their average age is 51.

revision.text:
{{More citations needed|date=February 2012}} This is a '''list of the costliest or deadliest [[hail]]storms''' on record.
== Notable events == === North America === {| class="wikitable" |- ! Date ! Location ! Incident |- | 6 July 1928 | [[Potter, Nebraska]], USA | A {{convert|7|in|0|abbr=on}} hailstone weighing {{convert|1.5|lb|g|abbr=on}} is believed to be the record largest known in the U.S. at the time.<ref>[http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2003/08/0804_030804_largesthailstone.html Largest Hailstone in U.S. History Found]</ref> |- | 2 September 1960 | [[Southern California]], USA | [[Golf ball]] to [[Baseball (ball)|baseball]] sized hail occurred in parts of southern California, including {{convert|2.75|in|cm|abbr=on}} (possibly larger) hail around [[Boulevard, California|Boulevard]] and in [[Riverside County, California|Riverside County]]. That is the largest hail recorded in southern California. A severe thunderstorm also struck [[San Bernardino, California|San Bernardino]].<ref name="SoCal">{{cite web|url=http://www.wrh.noaa.gov/sgx/document/weatherhistory.pdf |title=A History of Significant Weather Events in Southern California |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2013-11-24}}</ref> |- | December 1967 | [[Los Angeles County, California]], USA | A hailstorm hit the county, blanketing the region much like a snowstorm. The storm also produced [[lightning]], and one bolt struck an oil tank in [[Manhattan Beach, California|Manhattan Beach]], causing an explosion that covered much of the South Bay with oil. The next hailstorm to hit the area was in 1979.{{Citation needed|date=February 2008}} |- | 3 September 1970 | [[Coffeyville, Kansas]], USA | At the time the largest hailstone ever found in the U.S., measuring {{convert|5.7|in|abbr=on}} diameter, {{convert|17.5|in|abbr=on}} circumference, and {{convert|1.67|lb|g|abbr=on}}. |- | 30 July 1979 | [[Fort Collins, Colorado]], USA | A violent forty-minute hailstorm bombed Fort Collins, CO, with hail up to [[grapefruit]] size. Two thousand homes and 2500 automobiles were severely damaged, and about 25 people were injured, mainly when hit on the head by the huge stones. A three-month-old baby died of a fractured skull, struck by a large hailstone while being carried by her mother, who was running with her to seek cover.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wecsa.com/FCClimate/ClimHist.pdf |title=http://www.wecsa.com/FCClimate/ClimHist.pdf |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2013-11-24}}</ref> |- | 11 July 1990 | [[Denver]], Colorado, USA | [[Softball]]-sized hail destroyed roofs and cars, causing $625 million in total damage ($1.1 billion in damage adjusted to 2013 dollars).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rmiia.org/Catastrophes_and_Statistics/Hail.htm |title=Colorado hail statistics - Rocky Mountain Insurance Information Association |publisher=Rmiia.org |date= |accessdate=2013-11-24}}</ref> |- | 7 September 1991 | [[Calgary]], [[Alberta]], [[Canada]] | A [[Labour Day]] thunderstorm caused $342 million worth of insurable damage<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.torontosun.com/news/canada/2010/08/11/14992156.html |title=Calgary storm costliest in Canadian history |publisher=Torontosun.com |date= |accessdate=2013-11-24}}</ref> in Calgary. Thirteen additional hailstorms between 1981 and 1998 caused an estimated $600 million in damage in the Calgary area alone.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.springerlink.com/index/Q1032KK8U22Q5XXT.pdf |title=Urban hailstorms: a view from Alberta |publisher=Springerlink.com |date= |accessdate=2013-11-24}}</ref> |- | 19 June 1992 | [[Wichita, Kansas]], USA | Two batches of severe thunderstorms, occurring within 6 hours of each other, dumped hailstones up to {{convert|4.5|in|cm|abbr=on}} in diameter across Sedgwick, including the city of Wichita, and surrounding counties in south-central Kansas. Over 10,000 homes were damaged. The hail left wheat fields in a near total loss. Estimated property damage totaled $500 million with crop damage at $100 million. The thunderstorm episode ranks as one of the worst ever to hit Kansas.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.crh.noaa.gov/ddc/wxtrivia/wxtrvJun.php |title=Today's Weather Trivia: Dodge City, KS |publisher=Crh.noaa.gov |date= |accessdate=2013-11-24}}</ref> |- | 5 May 1995 | [[Dallas]] and [[Fort Worth, Texas]], USA | The [[1995 Mayfest Storm]] produced $1.1 billion insured losses, and total storm damage was reported at around $2 billion. The storms produced hail about the size of softballs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.srh.noaa.gov/fwd/?n=mayfest15 |title=National Weather Service Forecast Office - WFO, Ft. Worth, Texas |publisher=Srh.noaa.gov |date= |accessdate=2013-11-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.weather.com/encyclopedia/thunder/ftworth.html |title=Storm Encyclopedia |publisher=weather.com |date= |accessdate=2013-11-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203031812/http://www.weather.com/encyclopedia/thunder/ftworth.html |archivedate=2013-12-03 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://torrentialrainandhailstones.wordpress.com/ | title=Storm Insurance}}</ref> |- | 24 July 1996 | Calgary and [[Winnipeg|Winnipeg, Manitoba]], Canada | [[Orange (fruit)|Orange]]-sized hailstones caused almost $300 million worth of damage in Calgary and Winnipeg, as well as serious [[flood]]ing. Notably, one-third of cars damaged by the storm were irreparable.{{Citation needed|date=October 2012}} |- | 29 March 2000 | [[Lake Worth, Texas]], USA | The last known hail fatality in the United States occurred. The victim was Juan Oseguera, a nineteen-year-old man who died from head injuries after being hit by a softball sized hailstone in Lake Worth.<ref>[http://edition.cnn.com/2000/WEATHER/03/30/ft.worth.tornado.01/index.html#1 Fort Worth surveys tornado damage, counts the cost - March 30, 2000 - CNN.com] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080522131455/http://edition.cnn.com/2000/WEATHER/03/30/ft.worth.tornado.01/index.html#1 |date=May 22, 2008 }}</ref> |- | 18 May 2000 | [[Chicago]] area, [[Illinois]], USA | $572 million. Golfball-, baseball-, and softball-sized hail damaged roofs, cars, patio furniture, skylights, and windows in the area's worst and most widespread hailstorm in 30 years ([[McHenry County, Illinois|McHenry]], [[Lake County, Illinois|Lake]], northern [[Kane County, Illinois|Kane]], northern [[Cook County, Illinois|Cook County]]). Around 100,000 homes lost power. Hail was {{convert|3|in|mm|abbr=on}} deep in many areas. There were 100 canceled flights, and train service was disrupted.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.crh.noaa.gov/lot/stormdata/may2000.pdf |title=Storm Data and Unusual Weather Phenomena - National Weather Service |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2013-11-24}}</ref> |- | 10 April 2001 | [[St. Louis]], [[Missouri]], USA | $2.0 billion+. The costliest [[April 10–11, 2001 tornado outbreak#Tri-state hailstorm|hailstorm]] in US history struck the [[Interstate 70|I-70]] corridor of eastern Kansas, across Missouri, into southwestern Illinois producing many baseball-sized hail reports.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.crh.noaa.gov/lsx/?n=april_10_2001 |title=NOAA's National Weather Service Weather Forecast Office - St Louis, MO |publisher=Crh.noaa.gov |date= |accessdate=2013-11-24}}</ref> |- | 22 June 2003 | [[Aurora, Nebraska]], USA | The largest hailstone on record at the time fell on this date. It had a {{convert|7|in|mm|0|adj=on}} diameter and a circumference of {{convert|18.74|in|mm}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2003/08/0804_030804_largesthailstone.html |title=Largest Hailstone in U.S. History Found |publisher=News.nationalgeographic.com |date=2010-10-28 |accessdate=2013-11-24}}</ref> |- | 12 July 2004 | [[Edmonton]], [[Alberta]] [[Canada]] | Grape-golf-ball sized hail and more than {{convert|150|mm|in}} of rain in fell in 30 minutes, leaving {{convert|6|cm|in}} deep of hail on the ground and flash flooding, it is estimated to be a 1-in-200 year event. Over 20,000 People were evacuated from West Edmonton Mall when the weight from the hail and rain caused the glass roofs to shatter.<ref name="Edmontonstrorm">{{cite web|last1=St. Clair|first1=Chris|title=https://www.theweathernetwork.com/news/articles/top-five-most-expensive-floods-in-canada-this-century-/25124|url=https://www.theweathernetwork.com/news/articles/top-five-most-expensive-floods-in-canada-this-century-/25124|website=The Weather Network|publisher=Meteo Media|accessdate=22 August 2016|date=12 April 2014}}</ref> |- | 20–21 April 2006 | [[San Marcos, Texas]], USA | Hail of sizes up to {{convert|10|cm|in|abbr=on}}<ref>[http://www.srh.noaa.gov/ewx/html/wxevent/2006/apr2006.htm April 2006 Weather Review - National Weather Service Forecast Office - WFO, Austin/San Antonio, Texas] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080724133047/http://www.srh.noaa.gov/ewx/html/wxevent/2006/apr2006.htm |date=July 24, 2008 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.srh.noaa.gov/ewx/html/wxevent/2006/lsrapr2021.htm Preliminary [[Local Storm Report]] - National Weather Service]</ref> results in 10,000 auto claims, 7,000 homeowner and commercial property claims ranging between $100–160 million insured losses.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.insurancecouncil.org/news/2006/june022006.doc |title=Central Texas Hailstorms were Costly - The Insurance Council of Texas |date= |accessdate=2013-11-24 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120219062525/http://www.insurancecouncil.org/news/2006/june022006.doc |archive-date=2012-02-19 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20080528032640/http://www.ci.san-marcos.tx.us/departments/police/documents/YrinReview06.pdf 2006 Year in Review - San Marcos Police Department]</ref> One woman was hospitalized.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.insurancejournal.com/news/southcentral/2006/06/02/69106.htm |title=Losses from April Hailstorms in Central Texas Reach $160M |publisher=Insurance Journal |date=2006-06-02 |accessdate=2013-11-24}}</ref> The storm was especially costly at the [[San Marcos Outlet Malls]] and a nearby [[Toyota]] dealership.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20061005125808/http://www.ci.san-marcos.tx.us/Departments/planning/documents/NOTEPADS5.06.pdf News from the Planning and Development Services Department - City of San Marcos, Texas]</ref><ref>[http://www.news8austin.com/content/headlines/?ArID=160270&SecID=2 Storms strike again - News 8 Austin] {{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> |- | 20 July 2009 | [[Denver, Colorado]], USA | A hailstorm in the western suburbs of Denver caused $770 million (USD) damage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rmiia.org/Catastrophes_and_Statistics/Hail.asp |title=Hail Damage and Statistics |publisher=Rmiia.org |date= |accessdate=2013-11-24}}</ref> |- | 10 & 16 May 2010 | [[Oklahoma City, Oklahoma]], USA | Two major hailstorms separated by less than a week caused damage to large portions of the [[Oklahoma City metropolitan area]]. Damages from the first storm caused an estimated $595 million (USD) damage, and the second storm was expected to be around the same, totaling around $1 billion in damages.<ref>{{cite web|last=Mecoy |first=Don |url=http://www.newsok.com/article/3465717 |title=The Daily Oklahoman |publisher=Newsok.com |date=2010-06-03 |accessdate=2013-11-24}}</ref> |- | 12 July 2010 | [[Calgary]], [[Alberta]], Canada | The hailstorm that pounded Calgary on July 12 eclipsed the record originally set in 1991, with insurable damages totaling at least $400 million,<ref>[http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/calgary/calgary-hailstorm-sets-damage-record-1.925450 Calgary hailstorm sets damage record]</ref> excluding agricultural crop damage. The storm brought hail as wide as {{convert|4|cm|in|abbr=on}}.{{citation needed|date=August 2016}} |- | 23 July 2010 | [[Vivian, South Dakota|Vivian]], [[South Dakota]], USA | The largest diameter hailstone known, measuring {{convert|7.87|in|cm|abbr=on}} in diameter - larger than a [[bowling ball]] - and weighing {{convert|1.9375|lb|kg|2|abbr=on}}, fell on Vivian during an exceptional hailstorm.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zXgYH9pTu_Y |title=World Record Hail Stone Found |publisher=YouTube |date=2010-07-30 |accessdate=2013-11-24}}</ref> |- | 28 April 2012 | [[St. Louis]], [[Missouri]], USA | Series of [http://www.crh.noaa.gov/lsx/?n=04_28_2012 hailstorms] amount to 2nd costliest in U.S. history at estimated $1.6 billion in insured losses<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.crh.noaa.gov/news/display_cmsstory.php?wfo=lsx&storyid=88129&source=0 |title=April 28, 2012 Hailstorms In St. Louis Among The Most Costly In U.S. History |publisher=Crh.noaa.gov |date= |accessdate=2013-11-24}}</ref> |- | 13 June 2012 | [[Dallas, Texas|Dallas]] and [[Fort Worth, Texas]], USA | Baseball to softball-sized hail pummeled DFW causing significant damage to cars, houses, and other buildings. Estimated damages were approximately $900 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.srh.noaa.gov/fwd/?n=june132012 |title=June 13th 2012 Hailstorms - National Weather Service |publisher=Srh.noaa.gov |date= |accessdate=2013-11-24}}</ref> |- | 12 August 2012 | [[Calgary]], [[Alberta]], Canada | A storm, with hailstones approximately the size of golf balls, battered Calgary for 10 minutes. High winds were associated with the storm, causing $552 million in damage.<ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2012/12/20/calgary-hail-stor-environment-canadas-top-10-extreme-weather-events_n_2339941.html Calgary Hail Storm Makes Environment Canada's Top 10 Extreme Weather Events]</ref> |- | 16 April 2016 | [[San Antonio]], [[Texas]], USA | A storm producing hail up to the size of grapefruits pummeled the city causing extensive damage to cars, homes, windows, and roofs. It is estimated that the storm cost 1.4 billion dollars in losses (the costliest in the state's history).<ref>[http://www.mysanantonio.com/business/local/amp/San-Antonio-hail-storm-1-4-billion-in-losses-7269460.php San Antonio hail storm called costliest in Texas history with nearly $1.4 Billion in losses]</ref> |- | 8 May 2017 | [[Denver]], [[Colorado]], USA | In what is now the most catastrophic storm in state history, baseball-sized stones pummeled the west Denver Metro area, resulting in extensive damage to homes, windows, vehicles (many of which were in the late day commute), and roofs. The storm would surpass the state's costliest wildfires, force the closure of the [[Colorado Mills]] Mall until the end of 2017, and caused $2.3 billion in damage.<ref>[http://www.denverpost.com/2017/05/23/hailstorm-costliest-ever-metro-denver/ Hailstorm that hammered west metro Denver May 8 is costliest ever for Colorado]</ref><ref>[http://www.rmiia.org/catastrophes_and_statistics/Hail.asp Hail Damage and Statistics]</ref> |- | 9 June 2017 | [[Minneapolis]], [[Minnesota]], USA | A storm system lasting over a week created severe hail and high wind damage, reaching from Minnesota to Texas to Virginia to New York. The Minneapolis metro area suffered especially, receiving hail damage to many buildings and vehicles. The total damage was estimated to be over $2.5 billion.<ref>https://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/sotc/national/201706</ref> |}
=== Europe === {| class="wikitable" |- ! Date ! Location ! Incident
|- | 13 April 1360 | Outskirts of [[Chartres]], [[France]] | a freak hail storm struck and killed an estimated 1,000<ref name=CracknellBarnes>{{Cite web |url=http://www.stgeorges-windsor.org/archives/archive-features/image-of-the-month/title1/a-king-is-born-at-windsor.html |title=Eleanor Cracknell, Assistant Archivist, cites: Barnes, J., ''The History of that Most Victorious Monarch Edward IIId'' (Cambridge, 1688), p. 583. in 'A King is Born at Windsor', Windsor Castle Chapel Archives and Chapter Library at stgeorges-windsor.org |access-date=2018-04-20 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160604110801/http://www.stgeorges-windsor.org/archives/archive-features/image-of-the-month/title1/a-king-is-born-at-windsor.html |archive-date=2016-06-04 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> English soldiers on [[Black Monday (1360)]] during the [[Hundred Years War]]
|- | May 1411 | [[Wellesbourne]], [[Warwickshire]], [[England]], [[United Kingdom|UK]] | The first known severe hailstorm in Britain is thought to have incurred fatalities.<ref name="TORRO">{{cite web|url=http://www.torro.org.uk/site/hail_extremes.php |title=European Hailstorm Extremes |publisher=Torro.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2013-11-24}}</ref>
|- | 15 May 1697 | [[Hitchin]] to [[Great Offley]], [[Hertfordshire]], [[England]], [[United Kingdom|UK]] | A H8 level hailstorm is the most intense on record in Britain<ref name="TORRO"/>
|- |13 July 1788 |[[Kingdom of France|France]] and [[Dutch Republic]] |Heavy damage to crops, leading to further economic turmoil in France and preciptating the [[French Revolution]] one year later.
|- | 1 July 1891 | Netherlands, Germany | From Brabant and Limburg in the Netherlands, Münsterland, Weserbergland, Brandenburg.
|- | 9 August 1843 | [[Midlands (England)|Midlands]] and [[East Anglia]], Central and Southern England | One of Britain's worst ever hailstorms, possibly a [[supercell]], caused massive destruction as hailstones reached up to {{convert|1.5|m|ft|abbr=on}} deep in places. The storm is also believed to have spawned several [[tornado]]es, and the exact size of the hail that fell within it is unknown. The overall damage was so great that an entire new insurance company, The General Hail Insurance Company, was formed to help cope with future hailstorms. This company would later be known as the [[Norwich Union]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.geologywales.co.uk/storms/1843.htm |title=THE GREAT HAILSTORM OF AUGUST 9, 1843 |publisher=Geologywales.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2013-11-24}}</ref>
|- | 22 September 1935 | [[Newport, Wales|Newport]], [[Monmouthshire (historic)|Monmouthshire]] to [[Mundesley]], [[Norfolk]], [[United Kingdom|UK]] | A H6 level hailswath at least from points above and possibly longer is longest on record in Britain.<ref name="TORRO"/>
|- | 24 May 1937 | [[Belgrade]], [[Kingdom of Yugoslavia|Yugoslavia]] | <ref>[http://scc.digital.nb.rs/view/P-2484-1937&ID=10214&p=005&w=1024&h=525 Politika, May 25 1937]</ref>
|- | 1–2 July 1968 | [[England]] and [[Wales]] | [[Mineral dust]] blowing in from the Sahara met cold, moist air over the British Isles, forming unusually large hailstones (at least {{convert|75|mm}} across, possibly {{convert|100|mm}}) around the dust. In [[July 1968 England and Wales dust fall storms|the thunderstorms that ensued]], hail piled up to {{convert|0.45|m}} deep and many towns flooded.<ref name="dust">{{cite book|url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/DM_Elsom/publication/312301861_Severe_hailstorms_in_the_United_Kingdom_and_Ireland_a_climatological_survey_with_recent_and_historical_case_studies/links/5878f9f708ae9a860fe2ac1a/Severe-hailstorms-in-the-United-Kingdom-and-Ireland-a-climatological-survey-with-recent-and-historical-case-studies.pdf|title=Extreme Weather: Forty Years of the Tornado and Storm Research Organisation (TORRO)|chapter=Severe Hailstorms in the United Kingdom and Ireland: A Climatological Survey with Recent and Historical Case Studies|pages=181–185|first1=Jonathan D.C.|last1=Webb|first2=Derek M.|last2=Elsom|accessdate=2 October 2018|year=2016}}</ref>
|- | 12 July 1984 | [[Munich]], [[Bavaria]], [[Germany]] | [[Tennis ball]] sized hail fell on Munich and surrounding areas on this date.<ref>http://elib.dlr.de/64721/1/85-heimann.pdf</ref> It was the greatest loss event in the history of the German insurance industry: 200,000 cars were damaged and the storm cost an estimated 166 million Deutschmark.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.munichre.com/en/group/history/natural_catastrophes.aspx |title=group history 1970–1989 |publisher=Munich Re |date=1974-01-01 |accessdate=2013-11-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131202224959/http://www.munichre.com/en/group/history/natural_catastrophes.aspx |archivedate=2013-12-02 |df= }}</ref> For years afterwards people jokingly referred to those cars whose bodywork was not repaired as 'Munich Design'.
|- | 28–29 June 2006 | [[Villingen-Schwenningen]] and suburbs, [[Baden-Württemberg]], [[Germany]] | Supercell thunderstorms, severe damage by grapefruit-sized<ref>{{cite web |author=sueddeutsche.de GmbH, Munich, Germany |url=http://www.sueddeutsche.de/panorama/286/374096/text/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130212011141/http://www.sueddeutsche.de/panorama/286/374096/text/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-02-12 |title=Schweres Unwetter - ''Es sieht aus wie im Krieg'' - Panorama |publisher=sueddeutsche.de |date=2006-06-29 |accessdate=2010-04-08 }}</ref> hailstones, causing €150 million damage, more than 100 injuries.
|- | 27–28 July 2013 | [[Reutlingen]] and [[Pforzheim|Pfortzheim]], [[Baden-Württemberg]]; [[Wolfsburg]] and [[Hanover]], [[Lower Saxony]] | A series of hailstorms caused large amounts of damage in both Northern and Southern Germany. The total cost of these hailstorms has been estimated to be €3.6 billion.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ergo.com/~/media/ergocom/pdf/praesentationen/2016/201607-naturkatastrophen-deutschland-1980-2015.pdf?la=de|title=Naturkatastrophen in Deutschland 1980-2015, April 2016|last=|first=|date=|website=|page=7|access-date=3 June 2017}}</ref> In Reutlingen alone around 70 people received minor injuries.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.schwarzwaelder-bote.de/inhalt.unwetter-im-suedwesten-schaden-belaeuft-sich-auf-100-millionen-euro.a322528b-20a9-47bd-a657-65ad74a45ad6.html|title=Schaden beläuft sich auf 100 Millionen Euro|last=|first=|date=29 July 2013|work=Schwarzwälder Bote|access-date=3 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last = Kunz |first = Michael |author2 = et al |title = The severe hailstorm in southwest Germany on 28 July 2013: characteristics, impacts and meteorological conditions |journal = Q.J.R. === Asia === {| class="wikitable" |- ! Date ! Location ! Incident
|- | Circa 9th century | [[Roopkund]], [[Uttarakhand]], [[India]] | Several hundred [[pilgrim]]s were killed by a hailstorm in Roopkund.<ref>{{cite news|last=Orr |first=David |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/india/1476074/Giant-hail-killed-more-than-200-in-Himalayas.html |title=Telegraph News |publisher=Telegraph.co.uk |date=2004-11-07 |accessdate=2013-11-24 |location=London}}</ref>
|- | March 12 to April 19, 1490 | [[Qingyang]], [[China]] | The [[1490 Ch'ing-yang event]] may have been due to a large comet breaking up in the atmosphere, or a hail storm. Sources generally considered reliable say more than 10,000 killed, but the official [[History of Ming]] does not give a number of casualties.<ref name="Meteoritics-1994">Yau, K., Weissman, P., & Yeomans, D. [http://articles.adsabs.harvard.edu/full/1994Metic..29..864Y Meteorite Falls In China And Some Related Human Casualty Events], ''[[Meteoritics]]'', Vol. 29, No. 6, pp. 864–871, {{ISSN|0026-1114}}, bibliographic code: 1994Metic..29..864Y.</ref><ref name="Sky&Telescope">[http://connection.ebscohost.com/c/articles/9502082119/death-from-above-ancient-china Death from above in ancient China], ''[[Sky & Telescope]]'', March 1995, Vol. 89, Iss. 3, p. 15, {{ISSN|0037-6604}}.</ref><ref name="Webb">Webb, Sterling K., Juhl, Robert A. [http://www.mail-archive.com/meteorite-list@meteoritecentral.com/msg80757.html Meteorite deaths in Qingyang (Ch'ing-yang) in 1490], MeteoriteCentral.com website as archived on Mail-Archive.com, January 1, 2010. Retrieved March 13, 2013.</ref>
|- | 30 April 1888 | [[Moradabad (Uttar Pradesh)]], Northern India | One of the deadliest hailstorms of all time killed at least 230 people, and over 1600 sheep and goats, in Uttar Pradesh. The hailstones were reportedly as big as oranges, and in some areas piled up to {{convert|2|ft|m|abbr=on}} high. No warning system existed in 1888 and therefore the death toll of this event was exceptionally high.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.history.com/this-day-in-history/orange-sized-hail-reported-in-india |title=Orange-sized hail reported in India — History.com This Day in History — 4/30/1888 |publisher=History.com |date= |accessdate=2013-11-24}}</ref>
|- | 14 April 1986 | [[Gopalganj, Bangladesh|Gopalganj]], [[Bangladesh]] | At least 92 people were killed in Gopalganj by some of the heaviest hailstones ever recorded, which were the size of grapefruits and weighed around {{convert|1.02|kg|lb|2|abbr=on}} each.<ref>{{cite web|title=World: Heaviest Hailstone |url=http://wmo.asu.edu/world-heaviest-hailstone |website=Arizona State University |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150629151041/http://wmo.asu.edu/world-heaviest-hailstone |archivedate=2015-06-29 |df= }}</ref>
|- | 19 July 2002 | [[Henan Province]], the [[People's Republic of China]] | 25 dead and hundreds injured.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2002/WEATHER/07/22/weather.china.hail/|title=More casualties from China hail storm|last=|first=|date=23 July 2002|work=CNN|access-date=3 June 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170603142111/http://edition.cnn.com/2002/WEATHER/07/22/weather.china.hail/|archive-date=3 June 2017|dead-url=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn2575-giant-hailstones-kill-25-in-china/|title=Giant hailstones kill 25 in China|last=Vince|first=Gaia|date=22 July 2002|website=New Scientist|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160413022740/https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn2575-giant-hailstones-kill-25-in-china/|archive-date=13 April 2016|dead-url=|access-date=3 June 2017}}</ref>
|}

|- | 17 November 1949 | [[Pretoria]], [[Transvaal Province|Transvaal]], South Africa | Hailstorm struck [[List of Pretoria suburbs|Western Pretoria]]- hailstones of circumference {{convert|23|cm|in|abbr=on}} (diameter {{convert|7|cm|in|abbr=on}}) damaged windows or roofs on all buildings in the area, and broke 12000 large windows at the Iscor (now [[Mittal Steel South Africa]]) plant in the area, and damaged hundreds of cars at the plant.<ref name="UniversityOfPretoriaGrobler"/>
