revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=January 2007}}
[[Image:DomenichinounicornPalFarnese.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Quiffins resemble long-necked unicorns, except that they have no horn and can fly. Taxonomically, quiffins are closer to [[deer]] and [[llama]]s than to [[horse]]s.]]
In [[children's literature]], the '''Quiffin''' is a mythic animal that resembles a white [[llama]] or a long-necked unicorn without a horn.
==Characterization== Quiffins graze in the forests of Scandinavian countries, particularly forests near the [[Oresund]] separating [[Sweden]] from [[Denmark]]. Quiffins can fly, although they prefer to walk; quiffins can also swim over twelve miles if need be, although they are not fond of water. Quiffins were first described in [[Hans Peterson]]'s book, ''Liselott och garaffen'', which won the 1962 Children's Book of the Year in Sweden and which was translated into English as ''Liselott and the Quiffin''.
Quiffins are ordinarily shy, but they have several properties that endear them to children whom they choose to befriend. First and foremost, they think only good thoughts about their friends, and vice versa. Secondly, they are elegant and graceful creatures, and comfortable in many situations, whether standing in the rain, resting in a hastily built house, or swaying in the boughs of a tree into which they have flown. They are very obliging, and gladly perform tricks to amuse their friends. They are also very patient, always remembering their friends and always willing to comfort them, no matter how many years have passed since their last meeting. Finally, quiffins have cloven [[hoof|hooves]] and beautiful white [[fur]] that is warm and comforting even when wet.
[[Category:Swedish literature]]
{{Fictional-stub}}

{{About|the botanical term|other uses of the word|rhizome (disambiguation)}} [[File:Euphorbia rhizophora2 ies.jpg|thumb|An antique spurge plant, ''[[Euphorbia antiquorum]]'', sending out rhizomes]] [[Image:Lotus root.jpg|thumb|[[Nelumbo nucifera|Lotus]] rhizome sliced and peeled]] [[File:Curcuma longa roots.jpg|thumb|right|[[Turmeric]] rhizome, whole and ground into a spice]] [[File:Corm stolons5680.jpg|thumb|right|[[Stolon]]s growing from nodes from a [[corm]] of ''[[Crocosmia]]'']] In [[botany]] and [[dendrology]], a '''rhizome''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|r|aɪ|z|oʊ|m}}, from {{lang-grc|rhízōma|script=Latn}} "mass of roots",<ref>{{LSJ|r(I/zwma|ῥίζωμα|ref}}</ref> from {{lang|grc-Latn|rhizóō}} "cause to strike root")<ref>{{LSJ|r(izo/w|ῥιζόω}}</ref> is a modified subterranean [[plant stem]] that sends out [[root]]s and [[shoot]]s from its [[Node (botany)|nodes]]. Rhizomes are also called '''creeping rootstalks''' or just '''rootstalks'''.{{Cn|date=July 2018}} Rhizomes develop from [[axillary bud]]s and grow horizontally. The rhizome also retains the ability to allow new shoots to grow upwards.<ref name=Jang1148>{{cite journal|last=Jang|first=Cheol Seong|title=Functional classification, genomic organization, putatively cis-acting regulatory elements, and relationship to quantitative trait loci, of sorghum genes with rhizome-enriched expression.|journal=Plant Physiology|year=2006|volume=142|issue=3|pages=1148–1159|doi=10.1104/pp.106.082891|display-authors=etal|pmid=16998090|pmc=1630734}}</ref>
A rhizome is the main stem of the plant. A [[stolon]] is similar to a rhizome, but a stolon sprouts from an existing stem, has long internodes, and generates new shoots at the end, such as in the [[strawberry]] plant. In general, rhizomes have short internodes, send out roots from the bottom of the nodes, and generate new upward-growing shoots from the top of the nodes.
A [[stem tuber]] is a thickened part of a rhizome or stolon that has been enlarged for use as a [[storage organ]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Stern |first=Kingsley R. |title=Introductory Plant Biology |edition=10th |publisher=McGraw Hill |date=2002 |isbn=0-07-290941-2}}</ref> In general, a tuber is high in [[starch]], e.g. the [[potato]], which is a modified stolon. The term "tuber" is often used imprecisely and is sometimes applied to plants with rhizomes.
If a rhizome is separated each piece may be able to give rise to a new plant. The plant uses the rhizome to store [[starch]]es, [[protein]]s, and other nutrients. These nutrients become useful for the plant when new shoots must be formed or when the plant dies back for the winter.<ref name=Jang1148 /> This is a process known as [[vegetative reproduction]] and is used by farmers and gardeners to propagate certain plants. This also allows for lateral spread of grasses like [[bamboo]] and [[bunch grasses]]. Examples of plants that are propagated this way include [[hops]], [[asparagus]], [[ginger]], [[iris (plant)|iris]]es, [[lily of the valley]], [[Canna (plant)|cannas]], and [[sympodial]] [[orchid]]s. Some rhizomes which are used directly in cooking include ginger, [[turmeric]], [[galangal]], [[fingerroot]], and [[Nelumbo nucifera|lotus]].
Stored rhizomes are subject to bacterial and fungal infections, making them unsuitable for replanting and greatly diminishing stocks. However, rhizomes can also be produced artificially from tissue cultures. The ability to easily grow rhizomes from tissue cultures leads to better stocks for replanting and greater yields.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Nayak |first1=Sanghamitra |first2=Pradeep Kumar |last2=Naik |title=Factors effecting in vitro microrhizome formation and growth in ''Curcuma longa'' L. and improved field performance of micropropagated plants |journal= Science Asia |year=2006 |volume=32 |pages=31–37 |doi=10.2306/scienceasia1513-1874.2006.32.031}}</ref> The plant hormones [[ethylene]] and [[jasmonic acid]] have been found to help induce and regulate the growth of rhizomes, specifically in [[rhubarb]]. Ethylene that was applied externally was found to affect internal ethylene levels, allowing easy manipulations of ethylene concentrations.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Rayirath|first=Usha P|title=Role of ethylene and jasmonic acid on rhizome induction and growth in rhubarb (Rheum rhabarbarum L.) |journal=Plant Cell Tissue Organ Culture|year=2011|volume=105|pages=253–263|doi=10.1007/s11240-010-9861-y|display-authors=etal}}</ref> Knowledge of how to use these hormones to induce rhizome growth could help farmers and biologists producing plants grown from rhizomes more easily cultivate and grow better plants.
Some plants have rhizomes that grow above ground or that lie at the soil surface, including some ''[[Iris (plant)|Iris]]'' species, and [[fern]]s, whose spreading stems are rhizomes. Plants with underground rhizomes include [[Zingiberaceae|ginger]]s, [[bamboo]], the [[Venus flytrap]], [[Physalis alkekengi|Chinese lantern]], [[western poison-oak]],<ref>{{cite web |last=Hogan |first=C. Michael |date=2008 |url=http://globaltwitcher.auderis.se/artspec_information.asp?thingid=82914 |title=Western Poison-oak (''Toxicodendron diversilobum'') |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090721044257/http://globaltwitcher.auderis.se/artspec_information.asp?thingid=82914 |archive-date=2009-07-21 |website=GlobalTwitcher |editor-first=Nicklas |editor-last=Stromberg}}</ref> [[hops]], and [[Alstroemeria]], and the weeds [[Johnson grass]], [[Bermuda grass]], and [[Cyperus rotundus|purple nut sedge]]. Rhizomes generally form a single layer, but in [[giant horsetail]]s, can be multi-tiered.<ref>{{cite web |last=Husby |first=C. |date=2003 |url=http://www.fiu.edu/~chusb001/GiantEquisetum/Ecophysiology.html |title=Ecology and Physiology of the Giant Horsetails |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090714044939/http://www.fiu.edu/~chusb001/GiantEquisetum/Ecophysiology.html |archive-date=2009-07-14 |publisher=Florida International University}}</ref>
Many rhizomes have culinary value, and some, such as ''[[zhe'ergen]]'', are commonly consumed raw.<ref>{{cite book |last=Lim |first=T.K. |title=Edible Medicinal and Non-Medicinal Plants |edition=11th |publisher=Springer |date=2016 |isbn=978-3-319-26061-7}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Aspen]] *[[Corm]] *[[Mycorrhiza]]
==References== {{Reflist|35em}}
==External links== * {{Commons category-inline|Rhizomes}} *[http://www.rhizomecollective.org/ The Rhizome Collective] for sustainable living
{{botany}}

revision.comment: Reverting possible vandalism by [[Special:Contribs/2A02:C7D:32F0:5F00:8941:2E58:2897:D0DC|2A02:C7D:32F0:5F00:8941:2E58:2897:D0DC]] to version by KolbertBot. [[WP:CBFP|Report False Positive?]] Thanks, [[WP:CBNG|ClueBot NG]]. (3500329) (Bot)
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2014}} {{Coord|48.73|-123.1|type:waterbody|display=title}} [[File:Salish feet.jpg|thumb|upright=1.5|Locations of Salish Sea foot discoveries through December 8, 2017]]
The '''Salish Sea human foot discoveries''' refers to the discoveries of multiple [[amputation|detached]] human feet on the [[Pacific Northwest]] coasts of the [[Salish Sea]] in [[British Columbia]], Canada, and [[Washington (state)|Washington]], United States. The first discovery occurred on August 20, 2007 on [[Jedediah Island Marine Provincial Park|Jedediah Island]] in British Columbia. In the years since, multiple detached feet have been discovered on the coasts of numerous islands in British Columbia, as well as in the U.S. cities of [[Tacoma, Washington|Tacoma]] and [[Seattle]].
In December 2017, ''[[The Guardian]]'' reported: "In the past dozen cases, the provincial coroner’s office has ruled out foul play... All of the individuals either killed themselves or died accidentally, with their feet naturally coming apart from their bodies during decomposition, said the coroner. ... The ubiquitous presence of running shoes might explain some of the mystery; made with light but durable materials, the shoes both protect the foot from decomposition and act as a flotation device that pulls it to the surface."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/dec/13/canada-human-foot-british-columbia |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] | title = Human foot found on Canada shoreline – the 13th such discovery in a decade |date =13 Dec 2017}}</ref>
Such discoveries can be dated back a century with the discovery of a leg in a boot on a Vancouver beach in 1887.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=Kwantlen Chronicle | title = Believe it or not: The Unexpected History of Three Lower Mainland Roads |date =14 January 2010 |url=http://archive.kwantlenchronicle.ca/2010/01/believe-it-or-not-the-unexpected-history-of-three-lower-mainland-roads/index.html |first=Mitch |last=Thompson}}</ref>
==Discoveries== As of 6 May 2018, fourteen<ref name="CTV News, 7 May 2018"/> feet have been found in the Canadian province of British Columbia, and five in the US state of Washington.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/localnews/2013679886_apwamysteryfoot2ndldwritethru.html|title=Tacoma police say human foot washed ashore|date=14 Dec 2010 |newspaper=[[The Seattle Times]] |accessdate=8 Mar 2011|location=Tacoma, WA }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.vancitybuzz.com/2016/02/severed-human-foot-vancouver-island/ |title=Severed human foot found washed ashore on Vancouver Island |date=10 Feb 2016|work=[[Daily Hive]] |accessdate=9 May 2018}}</ref><ref>{{citenews|url=http://www.cbc.ca/beta/news/canada/british-columbia/found-foot-1.4438912 |title=Severed human foot found on Southern Vancouver Island |date=8 Dec 2017 |work=[[CBC News]]}}</ref>
Of the 19 feet there are two matched pairs, one of these pairs was a woman who jumped from a bridge. Two other feet have been identified, one as belonging to a missing fisherman and the other of a depressed man who probably committed suicide.<ref name="CTV November 11, 2008"/><ref name="MSNBC June 6, 2011">{{cite web |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/28088559/ns/world_news-americas/t/canada-coroner-matches-pair-mysterious-feet/ |title=Canada coroner matches pair of mysterious feet |work=[[MSNBC]] |date=6 Jun 2011 |accessdate=6 Jun 2011}}</ref> His identity was withheld on request of his family.
These foot discoveries are not the first ones on British Columbia's coast. One was found in Vancouver in 1887, leading to the place of discovery being called Leg-In-Boot Square.<ref name="Namely Vancouver: A Hidden History of Vancouver Place Names by Tom Snyders with Jennifer O'Rourke">{{cite web|url=http://www.abcbookworld.com/view_author.php?id=1856 |title=O'Rourke, Jennifer|website=ABC BookWorld|publisher=[[B.C. BookWorld]]}}</ref> On 30 July 1914, ''[[The Vancouver Sun]]'' reported that recent arrivals from [[Kimsquit]] reported a human leg encased in a high boot was found on a beach near the mouth of the Salmon River (a previous name for the [[Dean River]] near Kimsquit, near the headwater of [[Dean Channel]]). It was thought the remains were from a man who had drowned on the river the previous summer.<ref name="July 30, 1914">{{cite news |title=Human leg is found encased in a boot |newspaper=[[The Vancouver Sun]] |date=30 Jul 1914 |page=9}}</ref>
{| class="wikitable" ! # ! Date ! Location ! Details ! Coordinates |- | align="center" valign="top"|1 || nowrap valign="top"| August 20, 2007 || [[Jedediah Island Marine Provincial Park|Jedediah Island]], BC, Canada || A girl visiting from [[Washington (state)|Washington]]<ref name="CBC August 31, 2007">{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/british-columbia/story/2007/08/31/bc-feet.html|title=Discovery of unattached human feet baffles B.C. police|date=August 31, 2007|work=[[CBC News]]|accessdate=18 Jun 2008}}</ref> picked up a [[shoe sizes|size 12]] [[Adidas]] shoe and opened the sock<ref name="Vancouver Sun Aug 31 2007">{{cite news|date=31 Aug 2007|newspaper=[[The Vancouver Sun]] |first=Sunny |last= Freeman |page=A1 |title=Two large right feet found on Georgia Strait beaches; 'Finding one foot is like a million to one odds, but to find two is crazy' RCMP corporal's 'best guess is that they are from missing persons'}}</ref> to find a man's right foot. It is thought to have become [[disarticulated]] due to submerged decay.<ref name="CBC August 31, 2007"/> This kind of shoe was produced in 2003 and distributed mainly in [[India]].<ref name="CBC July 10, 2008"/> A man's right foot; size 12 white-and-blue-mesh running shoe. The remains were identified as those of a missing man suffering from depression.|| |- | align="center" valign="top"|2 || nowrap valign="top"| August 26, 2007 || [[Gabriola Island]], BC, Canada || A man's right foot, discovered by a couple, also disarticulated due to decay.<ref name="CBC August 31, 2007"/> It was waterlogged and appeared to have been taken ashore by an animal. It probably floated ashore from the south.<ref name="Vancouver Sun Aug 31 2007"/> The shoe, a size 12 white Reebok, was produced in 2004 and sold worldwide but primarily in North America, and the type has since been discontinued.<ref name="CBC July 10, 2008"/> ||{{coord|name=August 26, 2007|49.15| -123.733|display=inline|region:CA_type:isle}} |- | align="center" valign="top"|3 || nowrap valign="top"| February 8, 2008 || [[Valdes Island]], BC, Canada || A right foot in a size 11 [[Nike Inc.|Nike]]. The remains were identified as a 21-year-old [[Surrey, British Columbia|Surrey]] man reported missing four years prior, whose death is considered "not suspicious", indicating either misadventure or suicide.<ref name="Globe and Mail August 24, 2014">{{cite news |last=Bailey |first=Ian |title=Human feet washed up in B.C. identified |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/british-columbia/human-feet-washed-up-in-bc-identified/article4263242/ |accessdate=13 Feb 2016 |newspaper=[[The Globe and Mail]] |date=24 Aug 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160213035308/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/british-columbia/human-feet-washed-up-in-bc-identified/article4263242/|archivedate=13 February 2016 |location=Vancouver |origyear=25 May 2011 }}</ref> This type of shoe was sold in Canada and the United States between February 1, 2003, and June 30, 2003.<ref name="CBC July 10, 2008"/> It has been confirmed that the right foot found February 8 on Valdes Island and left foot found on June 16 on Westham Island belonged to the same man.<ref name="CBC July 10, 2008">{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/2-of-5-feet-found-on-b-c-coast-belong-to-same-man-rcmp-1.738354|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cbc.ca%2Fnews%2Fcanada%2Fbritish-columbia%2F2-of-5-feet-found-on-b-c-coast-belong-to-same-man-rcmp-1.738354&date=2016-02-12|archivedate=12 Feb 2016|title=2 of 5 feet found on B.C. coast belong to same man: RCMP|date=10 Jul 2008|accessdate=12 Feb 2016|work=[[CBC News]]}}</ref><ref name=fong>{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2008/07/10/two_mystery_feet_from_same_person_bc_police_say.html |date=10 Jul 2008 |accessdate=10 Jul 2008|title=Two mystery feet from same person, B.C. police say |newspaper=[[Toronto Star]]|first=Petti |last= Fong}}</ref>|| {{coord|name=February 8, 2008|49.083333|-123.666667|display=inline|region:CA_type:isle}} |- | align="center" valign="top"|4 || nowrap valign="top"| May 22, 2008 || [[Kirkland Island]], BC, Canada || A woman's right foot;<ref name="CBC June 17, 2008">{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/british-columbia/story/2008/06/16/bc-fifth-foot-found.html|date=17 Jun 2008|accessdate=18 Jun 2008|title=5th foot found on B.C.'s south coast|work=[[CBC News]]}}</ref> blue-and-white New Balance sneaker. The fourth foot was discovered on an island in the [[Fraser River|Fraser Delta]] between [[Richmond, British Columbia|Richmond]] and [[Delta, British Columbia]]. It was also wearing a sock and sneaker.<ref name="CBC May 24, 2008">{{cite news|accessdate=18 Jun 2008|title=Fourth right foot washes up near Vancouver, RCMP confirm|work=[[CBC News]]|url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/british-columbia/story/2008/05/22/bc-severed-foot-richmond.html|date=24 May 2008}}</ref> It is thought to have washed down the Fraser River, having nothing to do with the ones found in the Gulf Islands.<ref name="Vancouver Sun May 26, 2008">{{cite news |newspaper=[[The Vancouver Sun]]|date=26 May 2008|title=Latest washed-up foot likely a woman's, says finder |page=A7 |first=Judith |last= Lavoie}}</ref> The shoe was a [[New Balance]] sneaker<ref name="Fox News Nov. 13, 2008">{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,451186,00.html|title=7th Human Foot Washes Ashore on Canadian Coast|date=13 Nov 2008|work=[[Fox News]]|accessdate=13 Nov 2008}}</ref> manufactured in 1999.<ref name="CBC July 10, 2008"/> In 2011, the fourth sneaker found in Kirkland Island was identified as being part of a pair of blue and white New Balance sneakers belonging to a woman who jumped from the Pattullo Bridge in New Westminster in April 2004.<ref>{{cite news |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111023145834/https://abcnews.go.com/blogs/headlines/2011/10/feet-that-washed-ashore-identified-as-missing-canadian-woman/ |url=https://abcnews.go.com/blogs/headlines/2011/10/feet-that-washed-ashore-identified-as-missing-canadian-woman/ |title=Feet That Washed Ashore in Northwest Identified |work=[[ABC News]] |date=21 Oct 2011 |archive-date=23 October 2011 |accessdate=9 May 2018 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> || {{coord|name=May 22, 2008|49.110905|-123.095627|display=inline|region:CA_type:isle}} |- | align="center" valign="top"|5 || nowrap valign="top"| June 16, 2008 || [[Westham Island]], BC, Canada || A man's left foot was found by two hikers on June 16, floating in water in Delta.<ref name="CBC June 17, 2008"/><ref name=Carrigg>{{cite news|title=Fifth human foot — with shoe — found floating; Two most recent finds in Fraser delta, other three off Gulf Islands|date=17 Jun 2008 |page=A3 |newspaper=[[The Province]]|first=David |last= Carrigg}}</ref> It has been confirmed that the left foot found on June 16 on Westham Island and the right foot found February 8 on Valdes Island belonged to the same man.<ref name="CBC July 10, 2008"/><ref name=fong/> || {{coord|name=June 16, 2008|49.083333|-123.15|display=inline|region:CA_type:isle}} |- | align="center" valign="top"|6 || nowrap valign="top"| August 1, 2008 || Near [[Pysht, Washington]], US || A right foot inside a man's black size 11 shoe was discovered by a camper on a beach. It was covered in seaweed. The site of the discovery was less than 16 kilometers from the international border in the [[Strait of Juan de Fuca]]. [[Genetic fingerprinting|Testing]] confirmed that the foot was human. Police say the large black-top, size 11 athletic shoe for a right foot contains bones and flesh. This was the first foot of the series to be found outside of British Columbia. The RCMP and [[Clallam County, Washington|Clallam County]] Sheriff's Department agreed on August 5 that the foot could have been carried south from Canadian waters.<ref name="CTV British Columbia August 3, 2008">{{cite news|url=http://www.ctvbc.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20080803/BC_missing_foot_080803/20080803?hub=BritishColumbiaHome|date=3 Aug 2008|accessdate=3 Aug 2008|title=Missing foot mystery deepens with latest find|work=[[CTV News]] British Columbia}}</ref><ref name="Vancouver Sun August 6, 2008">{{cite news |newspaper=[[The Vancouver Sun]]|date=6 Aug 2008|page=a6|title=Foot found in U.S. may be from Canada |first=Paige |last= Dickerson, Peninsula Daily News}}</ref> || {{coord|name=August 1, 2008|48.183333|-124.116667|display=inline|region:CA_type:isle}} |- | align="center" valign="top"|7 || nowrap valign="top"| November 11, 2008 || [[Richmond, British Columbia|Richmond]], BC, Canada || A known woman's left foot, in a shoe that was found floating in the Fraser River in Richmond.<ref name="CTV November 11, 2008">{{cite news|url=http://www.ctvbc.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20081111/BC_missing_foot_November_081111/20081112/?hub=BritishColumbiaHome|title=Another severed foot washes up on B.C. shore |date=11 Nov 2008|work=[[CTV News]]|accessdate=11 Nov 2008}}</ref> The shoe was described as a small New Balance running shoe, possibly a woman's shoe.<ref name="Fox News Nov. 13, 2008"/> A forensic [[DNA profiling]] analysis indicated that it was a genetic match to the foot discovered on May 22 on Kirkland Island.<ref name="match7">{{Cite news |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20081205.wbcfeet1205/BNStory/National/home |title=DNA tests match feet washed ashore |work=The Globe and Mail |first=Ian |last= Bailey |date=5 Dec 2008 |accessdate=6 Dec 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081206053915/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20081205.wbcfeet1205/BNStory/National/home |archivedate=6 December 2008 |location=Toronto}}</ref> || {{coord|name=November 11, 2008|49.108|-123.132|display=inline|region:CA}} (approximate) |- | align="center" valign="top"|8 || nowrap valign="top"| October 27, 2009 || [[Richmond, British Columbia|Richmond]], BC, Canada || A right foot in a size 8½ Nike running shoe on a beach in [[Richmond, British Columbia|Richmond]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/british-columbia/story/2009/10/28/bc-foot-found-running-shoe-richmond.html |title=Human remains in shoe found near Vancouver |work=[[CBC.ca]] |date=28 Oct 2009 |accessdate=28 Oct 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091031130948/http://www.cbc.ca/canada/british-columbia/story/2009/10/28/bc-foot-found-running-shoe-richmond.html |archivedate=31 October 2009 }}</ref> The remains were identified as a Vancouver-area man who was reported missing in January 2008.<ref>{{cite news |title=Found foot belonged to man reported missing in 2008|url=http://www.canada.com/vancouversun/news/westcoastnews/story.html?id=7d788179-999b-4115-875b-d19b3b9868cc&k=61662|accessdate=13 Feb 2016 |newspaper=[[The Vancouver Sun]]|publisher=CanWest MediaWorks Publications |date=7 Nov 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.canada.com%2Fvancouversun%2Fnews%2Fwestcoastnews%2Fstory.html%3Fid%3D7d788179-999b-4115-875b-d19b3b9868cc%26k%3D61662&date=2016-02-12|archivedate=13 Feb 2016|via= Postmedia Network}}</ref> || {{coord|name=October 27, 2009|49.166667|-123.133333|display=inline|region:CA}} (approximate) |- | align="center" valign="top"|9 || nowrap valign="top"| August 27, 2010 || [[Whidbey Island]], Washington, US || A woman's or child's<ref>{{cite news |title=Human foot washes ashore on Whidbey Island|author=KOMO-TV Staff |date=27 Aug 2010 |url=http://www.seattlepi.com/local/425768_foot27.html |accessdate=27 Aug 2010 |newspaper=[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]] }}</ref> right foot, without a shoe or sock. This foot was determined to have been in the water for two months. Detective Ed Wallace of the [[Island County, Washington|Island County]] Sheriff's Office released a statement saying the foot would be tested for DNA.<ref>{{cite news | title=Human foot found on West Coast beach|author=CBC News|date=27 Aug 2010 |url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/british-columbia/story/2010/08/27/bc-washington-foot-whidbey.html#ixzz0y92pT5cO}}</ref> However, there was no match found in the national DNA database.<ref>{{cite news | title=No DNA match found for human foot found on Whidbey Island |website=MyNorthwest|date=30 Mar 2011|url=http://mynorthwest.com/?nid=189&sid=454145}}</ref> || {{coord|name=August 27, 2010|48.083333|-122.566667|display=inline|region:US-WA_type:isle}} |- | align="center" valign="top"|10 || nowrap valign="top"| December 5, 2010 || [[Tacoma, Washington|Tacoma]], Washington, US || Found on the tidal flats. "The right foot was still inside a boy's size 6 'Ozark Trail' [[hiking boot]], and likely belonged to a juvenile or small adult," police spokesman Mark Fulghum said Tuesday in Tacoma, about 40 kilometers south of Seattle and 225 kilometers south of Vancouver.<ref>{{cite news | title = Tenth foot washes up, on beach near Tacoma | date = 16 Dec 2010 | url = http://www.canada.com/vancouversun/news/westcoastnews/story.html?id=9c614eec-edee-4f14-aef0-677989e741af | work = Vancouver Sun | accessdate = 17 Dec 2010 | quote = On Dec. 5, a man walking along the shore spotted the foot and called police. | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150629003146/http://www.canada.com/vancouversun/news/westcoastnews/story.html?id=9c614eec-edee-4f14-aef0-677989e741af | archivedate = 29 June 2015 }}</ref> || {{coord|name=December 5, 2010|47.286|-122.441|display=inline|region:US-WA}} (approximate) |- | align="center" valign="top"|11 || nowrap valign="top"| August 30, 2011 || [[False Creek]], BC, Canada || Sex unknown. The foot was found in a man's white and blue size 9 runner, floating next to the Plaza of Nations marina, attached to the lower leg bones.<ref name="Huffington Post, August 31, 2011">{{cite news |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2011/08/31/vancouver-foot-human-autopsy_n_944292.html |title=Vancouver Foot Is Human: Autopsy Report |date=31 Aug 2011 |website=[[Huffington Post]] |accessdate=10 Sep 2011}}</ref> It had disarticulated naturally at the knee due to the water.<ref name="Ministry of Public Safety and Solicitor General, BC Coroners Service, August 31, 2011">{{cite news |url=https://archive.news.gov.bc.ca/releases/news_releases_2009-2013/2011PSSG0101-001089.htm |title=Coroner investigates remains found in False Creek |date=31 Aug 2011 |publisher=Ministry of Public Safety and Solicitor General |accessdate=10 Sep 2011 }}</ref> || {{coord|name=August 30, 2011|49.275|-123.110|display=inline|region:CA}} |- | align="center" valign="top"|12 || nowrap valign="top"| November 4, 2011 || [[Sasamat Lake]], BC, Canada || A man's right foot inside a size 12 hiking boot was discovered by a group of campers in a pool of fresh water at [[Sasamat Lake]] near Port Moody.<ref name="Huffington Post, November 10, 2011">{{cite news |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/11/09/human-foot-found-in-sasam_n_1085165.html |title=Human Foot found in Sasamat Lake, Canada |date=10 Nov 2011 |work=[[Huffington Post]] |accessdate=19 Nov 2011 |first=Michael |last=McLaughlin}}</ref> In January 2012, this foot was identified by the B.C. Coroner's Service as that of Stefan Zahorujko,<ref name="CBC News, February 18, 2012">{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/story/2012/02/17/bc-sasamat-lake-foot.html |accessdate=18 Feb 2012 | work=[[CBC News]] |title=Foot found in B.C. lake identified after 25 years |date=18 Feb 2012}}</ref> a local fisherman who went missing in 1987. Police believe the foot separated naturally from the body and do not suspect foul play.<ref name="Vancouver Sun, November 8, 2011">{{cite news |url=https://vancouversun.com/Foot+lake+linked+foul+play/5673315/story.html |title=Foot in lake not linked to foul play |work=[[The Vancouver Sun]] |accessdate=19 Nov 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111114075655/http://www.vancouversun.com/Foot+lake+linked+foul+play/5673315/story.html |archivedate=14 November 2011}}</ref> || {{coord|name=November 4, 2011|49.323|-122.889|display=inline|region:CA}} |- | align="center" valign="top"|13 || nowrap valign="top"| December 10, 2011 || [[Lake Union]], Seattle, Washington, US || Human leg bone and foot in a black plastic bag under the Ship Canal Bridge.<ref name=Heffter2011>{{citation |url= https://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/human-remains-found-in-eastlake-neighborhood/ |newspaper= [[The Seattle Times]] |title= Human remains found in Eastlake neighborhood |date=10 Dec 2011 |first= Emily |last= Heffter }}</ref> As of January 2, 2012, the medical examiner had not found a cause of death or identified the body.<ref name=McNerthney2012>{{cite news |url= https://www.seattlepi.com/local/article/List-of-2011-homicides-in-Seattle-2433596.php |work=[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]] |title= List of 2011 homicides in Seattle; City's homicide rate on 1950s pace |first= Casey |last= McNerthney |date= 2 Jan 2012 }}</ref> || {{coord|name=December 10, 2011|47.652|-122.323|display=inline|region:US-WA}} |- | align="center" valign="top"|14 || nowrap valign="top"| January 26, 2012 || [[Vancouver]], BC, Canada || On January 26, 2012, the remains of "what appears to be human bones inside a boot" were found in the sand along the water line at the dog park near the Maritime Museum at the foot of Arbutus Street, in Vancouver.<ref name="VPD News release, Jan 26, 2012">{{cite web |url=http://mediareleases.vpd.ca/2012/01/26/possible-human-remains-found-washed-up-in-shoe/ |title=Possible Human Remains Found Washed Up in Shoe |website=[[Vancouver Police Department]] |date=26 Jan 2012 |accessdate=18 Feb 2012}}</ref> || {{coord|name=January 26, 2012|49.278|-123.151|display=inline|region:CA}} |- | align="center" valign="top"|15 || nowrap valign="top"| May 6, 2014 || [[Seattle]], Washington, US || Human foot in white New Balance shoe found along the shoreline of Centennial Park near the Pier 86 grain terminal.<ref name="Q13 Fox, 6 May 2014">{{cite news |url=http://q13fox.com/2014/05/06/foot-washes-ashore-on-seattle-waterfront/ |title=Human foot in tennis shoe washes ashore in Seattle |work=Q13 Fox News |date=6 May 2014 |accessdate=9 May 2018}}</ref> The New Balance model 622 athletic shoe was white with blue trim, size men's 10½. This model of shoe was first available for sale in April 2008.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://q13fox.com/2014/05/07/do-you-recognize-it-photo-released-of-shoe-found-with-foot-in-it/#7CkK7s1xk6tzVUoe.99 |title=Foot in shoe that washed ashore in Seattle likely not severed |work=Q13 Fox News |date=7 May 2014 |accessdate=9 May 2018}}</ref><ref name="Q13 Fox, 6 May 2014"/><ref>{{cite news |url=http://blogs.seattletimes.com/today/2014/05/human-foot-in-sneaker-found-on-seattle-waterfront/ |title=Human Foot in Sneaker Found on Seattle Waterfront |work=[[Seattle Times]] |date=6 May 2014}}</ref> From an initial news photo, it appears to be a left foot.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://bc.ctvnews.ca/human-foot-found-on-seattle-waterfront-1.1809501 |title=Human Foot Found on Seattle Waterfront |work=[[CTV News]] |date=6 May 2014 |accessdate=9 May 2018}}</ref>|| {{coord|name=May 6, 2014|47.626|-122.373|display=inline|region:US-WA}} |- | align="center" valign="top"|16 || nowrap valign="top"| February 7, 2016 || [[Vancouver Island]], BC, Canada || Hikers on [[Botanical Beach, British Columbia|Botanical Beach]], near [[Port Renfrew]] on Vancouver Island, found a foot in a sock and running shoe.<ref>{{Citation |url=http://www.vancitybuzz.com/2016/02/severed-human-foot-vancouver-island/ |title= Severed human foot found washed ashore on Vancouver Island |first=Lauren |last=Sundstrom |date=10 Feb 2016 |newspaper=Vancity Buzz }}</ref><ref>{{Citation |newspaper=Times Colonist |title=Human foot found in shoe at Botanical Beach |first= Carla |last= Wilson |date=9 Feb 2016 |url=http://www.timescolonist.com/news/local/human-foot-found-in-shoe-at-botanical-beach-1.2169059 }}</ref> || {{coord|name=Feb 10, 2016|48.530|-124.445|display=inline|region:CA}} |- | align="center" valign="top"|17 || nowrap valign="top"| February 12, 2016 || [[Vancouver Island]], BC, Canada || A foot washed up near [[Port Renfrew]] on Vancouver Island. BC Coroners Service said it matches one found there five days earlier.<ref>{{Citation |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/british-columbia/second-foot-washed-up-in-bc-matches-first-confirmed-to-be-human-coroner/article28779883/ |title= Second foot washed up in B.C. matches first, confirmed to be human: coroner |date=17 Feb 2016 |newspaper=Canadian Press }}</ref>||{{coord|name=Feb 10, 2016|48.530|-124.445|display=inline|region:CA}} (approximate) |- | align="center" valign="top"|18 || nowrap valign="top"| December 8, 2017 || [[Vancouver Island]], BC, Canada || Remains of a leg with a shoe attached washed up on the near the settlement of [[Jordan River, British Columbia|Jordan River]] on Vancouver Island.<ref>{{Citation |url=http://victoriabuzz.com/2017/12/police-investigate-human-foot-found-jordan-river-beach-thursday/ |title=Police Investigate Human Foot Found at Jordan River beach Thursday |date=8 Dec 2017 |newspaper=Victoria Buzz}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.boston.com/news/world-news/2017/12/12/another-human-foot-washes-ashore-in-canada-that-makes-13| title=Another human foot washes ashore in Canada. That makes 13.| first=Matthew| last=Haag| date=12 Dec 2017| website=boston.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.bild.de/news/ausland/leiche/fuss-fund-kanada-54199584.bild.html| title=13 Füße in zehn Jahren angeschwemmt| date=15 Dec 2017| website=bild.de}}</ref> || {{coord|name=December 8, 2017 |48.420572| -124.044690|display=inline|region:CA}} |- | align="center" valign="top"|19 || nowrap valign="top"| May 6, 2018 || [[Gabriola Island]], BC, Canada || Shortly after noon on Sunday 6 May,<ref name="CTV News, 7 May 2018">{{cite news|url=https://vancouverisland.ctvnews.ca/human-foot-found-on-gabriola-island-sparks-investigation-1.3918943|title=Human foot found on Gabriola Island sparks investigation|date=7 May 2018|work=[[CTV News]]|accessdate=9 May 2018}}</ref> a man walking along the shore on Gabriola Island encountered a hiking boot, with a human foot inside, wedged in a logjam.<ref name="Global News, 9 May 2018">{{cite news|url=https://globalnews.ca/news/4192777/feet-washes-ashore-bc/|title=Another human foot washes up on B.C. shores|date=9 May 2018|work=[[Global News]]|accessdate=9 May 2018}}</ref>|| |- |} {{GeoGroupTemplate}}
===Hoaxes=== Another "human" foot, discovered on June 18, 2008, on Tyee Spit near [[Campbell River, British Columbia|Campbell River]] on [[Vancouver Island]],<ref name="CBC June 18 2008">{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/british-columbia/story/2008/06/18/bc-sixth-foot-found.html|date=18 Jun 2008| accessdate=18 Jun 2008 |title=6th foot found on B.C. south coast |work=[[CBC News]]}}</ref> was a [[hoax]].<ref name="CNN June 19, 2008">{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2008/CRIME/06/19/canada.feet/index.html |date=18 Jun 2008|accessdate=18 Jun 2008|title=Latest floating 'foot' turns out to be a hoax |work=[[CNN]]}}</ref> The hoax was a "skeletonized animal paw" which was put in a sock and shoe and then stuffed with dried seaweed. [[Royal Canadian Mounted Police]] launched an investigation into the hoax and an arrest could be made due to charges of [[mischief|public mischief]].<ref name="CBC June 18 2008 Foot Hoax">{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/foot-hoax-on-b-c-south-coast-despicable-police-1.711228 |date=18 Jun 2008|accessdate=18 Jun 2008|title='Foot' hoax on B.C. south coast despicable: police|work=[[CBC News]]}}</ref>{{update after|2018|1|19}}
After the eleventh foot was found on August 31, 2011, several running shoes containing what police suspected was raw meat were found washed up on Oak Beach, British Columbia.<ref name="ABCNews September 06, 2011">{{cite news |url=http://abcnews.go.com/blogs/headlines/2011/09/latest-feet-to-wash-ashore-in-canada-a-hoax-police-say/ |date=6 Sep 2011 |accessdate=10 Sep 2011 |title=Latest Floating Feet Are a Hoax, Police Say |work=[[ABC News]]}}</ref>
==Proposed explanations==
The series of discoveries has been called "astounding" and "almost beyond explanation", as no other body parts have turned up.<ref name="Vancouver Sun May 24, 2008">{{cite news|title=A fourth foot deepens the mystery; The severed-feet explanation is 'beyond imagination,' expert says after latest find|date=24 May 2008 |page=B1 |first=Gary |last= Bellett|newspaper=[[The Vancouver Sun]]}} Original article wrote five bodies, but it has since been confirmed that two of the feet belong to the same person.</ref> The discoveries have caused speculation that the feet may be those of people who died in a boating accident or a plane crash in the ocean.<ref name="CBC August 31, 2007"/> One explanation is that some of the feet are those of four men who died in a plane crash near [[Quadra Island]] in 2005 and whose bodies have not been recovered, though one of the feet has been determined to be from a female.<ref name="CBC May 24, 2008"/> [[Crime|Foul play]] has also been suggested,<ref name="The Province May 23, 2008">{{cite news|title=Fourth foot fuels flotsam frenzy; Still no clues after boater's discovery in Richmond |first=Cheryl |last= Chan |date=23 May 2008 |page=A4}}</ref> although none of the first four feet showed tool marks.<ref name="CNN June 19, 2008"/> This does not rule out foul play, however; it is possible that the bodies could have been weighted down and disposed of, and the feet were separated due to natural decay.
Determining the origin of the feet is complicated because [[ocean currents]] may carry floating items long distances,<ref name="CBC News June 17, 2008 B">{{cite news|title=Mysterious feet may be linked to single accident: B.C. forensic expert |date=17 Jun 2008 |accessdate=18 Jun 2008 |url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/british-columbia/story/2008/06/17/bc-forensic-feet-connection.html |work=[[CBC News]]}}</ref> and because currents in the [[Strait of Georgia]] are unpredictable.<ref name="The Province May 23, 2008"/> A foot may float as far as {{convert|1000|mi|km}}.<ref name="CNN June 19, 2008"/> Also, human feet have a tendency to produce [[adipocere]] (a soap-like substance formed from [[animal fat|body fat]]), which makes it hard for forensic scientists to find clues.<ref name="The Province Feb 15 2008">{{cite news |page=A3|newspaper=[[The Province]]|date=15 Feb 2008|title=Human right foot found on Valdes; This is the third foot to wash up on a Gulf Island within a year;}}</ref> Under optimal conditions, a human body may remain intact in water for as long as three decades, meaning that the feet may have been floating around for years.<ref name="Heiman">{{cite news |date=25 May 2005 |page=A9|title=Families of victims seek expert's help |first=Carolyn |last= Heiman |newspaper=[[The Province]]}}</ref>
Another theory is that the feet belonged to people who died in the [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami|Asian tsunami]] on December 26, 2004. Richmond-based writer Shane Lambert said that many of the shoes found were manufactured and sold in 2004 or earlier, and that there could be other sources for the shoes or multiple sources. However, besides the dates when the shoes were manufactured, Lambert said ocean currents and their ultimate northward tendencies up the Pacific Ocean from part of the region that was hit by the 2004 tsunami.<ref>{{cite web|first=Shane|last=Lambert|title=Human Feet in the Pacific Northwest – a Better Theory?|url=https://treepony.com/human-feet-in-the-pacific-northwest-a-better-theory/|website=Tree Pony|date=December 16, 2010}}</ref>
One foot has been identified as belonging to a man who was depressed and was believed to have committed suicide.<ref name="CTV November 11, 2008"/><ref name="MSNBC June 6, 2011"/> Another two feet were identified as belonging to a woman who committed suicide by jumping from the [[Pattullo Bridge]] ({{coord|display=inline|name=Pattullo Bridge|49.207575|N|122.894654|W}}) in [[New Westminster]], B.C., in 2004.<ref name="HuffPost 19 Oct 2011">{{cite news |title=B.C. Feet Mystery Partly Solved, As Coroner Identifies Female Suicide Victim |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2011/10/19/bc-feet-mystery-coroner_n_1020772.html |work=[[HuffPost]] |date=19 Oct 2011 |accessdate=9 May 2018}}</ref> This suggests the feet could belong to other people who have [[Jumper (suicide)|jumped from the bridge]] .
==Level of rarity== [[Decomposition]] may separate the foot from the body because the [[ankle]] is relatively weak, and the buoyancy caused by air either inside or trapped within a shoe would allow it to float away.<ref name="Vancouver Sun Aug 31 2007"/> According to [[Simon Fraser University]] [[forensic entomology|entomologist]] Gail Anderson, extremities such as the hands, feet, and head often detach as a body decomposes in the water, although they rarely float.<ref name="The Province Feb 15 2008"/>
However, finding feet and not the rest of the bodies has been deemed unusual. Finding two feet has been given a "million to one odds" and has thus been described as "an anomaly".<ref name="Vancouver Sun Aug 31 2007"/> The finding of the third foot made it the first time three such discoveries had been made so close to each other.<ref name="The Province Feb 15 2008"/> The fourth discovery caused speculation about human interference and, statistically, was called "curious".<ref name="Heiman"/>
==Media reaction== A newspaper article in February 2008 captured [[Jørn Lier Horst]]'s attention and he began to write ''Dregs''; while writing, the discovery of a fourth foot was made public.<ref>{{Cite web| url = http://murderiseverywhere.blogspot.ca/2015/08/mystery-of-disembodied-feet.html| title = Mystery of the Disembodied Feet| first = Jorn Lier |last= Horst |authorlink= Jørn Lier Horst | date =19 Aug 2015| accessdate = 9 Oct 2016}}</ref>
After the fifth foot was discovered the story had begun to receive increased international media attention. With major headlines from newspapers such as the Melbourne ''[[Herald Sun]]'', ''[[The Guardian]]'', and the ''[[Cape Times]]'' in South Africa, the story elicited much speculation about the cause of the mystery, originating from "morbid fascination" with this type of subject, as stated by one scientist who identifies remains of victims.<ref name="mediareaction1">{{cite news | url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/life/fascinated-by-bcs-floating-feet/article44528/ | title=Fascinated by B.C.'s floating feet | first=Patrick |last= White | newspaper=[[The Globe and Mail]] | date=20 Jun 2008 | accessdate=2 Nov 2009 | location=Toronto}}</ref> On his late night talk show [[David Letterman]] questioned two of his audience members who were Canadian about the mystery.<ref name="mediareaction2">{{cite web | url=https://thetyee.ca/Mediacheck/2008/06/26/HorrificBC/ | title=Super, Horrific BC | first=Vanessa |last=Richmond | newspaper=[[The Tyee]] | date=26 Jun 2008 | accessdate=2 Nov 2009}}</ref>
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
==References== * {{citation |url= http://www.cbc.ca/bc/features/found-feet/ |title=Found feet; Human feet found near B.C. shores since August 2007 [interactive map of discoveries] |work=CBC News |date=November 8, 2011 }} * {{citation |publisher=NPR |format=podcast |work=How To Do Everything |date= May 14, 2014 |episode=157 |title= Human Feet and Graham Crackers |url= http://howtodoeverything.org/post/87393249735/how-to-have-less-fun-at-the-beach-and-how-to }} * {{citation |work=[[Stuff You Should Know]] |date= June 2016 |url= http://www.stuffyoushouldknow.com/podcasts/why-are-so-many-disembodied-feet-washing-ashore-in-british-columbia/ |title= Why Are So Many Disembodied Feet Washing Ashore In British Columbia? |first=Josh |last= Clark |format=podcast}}
{{Unidentified decedent}}

page.title: Terrorism in the British Indian Ocean Territory

revision.text:
'''The British Indian Ocean Territory''', sometimes known as the [[Chagos Archipelago]] has had many threats of occupation by various groups, especially the since the [[Depopulation of Chagossians from the Chagos Archipelago]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/nov/17/mauritius-threatens-to-take-chagos-islands-row-to-un-court|title=Mauritius threatens to take Chagos Islands row to UN court|first=Owen Bowcott Legal affairs|last=correspondent|date=17 November 2016|publisher=|via=The Guardian}}</ref> as well as being a joint UK-US facility that is used in countering terrorism. The UK maintains there is a low risk of terrorism in this territory.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/british-indian-ocean-territory/terrorism|title=Terrorism - British Indian Ocean Territory travel advice - GOV.UK|website=www.gov.uk}}</ref>
=="Secret" Prison== [[File:Diego Garcia Island Map.jpg|thumb|A map of military installations on Diego Garcia in 2002]] In 2008 it was exposed in [[TIME]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://content.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1828469,00.html|title=Source: US Used UK Isle for Interrogations|first=Adam|last=Zagorin|date=31 July 2008|publisher=|via=content.time.com}}</ref> magazine by [[Lawrence Wilkerson]] that a secret [[War on Terror]] prison had existed on the island of [[Diego Garcia]] from 2002–2006. He claimed that Diego Garcia was used by the [[CIA]] for "nefarious activities". He said that he had heard from three US intelligence sources that Diego Garcia was used as "a transit site where people were temporarily housed, let us say, and interrogated from time to time" and, "What I heard was more along the lines of using it as a transit location when perhaps other places were full or other places were deemed too dangerous or insecure, or unavailable at the moment".<ref name="guardian-20150130">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/jan/30/cia-interrogation-diego-garcia-lawrence-wilkerson |title=CIA interrogated suspects on Diego Garcia, says Colin Powell aide |author=Ian Cobain |newspaper=The Guardian |date=30 January 2015 |accessdate=27 February 2015}}</ref><ref name="telegraph-20150130">{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/terrorism-in-the-uk/11380992/Terror-suspects-were-interrogated-on-Diego-Garcia-US-official-admits.html |title=Terror suspects were interrogated on Diego Garcia, US official admits |agency=Press Association |newspaper=Daily Telegraph |date=30 January 2015 |accessdate=27 February 2015}}</ref>
In June 2004, the British [[Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs|Foreign Secretary]] [[Jack Straw]] stated that United States authorities had repeatedly assured him that no detainees had passed in transit through Diego Garcia or were disembarked there.<ref>{{Cite journal| title=Written Answers to Questions 21 June 2004 | journal=Hansard House of Commons Daily Debates| publisher=UK Parliament | volume= 422 | issue=part 605 | url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200304/cmhansrd/vo040621/text/40621w13.htm#40621w13.html_wqn9 | accessdate=2008-02-21 | format= – <sup>[https://scholar.google.co.uk/scholar?hl=en&lr=&q=intitle%3AWritten+Answers+to+Questions+%5B%5B21+June%5D%5D+%5B%5B2004%5D%5D&as_publication=Hansard+House+of+Commons+Daily+Debates&as_ylo=&as_yhi=&btnG=Search Scholar search]</sup>}}</ref>
Diego Garcia was first rumoured to have been one of the locations of the [[CIA]]'s [[black sites]] in 2005.<ref name=TorStar20050702>{{cite news | url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/org/news/2005/050702-island-torture.htm | title=Island paradise or torture chamber? | publisher=[[The Toronto Star]] | author=Lynda Hurst | date=July 2, 2005 | accessdate=October 14, 2007}}</ref> [[Khalid Sheikh Mohammed]] is one of the "[[high-value detainees]]" suspected to have been held in Diego Garcia.<ref name=AssociatePress20060316>{{cite news | url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/org/news/2006/060316-detainee-transcripts.htm | title=Detainee transcripts reveal more questions | agency=Associated Press | author=Andrew Selsky | date=March 16, 2006 | accessdate=October 14, 2007}}</ref> In October 2007, the [[Foreign Affairs Select Committee]] of the British Parliament announced that it would launch an investigation of continued allegations of a prison camp on Diego Garcia, which it claimed were twice confirmed by comments made by retired United States Army General [[Barry McCaffrey]].<ref name=guardian>{{Cite news| author1=Ian Cobain |author2=Richard Norton-Taylor | url=https://www.theguardian.com/usa/story/0,,2194649,00.html | title=Claims of secret CIA jail for terror suspects on British island to be investigated | work=The Guardian | date=2007-10-19 | accessdate=2007-10-21 | location=London}}</ref> On 31 July 2008, an unnamed former White House official alleged that the United States had imprisoned and interrogated at least one suspect on Diego Garcia during 2002 and possibly 2003.<ref>{{Cite news| url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1828469,00.html | work=Time | title=Source: US Used UK Isle for Interrogations | date=2008-07-31 | accessdate=2010-05-01 | first=Adam | last=Zagorin}}</ref>
The existence of the site was confirmed by US general [[Barry McCaffrey]], and Swiss Senator [[Dick Marty]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2008/aug/04/humanrights.terrorism|title=Diego Garcia: the UK's shame|date=4 August 2008|publisher=|via=The Guardian}}</ref> Also, [[Manfred Nowak]], one of five of the [[United Nations Special Rapporteur]] on [[torture]], says that credible evidence exists supporting allegations that ships serving as black sites have used Diego Garcia as a base.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2007/oct/19/alqaida.usa |title=Claims of secret CIA jail for terror suspects on British island to be investigated |first1=Ian |last1=Cobain |author2=Richard Norton-Taylor |publisher=''[[The Guardian]]'' |date=19 October 2007}}</ref> The human rights group [[Reprieve (organisation)|Reprieve]] alleges that United States-operated ships moored outside the [[territorial waters]] of Diego Garcia were used to incarcerate and torture detainees.<ref>{{Cite news| author=Jamie Doward | title=British island 'used by US for rendition' | url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2008/mar/02/ciarendition.unitednations | work=The Observer | date=2008-03-02 | accessdate=2008-03-27 | location=London}}</ref>
Inmates included [[Mustafa Setmariam Nasar]], and [[Riduan Isamuddin]] was held there before being transferred to [[Guantanamo Bay detention camp]]. The United Kingdom government, who lease the island to the US, denied any knowledge of the incident, saying that two prisoners had passed through Diego Garcia but the plane they were on had only stopped to refuel. Nasar's location is still unknown since his arrival on Diego Garcia was announced in Spanish newspaper ''[[El Pais]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://elpais.com/diario/2008/05/18/domingo/1211082753_850215.html|title=Reportaje - Un 'yihadista' en el limbo|first=Ediciones El|last=País|date=18 May 2008|publisher=}}</ref>
On December 9, 2014, the [[United States Senate Intelligence Committee]] published a 600-page unclassified summary of its 6,700 page secret report on the CIA's abuse of its secret prisoners.<ref name="DailyMail2014-12-20"> {{cite news | url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2881451/Is-speck-Indian-Ocean-Britain-s-Guantanamo-Chilling-questions-raised-secretive-island-disturbing-allegations-emerge-UK-s-role-CIA-torture.html | title = Is this speck in the Indian Ocean Britain's Guantanamo? Chilling questions raised over secretive island as more disturbing allegations emerge over UK's role in CIA torture | publisher = [[Daily Mail]] | author = David Jones | date = 2014-12-20 | page = | location = | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.dailymail.co.uk%2Fnews%2Farticle-2881451%2FIs-speck-Indian-Ocean-Britain-s-Guantanamo-Chilling-questions-raised-secretive-island-disturbing-allegations-emerge-UK-s-role-CIA-torture.html&date=2014-12-20 | archivedate = 2014-12-20 | deadurl = No | quote = Given the weight of evidence proving that Diego Garcia was — at the very least — a key staging post in the U.S. rendition and torture programme, it had been widely expected to feature in the dossier, thus exposing Britain’s involvement beyond doubt. That the island was not mentioned once in almost 500 heavily redacted pages has merely heightened suspicion of an MI6-orchestrated cover-up. }} </ref> David Jones, writing in the ''[[Daily Mail]]'', expressed surprise that Diego Garcia went entirely unmentioned on every page of the unclassified summary, and speculated that pressure from UK security agencies caused the portions of the report that covered CIA prisoner facilities on the island to remain classified.
==References== <references />

{{other uses|Ghost in the machine (disambiguation)}} {{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} {{Refimprove|date=October 2011}} {{Infobox book | title_orig = | translator = | image = File:TheGhostInTheMachine.jpg | caption = First UK edition | author = [[Arthur Koestler]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = | language = | subject = Philosophy, [[psychiatry]] | genre = | publisher = [[Hutchinson (publisher)|Hutchinson]] (UK)
[[Macmillan Publishers (United States)|Macmillan]] (US) | release_date = 1967 | english_release_date= | media_type = Print | pages = 381 (UK), 384 (US) | isbn = }} '''''The Ghost in the Machine''''' is a 1967 book about [[Theoretical psychology|philosophical psychology]] by [[Arthur Koestler]]. The title is a phrase (see [[ghost in the machine]]) coined by the Oxford philosopher [[Gilbert Ryle]] to describe the Cartesian dualist account of the mind–body relationship. Koestler shares with Ryle the view that the mind of a person is not an independent non-material entity, temporarily inhabiting and governing the body. The work attempts to explain humanity's self-destructive tendency in terms of individual and collective functioning, philosophy, and overarching, cyclical political–historical dynamics, peaking in the [[nuclear weapon]]s arena. ==Overview== In an attempt to explain human violence, Koestler criticizes the dominant conceptions of psychology of his time (behaviorism) that postulate that human behaviors are subject to the selection of the fittest. For him this theory echoed the Darwinian conceptions of the evolution of species. Koestler refutes both theories. The book contributes also to the longstanding debate surrounding the [[mind–body problem]] and focusing in particular on [[René Descartes]]'s [[Cartesian dualism|dualism]], in the form elucidated by Ryle. Koestler's [[Materialism|materialistic]] account argues that the personal experience of [[Mind-body dualism|duality]] arises from what Koestler calls a ''[[Holon (philosophy)|holon]]''. The notion of a holon emerges from the observation that everything in the nature is both a whole and a part. It is true for atoms who are a whole in themselves, but also a part of a molecule, of atom who could be a whole and part of cell, of cells who are both an autonomous unity and part of an organism. It is also true for human beings who have an independent life and are part of social systems. Every holon is willing to express two contradictory tendencies : to express himself, and to disappear in something greater. For human, those tendencies lead to an error in the development : we create collectives units who are based on the oppression of some individuals and on inflated ego of others. This is for Koestler an error of transcendence that is reflected in a poor integration of our reptilian brain and cognitive brain. A superposition of forces manifests, at each bodily holon, as the outcome of an entire hierarchy of forces—[[Ontogeny|ontogenetic]], [[habit (psychology)|habit]]ual, [[linguistic prescription|linguistic prescriptive]], and [[social science]]—operating in a continuum of independent feedback and feedforward streams of a body extended to its larger environment. The streams are fed by the life signals of each and every group member, and this fully participative medley is the spirit of life one senses as a ghost; but this spirit is just a simplified output of a complex knowledge set; it is [[Emergentism|emergent]] from the [[Complex adaptive system|complexity]] of the group's rules and strategies. He contrasts ''his'' basic approach to the mind–body problem with [[behaviorism]]'s basic approach to the problem.The book is vehemently critical of [[Burrhus Frederic Skinner|B. F. Skinner]]'s [[Behaviorism|Behaviorist]] theory of [[psychology]]. Following the holon of humanity down to its roots, the work explains humanity's tendency toward self-destruction in terms of brain structure, philosophies, and its overarching, cyclical political–historical dynamics, reaching the height of its potential in the nuclear arms arena. One of the book's central concepts is that as the human [[triune brain]] has evolved, it has retained and built upon earlier, more primitive brain structures. The head portion of the "[[ghost in the machine]]" has, as a consequence of poor, inadequate connections, a rich potential for conflict. The primitive layers can, and may, together, overpower rational logic's hold. This explains a person's [[hate]], [[anger]] and other such [[Stress (medicine)|emotional distress]]. In ''[[Janus: A Summing Up]]'' (1978) Koestler continues the theories developed in ''The Ghost in the Machine'' and further elaborates on the concept of [[holarchy]]. ==Publication details== * {{cite book |last=Koestler |first=Arthur |authorlink=Arthur Koestler |title=The Ghost in the Machine |year=1967 |edition=1990 reprint |publisher=[[Penguin Group]] |isbn=0-14-019192-5}} ==See also== * [[Emergent materialism]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Arthur Koestler}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ghost in the Machine}} [[Category:1967 books]] [[Category:Books by Arthur Koestler]] [[Category:Cognitive science literature]] [[Category:Consciousness studies]] [[Category:Philosophy of mind literature]] [[Category:Hutchinson (publisher) books]] [[Category:Emergence]]

{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} An '''V1-morph''' is an organism that changes in shape during growth such that its surface area is proportional to its volume to the power 1, so to its volume. In most cases both volume and surface area are proportional to length
The reason the concept is important in the context of the [[Dynamic Energy Budget]] theory is that food (substrate) uptake is proportional to surface area, and maintenance to volume. The surface area that is of importance is that part that is involved in substrate uptake.Since uptake is proportional to maintenance for V1-morphs, there is no size control, and an organism grows exponentially at constant food (substrate) availability.
Filaments, such as fungi that form hyphae growing in length, but not in diameter, are examples of V1-morphs. Sheets that extend, but do not change in thickness, like some colonial bacteria and algae, are another example.
An important property of V1-morphs is that the distinction between the individual and the population level disappears; a single long filament grows as fast as many small ones of the same diameter and the same total length.
==See also== * [[Dynamic Energy Budget]] * [[V0-morph]] * [[isomorph]] * [[shape correction function]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:V1-Morph}} [[Category:Developmental biology]] [[Category:Metabolism]]

revision.text:
'''Vika''' or '''TGK''' is an oxygen generating system for spaceflight.<ref name=ellis>[https://www.nasa.gov/pdf/602090main_44s_international_life_support.pdf Kerry Ellis - '''International Life Support''' - Ask Magazine]</ref> It is a SFOG, or solid-fuel oxygen generator, a kind of [[chemical oxygen generator]].<ref name=ellis/> It has been used on the retired [[Mir]] space station and the [[International Space Station]].<ref name=ellis/> It was originally developed by [[Roscosmos]] to supplement the ''Elektron'' oxygen system on ''Mir''.<ref name=ellis/> A Vika module, also known as a "candle", contains about one liter of [[lithium perchlorate]] and can provide oxygen for one person for 24 hours.<ref name=ellis/>
The canister contains powdered sodium chlorate and powdered [[iron]], which when combined burns to create enough heat and temperature to break down [[sodium chlorate]] into salt (sodium chloride) and [[oxygen]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnet.com/news/breathe-deep-how-the-iss-keeps-astronauts-alive/|title=Breathe deep: How the ISS keeps astronauts alive|date=2015-03-19|work=CNET|access-date=2018-01-24|language=en}}</ref>
After being adopted for use on the ISS, it had the NASA name '''SFOG''', but they also sometimes use the Russian acronym TGK.<ref name=ellis/>
==Vika on Mir== [[Image:Linenger in Respirator.jpg|thumb|right|Astronaut [[Jerry Linenger]] wearing a respirator mask following the 1997 fire aboard ''Mir'' from an SFOG fire|alt=A man holding a piece of hose floats in front of a selection of transient space station hardware. He is wearing a gray-and-yellow plastic mask over his mouth and nose, a pair of goggles above his eyes, and a blue jumpsuit with a name patch on it.]] Vika was used on Mir when more than three people were on board.<ref name=david>[https://books.google.com/books?id=FUtZwjleT3kC&pg=PA270&lpg=PA270&dq=Vika+oxygen&source=bl&ots=c1ojtq99y3&sig=hduoB3ZcMFuPLPh4EWPy1hiWq-0&hl=en&sa=X&ei=xATsTpL5K4Xhtgfi0IimCg&ved=0CFkQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=Vika%20oxygen&f=false David Michael Harland - '''The story of the space shuttle''' (2004) - Page 270] (Google Books link)</ref> Vika needs a supply of canisters to work, which must be flown into space.<ref name=david/> An example of this is [[Progress M-34]], which carried 60 canisters to Mir in 1997 along with other cargo.<ref name=david/> If ''Vika'' and ''Elektron'' stopped working, the station would have to rely on a limited supply of bottled oxygen.<ref name=david/>
{{quote box|width=22em|The fire was a “raging blowtorch" .. |—Mir crewmember onboard during the fire<ref name=ellis/>}}
In February 1997 a Vika chemical oxygen generator failed on Mir. It caught fire and spewed a torch-like jet of a molten metal and sparks across one of the [[Mir]] [[space station]] modules, burning for around 14 minutes and blocking the escape route to the docked [[Soyuz spacecraft]].<ref name=ellis/> The fire was eventually extinguished, and the crew was not harmed.<ref name=ellis/> A definitive cause of the accident was not determined because the fire destroyed the device. It was suspected that a torn piece of rubber glove worn during assembly likely contaminated the canister.<ref name=ellis/> Despite this incident, NASA decided it was still the best supplemental oxygen system available, and supported its use on the then-upcoming ISS.<ref name=ellis/> The US and Russia worked together to improve the safety of the system before using it on the new space station.<ref name=ellis/>
==Vika on ISS==
A backup to the temperamental Elektron system used on both the ISS and ''Mir'' is the ''Vika'' solid-fuel oxygen generator (SFOG), which contains a replaceable cartridge – a thin-walled steel tube with a three-part block of oxygen-releasing mixture based on [[lithium perchlorate]]. Two parts are tablets of the chemical mixture and the third one is the igniter tablet with a flash [[igniter]]. The igniter is struck by a firing pin when the device is activated. One cartridge releases {{convert|600|l|USgal}} of oxygen and burns for 5–20 minutes at {{convert|450|-|500|C|F}}.<ref>[http://www.molecularproducts.com/products_detail.php?id=2 Oxygen Generators]</ref> The oxygen is cooled and filtered to remove dust and odours, and released into the space station atmosphere.{{citation needed|date=December 2010}} {{see also|ISS ECLSS}}
==See also== *[[Life support system]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[[:File:Environmental.pdf]] (this has a small picture of an SFOG on the bottom left) *[http://llis.nasa.gov/lesson/1143 SFOG Lessons Learned]
[[Category:Mir]] [[Category:Oxygen]] [[Category:Human spaceflight]] [[Category:Spacecraft life support systems]]

revision.text:
'''Warmed-over flavor''' is an unpleasant characteristic usually associated with [[meat]] which has been cooked and then refrigerated. The deterioration of meat flavor is most noticeable upon reheating. As cooking and subsequent refrigeration is the case with most [[convenience food]]s containing meat, it is a significant challenge to the [[Food processing|processed food]] [[Food industry|industry]]. The flavor is variously described as "rancid," "stale," and like "cardboard," and even compared to "damp dog hair."<ref name="Frank">{{ cite journal | author = Frank, P. | title = Warmed-over flavor: a processing challenge | journal = Refrigerated & Frozen Foods |date=March 2003 | volume = 2003 | issue = 3 | url = http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-100074391.html }}</ref> Warmed-over flavor is caused by the [[oxidation|oxidative]] [[decomposition]] of [[lipids]] (fatty substances) in the meat into chemicals (short-chain [[aldehydes]] or [[ketones]]) which have an unpleasant taste or odor. This decomposition process begins after cooking or processing and is aided by the release of naturally occurring [[iron]] in the meat.<ref name="Frank" />
==Appearance of warmed-over flavor== The appearance of warmed-over flavor begins as lipids, primarily lipids from the [[cell membrane]] of cells in the meat, are attacked by [[oxygen]]. This process is aided by the release of [[iron]] from iron-containing proteins in the meat, including [[myoglobin]] and [[hemoglobin]]. The iron is released by the heat of cooking, or by mechanical grinding. The free iron then acts as a [[catalyst]], or promoter, of oxidation reactions. The reactions break down some of the fats in the meat to form primary oxidation products. These chemicals are not directly responsible for the objectionable taste. Instead, they subsequently further decompose to secondary oxidation products including "[[alcohol]]s, [[acid]]s, [[ketone]]s, [[lactone]]s and [[unsaturated hydrocarbon]]s which produce the [warmed-over flavor]." Many of these compounds, including [[pentanal]], [[hexanal]], [[pentylfuran]], [[2-pentylfuran]], [[2-octenal]] and [[2,3-octanedione]] have a strong odor and can be tasted at concentrations as low as 1 part per billion.<ref name="Trout">{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1021/jf00093a017 | title = Prevention of warmed-over flavor in cooked beef: effect of phosphate type, phosphate concentration, a lemon juice/phosphate blend, and beef extract | year = 1990 | last1 = Trout | first1 = G. R. | last2 = Dale | first2 = S. | journal = Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry | volume = 38 | issue = 3| pages = 665–669}}</ref>
==Prevention== Warmed-over flavor can be prevented by the addition of [[preservatives]] to processed meat. Many of the preservatives are [[antioxidant]]s, ranging from [[tocopherol]]s (related to vitamin E) to [[plum]] juice to industrial additives such as [[butylated hydroxytoluene]] (BHT), [[butylated hydroxyanisole]] (BHA) and [[propyl gallate]].<ref name="Frank" /> Other preservatives such as [[sodium pyrophosphate]] and [[sodium hexametaphosphate]] may work by binding iron and preventing it from catalyzing the chemical reactions which lead to warmed-over flavor; as these compounds are generally more soluble in water than the fat-soluble antioxidant preservatives, they may be more readily used to prevent oxidative decomposition in meat.<ref name="Trout" /> [[Nitrite]]s, a curing agent for meat, may prevent the development of warmed-over flavor by preventing the release of iron during cooking.<ref name="Igene">{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1016/0308-8146(85)90099-8 | title = Mechanisms by which nitrite inhibits the development of warmed-over flavour (WOF) in cured meat | year = 1985 | last1 = Igene | first1 = J. | last2 = Yamauchi | first2 = K. | last3 = Pearson | first3 = A. M. | last4 = Gray | first4 = J. I. | last5 = Aust | first5 = S. D. | journal = Food Chemistry | volume = 18 | issue = 1| pages = 1–18}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Food preservation]] * [[Rancidification]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Gustation]] [[Category:Meat]]
