revision.text:
{{Distinguish|Life unworthy of life|Wrongful birth}} {{Tort law}} '''Wrongful life''' is the name given to a [[legal action]] in which someone is sued by a severely [[disability|disabled]] child (through the child's [[legal guardian]]) for failing to prevent the child's birth.
==Definition==
Typically a child and the parents will sue a [[physician|doctor]] or a [[hospital]] for failing to provide information about the disability during the pregnancy, or a genetic disposition before the pregnancy. Had the mother been aware of this information, it is argued, she would have had an [[abortion]], or chosen not to conceive at all.
== History ==
Historically, only parents could sue for their ''own'' damages incurred as a result of the birth of a disabled child (e.g., the mother's own pregnancy medical bills and cost of psychiatric treatment for both parents' emotional distress resulting from the realization that their child was disabled). This cause of action is known as [[wrongful birth]]. But the child could not sue for his or her own damages, which were often much more substantial, in terms of the cost of round-the-clock personal care and special education.
In four [[U.S. state]]s {{citation needed|date=April 2016}} the child is allowed to bring a wrongful life [[cause of action]] for such damages. In a 1982 case involving hereditary [[Hearing impairment|deafness]], the [[Supreme Court of California]] was the first [[state supreme court]] to endorse the child's right to sue for wrongful life, but in the same decision, limited the child's recovery to special damages.<ref>''Turpin v. Sortini'', [http://online.ceb.com/CalCases/C3/31C3d220.htm 31 Cal. 3d 220] (1982).</ref><ref>{{cite web | author=Matthew O. Jannol | title =Wrongful Life and Pragmatic Justice in Light of Changing Societal Values: Turpin v. Sortini | work =Tort Stories -- Student Papers from 2003-04 | publisher =Steve Sugarman; UC Berkeley School of Law | date =2004 | url = http://www.law.berkeley.edu/9428.htm | format = doc | deadurl = yes | accessdate = March 28, 2017 | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20150221090540/http://www.law.berkeley.edu/sugarman/Turpin7.doc | archivedate = February 21, 2015}}</ref> This rule implies that the child can recover objectively provable economic damages, but cannot recover general damages like subjective "pain and suffering"—that is, monetary compensation for the entire experience of having a disabled life versus having a healthy mind and/or body.
The Supreme Court of California's 1982 decision, in turn, was based on the landmark [[California Courts of Appeal|California Court of Appeal]] decision in ''Curlender v. Bio-Science Laboratories'' (1980).<ref>''Curlender v. Bio-Science Laboratories'', [http://online.ceb.com/CalCases/CA3/106CA3d811.htm 106 Cal. App. 3d 811] (1980).</ref> The ''Curlender'' decision involved a child who was allegedly born with [[Tay-Sachs disease]] after the parents relied upon the defendants' representations about the reliability of their genetic tests in refraining from proceeding with [[amniocentesis]].
The most famous passage<ref>Robert H. Blank, ''Fetal Protection in the Workplace: Women's Rights, Business Interests, and the Unborn'' (New York: Columbia University Press, 1993), 139.</ref><ref>[[Daniel J. Kevles]], ''In the Name of Eugenics: Genetics and the Uses of Human Heredity'' (Berkeley: University of California Press, 1985), 293.</ref> from the ''Curlender'' opinion is as follows:
{{quote|The circumstance that the birth and injury have come hand in hand has caused other courts to deal with the problem by barring recovery. The reality of the "wrongful-life" concept is that such a plaintiff both exists and suffers, due to the negligence of others. It is neither necessary nor just to retreat into meditation on the mysteries of life. We need not be concerned with the fact that had defendants not been negligent, the plaintiff might not have come into existence at all. The certainty of genetic impairment is no longer a mystery. In addition, a reverent appreciation of life compels recognition that plaintiff, however impaired she may be, has come into existence as a living person with certain rights.}}
''Curlender'' was not the first appellate decision to authorize a cause of action for wrongful life—it noted that a 1977 decision of the [[New York Supreme Court, Appellate Division|intermediate appellate court of New York]] had taken the same position, and was promptly overruled by the [[New York Court of Appeals|highest court of that state]] a year later. However, ''Curlender'' stands as the first such appellate decision which was ''not'' later overruled.
Most other jurisdictions, including [[New York (state)|New York]],<ref>''Sheppard-Mobley v. King'', 4 N.Y.3d 627, 797 N.Y.S.2d 403, 830 N.E.2d 301 (2005).</ref> [[England and Wales]],<ref>''McKay v. Essex Area Health Authority'' [1982] 1 QB 1166.</ref> [[Ontario]],<ref>''Bovingdon v. Hergott'', [http://www.ontariocourts.on.ca/decisions/2008/january/2008ONCA0002.htm 2008 ONCA 2], 290 D.L.R. (4th) 126.</ref> and [[Australia]],<ref name="Harriton v Stephens">{{cite AustLII|HCA|15|2006|litigants=[[Harriton v Stephens]] |parallelcite=(2006) 226 [[Commonwealth Law Reports|CLR]] 52 |courtname=auto}}.</ref><ref name="Waller v James">{{cite AustLII|HCA|16|2006|litigants=[[Waller v James]] |parallelcite=(2006) 226 [[Commonwealth Law Reports|CLR]] 136 |courtname=auto}}.</ref> have refused to allow the wrongful life cause of action.
In [[Germany]], the [[Federal Constitutional Court of Germany|Federal Constitutional Court]] declared wrongful life claims unconstitutional. The court reasoned that such a claim implies that the life of a disabled person is less valuable than that of a non-disabled one. Therefore, claiming damages for one's life as such violates the [[Dignity#Germany|human dignity]] principle codified in the first article of the [[Basic Law for the Federal Republic of Germany|German Basic Law]].<ref>BVerfGE 88, 203 (296).</ref>
In 2005, the [[Supreme Court of the Netherlands|Dutch Supreme Court]] fully upheld a wrongful life claim in the [[Netherlands]]' first wrongful life case ever.<ref name="MedischContact">{{cite journal|last=Buijsen |first=Martin |date=3 June 2005 |title=Wrongful life-vordering gehonoreerd |trans-title=Wrongful life claim honored |journal=Medisch Contact |volume=60 |issue=22 |pages=946–948 |location=Utrecht |publisher=[[Royal Dutch Medical Association]] |language=Dutch |format=PDF |issn=0025-8245 |accessdate=23 June 2013 |url=http://medischcontact.artsennet.nl/web/file?uuid=82e949f6-a96e-43bb-a424-78810a52ba46&owner=170633d1-1865-4910-ad53-77ff653599da |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140527215407/http://medischcontact.artsennet.nl/web/file?uuid=82e949f6-a96e-43bb-a424-78810a52ba46&owner=170633d1-1865-4910-ad53-77ff653599da |archivedate=27 May 2014 |df= }}</ref>
==Ethics==
Since wrongful life suits are a relatively new application of human rights, doctors and scholars have not come to consensus regarding their place in medical ethics.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Lane|first1=Richard|title=Avraham Steinberg: leading light in faith-based medical ethics|journal=The Lancet|date=7 Jul 2015|volume=386|page=1723|doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(15)61218-1|url=http://www.thelancet.com/pdfs/journals/lancet/PIIS0140-6736(15)61218-1.pdf|accessdate=12 December 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Gillon|first1=Raanan|title='Wrongful life' claims|journal=Journal of Medical Ethics|date=1998|volume=24|page=363-364|doi=10.1136/jme.24.6.363|url=http://jme.bmj.com/content/medethics/24/6/363.full.pdf|accessdate=12 December 2017}}</ref> Others have objected to wrongful life claims on conceptual grounds, including the question of whether there exist rights and duties with regards to non-existent persons.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Mũrĩithi|first1=Paul Mũtuanyingĩ|title=Does the rejection of wrongful life claims rely on a conceptual error?|journal=Journal of Medical Ethics|date=2011|volume=37|issue=7|pages=433-436|doi=10.1136/jme.2010.042051|url=http://jme.bmj.com/content/37/7/433|accessdate=12 December 2017}}</ref>
== See also == *[[Wrongful birth]] *[[Wrongful abortion]] *[[Bioethics]]
== References == Belsky, Alan J., ''Injury as a Matter of Law: Is This the Answer to the Wrongful Life Dilemma?'', 22 U. Balt. L. Rev 185 (1993). <references/>
== Further reading == *{{cite journal |last=Appel |first=Jacob M. |pmid=15031969 |url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qa4100/is_200402/ai_n9393049/ |year=2004 |title=Physicians, 'wrongful life' and the Constitution |volume=87 |issue=2 |pages=55–8 |journal=Medicine and health, Rhode Island}} *{{cite journal |pmid=11665224 |year=1980 |last1=Foutz |first1=TK |title='Wrongful life': The right not to be born |volume=54 |issue=2 |pages=480–99 |journal=Tulane law review}} *{{cite journal|last=Perry |first=Ronen | ssrn=977852|year=2008 |title=It's a Wonderful Life |volume=93 |pages=329–399 |journal=Cornell Law Review}} http://www.bormanviolins.com/SC/belsky.htm
== External links == *[http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2004/05/02/1083436478926.html?from=storyrhs Sydney Morning Herald article from May 2004] *[http://papers.ssrn.com/abstract=977852 Article on wrongful life] in the [[Cornell Law Review]].
{{DEFAULTSORT:Wrongful Life}} [[Category:Abortion]] [[Category:Abortion law]] [[Category:Bioethics]]
[[he:הולדה בעוולה]]

{{Infobox military person | name = Yevgeny Miller | image = Evgenij Miller.jpg | image_size = | caption = General Yevgeny Miller | nickname = | birth_name = Eugen Ludwig Müller | birth_date = {{Birth date|1867|09|25|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Dünaburg]], [[Vitebsk Governorate]], [[Russian Empire]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1939|05|11|1867|09|25|df=y}} | death_place = [[Moscow|Moscow, Soviet Union]] | allegiance = {{flag|Russian Empire|1914}} | branch = [[Imperial Russian Army]]
[[White Army]] | serviceyears = 1884–1920 | rank = [[Lieutenant-General]] | battles = [[World War I]]
[[Russian Civil War]] }} '''Eugen Ludwig Müller''' ({{lang-ru|Евге́ний-Лю́двиг Ка́рлович Ми́ллер}}A. Tarulis, American-Baltic relations, 1918-1922: the struggle over recognition, Catholic University of America Press, 1965, p. 190, [[Romanisation of Russian|tr.]] {{transl|ru|Evgeniy-Lyudvig Karlovich Miller}}; 25 September 1867 – 11 May 1939), better known as '''Yevgeny Miller''', was a [[Baltic German]] general and one of the leaders of the [[anticommunist]] [[White Army]] during and after the [[Russian Civil War]] (1917-1922). After the civil war he lived in exile in France. Kidnapped by the Soviet intelligence operatives in [[Paris]] in 1937, he was smuggled to [[Moscow]], the [[USSR]], and executed there in 1939. ==Early life== Miller was a career officer born to a [[Baltic German]] noble family in Dünaburg (now [[Daugavpils]], [[Latvia]]).V. Goldin, J. Long, Resistance and Retribution: The Life and Fate of General EK Miller. Revolutionary Russia, 1999. After he graduated from the [[General Staff Academy (Imperial Russia)|General Staff Academy]], he served with the [[Russian Imperial Guard]]. Between 1898 and 1907, he was a Russian [[military attaché]] in several European capitals, such as [[Rome]], [[The Hague]] and [[Brussels]]. During the [[First World War]], he headed the [[Moscow]] military district and the 5th Russian Army and was promoted to the rank of [[lieutenant general]]. ==Civil War== After the [[February Revolution]] of 1917, Miller opposed "democratization" of the Russian army and was arrested by his own soldiers after he ordered them to remove red armbands. After the [[Russian Revolution of 1917|October Revolution]] of 1917, Miller fled to [[Archangelsk]] and declared himself [[Governor-General]] of Northern Russia. In May 1919, [[Admiral Kolchak]] appointed him to be in charge of the [[White movement|White Army]] in the region. In [[Archangelsk]], [[Murmansk]] and [[Olonets]], his anti-Bolshevik [[Northern Army (Russia)| Northern Army]] was supported by the [[Triple Entente]], mostly [[United Kingdom|British]] forces. However, after an unsuccessful advance against the [[Red Army]] along the [[Northern Dvina]] in the summer of 1919, British forces withdrew from the region, and Miller's men faced the enemy alone. ==Exile== [[File:Evgeny Miller1.png|thumb|upright|General Yevgeny Miller in 1930s]] In February 1920, General Miller with 800 refugees sailed from Archangelsk to [[Tromsø]], [[Norway]]. Later, he moved to [[France]] and, together with [[Grand Duke Nicholas Nikolaevich of Russia (1856–1929)|Grand Duke Nicholas]] and [[Pyotr Nikolayevich Wrangel]], continued his anticommunist activism. Between 1930 and 1937, Miller served as chairman of the [[Russian All-Military Union]], an organization of exiled former White Army officers and soldiers opposed to the Soviet Union. His niece, [[Nathalie Sergueiew]], also fled to France and subsequently became an [[MI5]] agent.[http://www.svobodanews.ru/content/article/24531603.html Собачье сердце и двойной обман] As the ROVS chairman, Miller was not an influential figure, as he did not belong to the dominant clan in the ROVS, namely former members of the White Army of [[South Russia (1919–1920)|South Russia]], nor the former ″Gallipoli campers″.″Врангелов неоспорни ауторитет: Из тајних архива УДБЕ: РУСКА ЕМИГРАЦИЈА У ЈУГОСЛАВИЈИ 1918–1941.″ // ''[[Politika]]'', 8 December 2017, p. 17. ==Kidnapping== On 22 September 1937, [[NKVD]] agent and [[Inner Line|All-Military Union counter-intelligence]] chief [[Nikolai Skoblin]] led Miller to a Paris [[safe house]], ostensibly to meet with two German [[Abwehr]] agents, who were in fact officers of the Soviet NKVD disguised as Germans. They drugged Miller, placed him in a steamer trunk and smuggled him aboard a Soviet ship in [[Le Havre]].{{sfn|Sudoplatov|1994|pp=38, 91}}″Помирљивост према политичким партијама: Из тајних архива УДБЕ: РУСКА ЕМИГРАЦИЈА У ЈУГОСЛАВИЈИ 1918–1941.″ // ''[[Politika]]'', 12 December 2017, p. 21. Miller had left behind a note to be opened in case he failed to return from the meeting. In it, he detailed his suspicions about Skoblin. French police launched a massive manhunt, but Skoblin fled to the Soviet embassy in Paris and eventually was smuggled to [[Barcelona]], where the [[Second Spanish Republic]] refused to extradite him to France.Barmine, Alexander, ''One Who Survived'', New York: G.P. Putnam (1945), pp. 232–233 However, the French authorities arrested Skoblin's wife, [[Nadezhda Plevitskaya]], and a French court convicted her and sentenced her to 20 years in prison.Orlov, Alexander, ''The March of Time'', St. Ermin's Press (2004), {{ISBN|1-903608-05-8}} The NKVD successfully smuggled Miller back to [[Moscow]], where he was tortured and summarily shot nineteen months later on 11 May 1939. According to NKVD General [[Pavel Sudoplatov]], "His kidnapping was a [[cause célèbre]]. Eliminating him disrupted his organization of Tsarist officers and effectively prevented them from collaborating with the Germans against us."{{sfn|Sudoplatov|1994|p=37}} Sudoplatov also notes that Western accounts of NKVD officer [[Nahum Eitingon|Leonid Eitingon]] having played a role in the abduction of Miller are false.{{sfn|Sudoplatov|1994|p=36}} Copies of letters written by Miller while imprisoned in Moscow are in the [[Dmitri Volkogonov]] papers at the [[Library of Congress]]. ==In popular culture== The kidnapping was the subject of a book written by [[Anatoly Rybakov]], ''The Fear''. It was also the basis of the French film ''[[Triple agent (film)|Triple Agent]]'' (2004), directed by [[Éric Rohmer]]. General Miller appears as General Fedchenko in [[Vladimir Nabokov]]'s story "The Assistant Producer", in which he is betrayed by "General Golubkov". The kidnapping of General Miller was fictionalized in [[Nikita Mikhalkov]]'s award-winning film ''[[Burnt by the Sun]]''. In the film the character known as "Mitya" ([[Oleg Menshikov]]) is a former White Army officer turned NKVD agent. Posing as a pianist in Paris, Mitya is described as having delivered eight White Generals to the NKVD. All are described as having been kidnapped, returned to Moscow, and shot without trial. One of the Generals is given the name "Weiner". ==See also== * [[List of people who disappeared mysteriously]] * [[Mikhail Kvetsinsky]], Miller's chief of staff * [[North Russia Intervention]] * [[Russian All-Military Union]] * [[White movement]] ==Notes and citations== {{reflist}} ==References== {{commons category|Evgeny Miller}} ===Books=== * {{cite book | last = Sudoplatov | first = Pavel | authorlink = Pavel Sudoplatov | title = [[Special Tasks|Special Tasks: The Memoirs of an Unwanted Witness — A Soviet Spymaster]] | publisher = Little, Brown & Co. | location = Boston, MA | year = 1994 | isbn = 0316773522 | url = | ref = harv }} * Barmine, Alexander, ''One Who Survived'', New York: G.P.
